description:
Best focaccia I've had stateside.

Terrible operating hours though.
author: Alex L.

description:
No BS bakery!!!
Yes it is old and dingy inside, yes she is not wearing gloves, yes no hello and thank you, yes cash only and all that...
But? This is best bakery in SF and no trip to town is complete without going to Liguria. My standard order is Pizza and Mushrooms. 
I never had a bad experience. I will keep coming back as long as they are baking...!!!
author: Rahi Y.

description:
Expect: Best foccacia in Bay Area!

Don't Expect: Cleanliness (wish the ladies use gloves). A smile or thank you. Any left if you don't order in advance or arrive past ~11am.
author: Take-out Princess M.

description:
I had to come into this corner bakery considering how short the mid morning line was on a weekend. They had just the basics inside. Just a few taken chairs, a counter manned by two women and the letter board menu. The focaccia options were listed in price ascending order. I went with a pesto cheese for $6.50 and cut up to snack on while wandering in North Beach.

Sneaking a peek into the back, you can see the brick oven, storing racks and a table to slice and wrap slabs of focaccia up. You place your order, pay cash only, they disappear into the back, and come back with your food.

It's so soft, moist and fluffy! The pesto cheese seemed to be a special and it was light yet indulgent. Really delicious bread.
author: Samantha L.

description:
This was my first stop during my trip to San Francisco. My friend had recommended it to me as a MUST for something really tasty. My friend and I woke up on our first day and made our way there around the time it opened at 8 AM.

When we arrived there was already a line of about 6 people there 5 minutes after the store had opened. After ordering and trying their namesake focaccia for myself I understand why! Focaccia is a baked flat bread which originated from Italy. The family that is behind this store has been operating it for over a hundred years in the San Francisco area! When it came time to order I went with the Rosemary Garlic ($5.50). Fair warning, this is a CASH ONLY establishment. Make sure to come with a few bucks and you'll be set.

The rosemary garlic was out of this world. It literally was a HUGE piece of flatbread that was extremely tasty. My friend and I actually got our focaccia to go and walked to nearby Washington Square Park and sat on a bench to watch the people walking around while enjoying our flatbreads. I'd definitely recommend it if you've got some time to spare.

Overall a great place to get an authentic Italian flatbread with a variety of different flavors to choose from!
author: Nicholas C.

description: My absolute favorite bakery in the City. No frills, delicious quality bread. I go every time I'm in the area.
author: Vince W.

description:
I got $16 worth of focaccia bread here - pizza, jalapeno cheddar, and olive. They were thick, beautiful slabs wrapped in parchment paper and I just loved the storefront and efficiency. No goods on display, no credit cards, only cash. Very anachronistic but it should be more of the norm. 

The focaccia. So good. I ate most of it by myself. My favorite was the pizza, which is slathered in tomato sauce and green onion. Olive, second favorite. Jalapeno cheddar, excellent but in retrospect - I should have paid honor to the elegance of Italian elements only.  

I then signed up for a 5k tomorrow, and a half marathon in 2 weeks. Not a joke. Am I in training? Nah. I am definitely fueled by super premium octane carbs and mind over matter. I got this. It will be my first race in over a year, so thank you Liguria Bakery! 

We all have to find our motivation, right?
author: Spartevan V.

description:
Amazing focaccia. Tip: call ahead and reserve your bread in advance. They sell out by mid-morning. Located in North Beach it is a must go!

We will be back!
author: Wendy C.

description:
Yes!!! I finally woke up early enough to run out here on Saturday morning to try their famous focaccia bread! I hadn't read reviews but I've heard from a few friends that the bread here was amazing, so I thought I MUST give it a try. Upon walking in and waiting in line, I already noticed that these two women working (owners?) looked as if they were NOT happy to be there. SUPER grumpy, impatient and flat out unhelpful. Being my first time there, I didn't feel welcomed or simply comfortable enough to even ask any questions. So I just looked at the board and asked for two flavors. 

VERY QUESTIONABLE WHETHER OR NOT THEY WASH THEIR HANDS BEFORE HANDLING FOOD. 

I see that they use their BARE hands to hold my bread... and bare hands to receive CASH. Honestly, I don't care how clean your hands are, they're still your HANDS. You perspire. You can have sh*t stuck in your nails. Cross contamination!!! What if someone is allergic to garlic or onion or one of your other flavors? I'm sorry but food safety is one thing I can't turn a blind eye to.

Having said all that, I did eat/try the bread anyway, and it was good, no doubt. But not amazing, other worldly good. Not food poisoning worthy good. 

Sad (or not so sad) to say, I won't be returning.
author: Athena L.

description:
anytime anyone tells me that they're going to SF Bay I ALWAYS recommend this place.

I was here for a work trip and one of the born and bred locals took me here. he said to me: if I don't help you with anything during this entire trip other than taking you to this one spot, it'll be enough... so I obviously ditched my laptop and started walkin... this small cash only place is on a corner in little Italy. we walk in and there's a small Italian woman with a huge personality behind the counter to greet me and my friend (who she knew by name). we ordered the focaccia --the pizza style which simply has a tiny bit of red sauce and the rosemary garlic. and my goodness... my local was right... it was the best thing (and frankly the only useful thing) that he showed me the entire trip! I went back before my trip ended to bring some home.... needless to say, it didn't make it to my house lol.
author: Rucinda S.

description:
I crossed paths with Liguria Bakery when visiting Washington Square. On a Saturday at 11 am there were a bunch of people outside grumbling that they were completely sold out. This perked my interest and a couple of days ago when I happened to be in the area earlier in the day, I saw that there was no line so decided to give it a try. There was an old lady behind the counter and another younger one who was doing something inside.

The older lady was getting irritated with a young woman who was asking questions that any first timer would want to know. After two answers she ignored any further questions and just pointed to the barebones ordering board which had Focaccia written on top, followed by what I assumed were toppings. The young woman just stood there completely confused not knowing what to do next.

Anyway while this drama was playing out the younger lady came out and decided to deal with the next person in line which was me. After seeing the fate of the other customer I decided not to ask any questions and simply asked for the pizza focaccia ($5.50) as I had never seen or even hear of this topping, and replied yes for it to be cut. The young lady disappeared inside and returned with a package containing the pizza focaccia bread. No cards were accepted so I paid with cash and got out without being insulted.

The focaccia bread was pretty good. It was nice and fluffy without being doughy. The pizza toppings were basically tomato sauce and scallions. Overall it was pretty good. Price was also pretty cheap for the area. 

I think this place is comparable to Golden Gate Bakery (which sells egg tarts). Its popularity is attributed to the scarcity value of the product rather than on the merit of the product. However good the product is, there is no reason for poor service. I'll leave this one for tourists, and only if I happen to be in the area early in the morning, will I return and try some more toppings from their menu.
author: Ahmad J.

description:
I love Liguria Bakery! I've been eating this focaccia for my entire life and it's amazing. It is the best focaccia I've ever had. 

I used to buy Liguria's focaccia from Genova Delicatessen in Oakland before it closed. I believe the focaccia used to get delivered there once a week. Unfortunately, Genova in Oakland closed and so I haven't had my fix of Liguria focaccia for a while. 

I have also gone to Liguria's Bakery in San Francisco a handful of times. However, it has been years since I've gone out to SF to get the focaccia because you have to go early and there's usually traffic in the morning. If you don't go in the morning there will be a chance that the focaccia will sell out. 

I went to Liguria Bakery last Saturday. I went around 8:30/9am to make sure I got all the different kinds of focaccia that I wanted. I believe Liguria's hours say that they are open until 2pm however they close when they sell out. Liguria usually sells out. From reading other reviews I believe they tend to sell out around 11:30am. 


Liguria Bakery is very small inside. There are a couple cashiers and standing room for about 5-10 people. You can see the focaccia in the back cooling and waiting to be cut and packaged. It is pretty cool to see because there are a lot of sheets of focaccia. 

I recommend being ready with what you want when you order. The people working at Liguria weren't extremely friendly but they weren't rude to me either. They basically ask you what you want and package the focaccia for you nothing more. 

There are many kinds of focaccia to choose from. I've tried the raisin, pizza, plain, pesto, and onion. My favorites are the pizza, pesto, and raisin. The raisin focaccia is sweet so it is a little different than the others. The pizza focaccia has sauce and onions on it. The pesto is pesto and cheese. This time I got the pizza and pesto focaccia. The focaccia is sold in sheets. (see pictures for the size) I think the sheets are a good size and they are about $5 each some are a little more depending on the toppings. You can also get the sheet cut into smaller pieces so you can eat them on the go or just get them wrapped in paper and tied. 

I am giving Liguria 5 stars because of the amazing and fresh focaccia. The price and the size of the sheets are great as well. The customer service may not be amazing but that's okay because I go to Liguria Bakery for the focaccia and not the service. I definitely recommend this place if you would like to try fresh and delicious focaccia!

TIP: The longer you wait to eat the focaccia the less fresh it is; the focaccia will get harder so it is best to eat it within the first day or so of buying it. (That way it's nice and soft!) However, that won't be hard to do because it's so delicious! 

Enjoy!
Simona
author: Simona N.

description:
Came here for a quick stop by for the first time and wasn't expecting too much. Although after I ordered my food I was impressed. 

We came as a group and they quickly served us all of and we got pesto and pizza slices. 

The pizza was amazing. It was served cold but was still super amazing! The sauce was really good and I just about died from joy. 

Only thing is they seemed someone frustrated but that's fine because the food was great haha
author: Brandon S.

description:
What a cool little spot. I enjoyed reading the reviews for this place almost as much as the focaccia itself.

What I've noticed on Yelp is that often times service at spots isn't as bad as some people make it out to be. People feed off your energy. Is the lady who runs this spot going to win Mrs. Congeniality at the pageant ...no...but if you don't like her style there are many other places to in the city to check out ( that's the beauty of SF or any big city for that matter). 

Meeting her was like meeting the principal in Elementary school for me  because of all the stories/accounts I read...lol...and you know what I met her with positivity and I think I even made her smile. My total came out to $11 and I even gave her $21 to make the change giving " a little easier" ( wink wink) . 

I could also see that she had positive relationships with many members of the local community, so that told me all I needed to know. 

Shout out to the old misunderstood lady who serves up bomb focaccia . I went with my buddies suggestion of Pizza and Rosemary and I wasn't disappointed. Maybe I just have a sweet spot for senior citizens : o p
author: Rod M.

description:
How do they make bread so delicious??

We were on the first flight into SFO, got our rental and made our way to North Beach. It was past 10am by the time we got to Washington Square. When we walked in there were only 3 types of focaccia available. 5 minutes later, when we walked out, there were only 2... Damn!

The bread is so soft and the flavors are so delicious. We got 2 pesto cheese and 2 mushroom. We had 1 of each sliced up and the other 2 left whole and wrapped in paper and string as a gift to our friends that we were meeting for lunch at the Ferry Building. I love that they do that. It's classic being that it's all wrapped up in old school paper & string. I love long standing places like Liguria Bakery and the history they bring. I grew up in San Francisco and Liguria is certainly a city institution. It should be revered and always supported.

The mushroom focaccia was very tasty. The bread was soft and the mushroom topping added a great flavor to it. Just so good. So much flavor... The pesto cheese was also very good. It was a little on the salty side due to the cheese but I didnt mind it at all. I am not the biggest pesto fan but this was very good. I would get it again for sure. The mushroom as well.

The mushroom was $5.50 each and the pesto cheese was $6.50 each. Well worth it... Cash only. Street parking only. I will be back on my next trip home for sure. Hoping to try the other flavors.

Best foccacia bread ever.
author: Chuck D.

description:
I don't really eat focaccia...but when I do...I get it from this place!

Family owned and operated. Good price - around $6 for a paper bag full of it. And plenty of flavor options. You can't beat it! 

Buy some, go to Washington square, and eat it there while enjoying the beautiful Bay Area weather!!!
author: Ryan N.

description:
Can't get enough of their focaccia!

I definitely recommend coming early because their focaccia sells like hot cakes, gone from 0 - 100 real quick. My favorite is their mushroom and i always get multiple cause I can eat it in just one sitting. It's that delicious and addictive and can't find another place like them. 

Why go elsewhere when you can have the original?
author: Eva O.

description:
Since we've return from our trip from Italy my husband has been trying to make his secret focaccia recipe. It's almost been a year now...lol He found this place and decided that we were going to food adventure! 

You walk in to this small shop with the menu hanging over the register and a sign that says CASH ONLY. Our eyes widen as we stare at each other and check if we had enough cash. We managed to have enough cash for 2 slices. Good thing there slices were big and a steal. If we had brought more cash we would have probably bought one of each flavor.

About the flavors, I know nothing about authenticity when it comes to focaccia but I can tell you this, it is soft, pillowy, and has the perfect amount of bounce in each bite and a bit of crunch. Note that you would not have this same sensation eating on the spot so you are going to have to take it home and pop it in the toaster oven. If you are okay with eating it cold, its just as good. Lots of flavor for such a simple and complex piece of bread. I would highly recommend checking this place out. If your looking for something thats instagram worthy or hip move on. This is your traditional mom and pap place that serves really good focaccia.
author: Cynthia W.

description:
Focaccia bread. They have so many different types of em! From plain, to pizza, to mushroom, to jalapeño cheese... yummy! Jalapeño cheese is probably my favorite, although these seem to always run out or not have it when I get there. The rest are pretty good too!

Come early, they close when they sell out! 

Also cash only!
author: Melody W.

description:
I love that this place exist! Focaccia is one of my favorite breads because it's so tasty and easy to eat, by itself, as part of a sandwich or open face avocado toast. It's so hard to find focaccia freshly baked and ready to order unless you go to a good Italian restaurant.

I was so excited to visit Liguria and am happy to say that it did not disappoint. The pizza focaccia, jalapeno cheese, and rosemary focaccia are all delicious, flavorful, perfectly fluffy and versatile in different ways. Made well, enjoyable to munch on as a snack or sandwiched with delicious Italian cheese and charcuterie.

You won't be disappointed! Perfect place to stop by before heading out for picnic at a park!
author: Jenny Z.

description: Lines are crazy long, even before opening. Location is great, staff is friendly and bread is baked daily. The onion and tomato focaccia is must get. Enjoy at he park across the street.
author: Juan M.

description:
The absolute best focaccia you can find in San Francisco!  Located on the northwest corner of iconic Washington Square Park in beautiful North Beach, Liguria Bakery is a must try for locals and visitors alike.  My favorites are the Jalapeno and the Rosemary & Garlic, but you can't go wrong with any of the delectable choices, which also include Onion, Olive, Garlic and Plain (another word for non-embellished deliciousness!).

TIP: The focaccia is very modestly priced, but bring cash because they do not accept plastic or eCommerce payments of any kind.

TIPP: Since you're already there, don't forget to visit Tony's Pizza Nepolitana (southwest corner of the park), another not-to-be-missed spot for what just may be the best pizza on the continent!
author: Damon C.

description: Since I was wee high, I loved the bread. The crabby ladies are slightly nicer to kids. But, as an old person now who has traveled and traveled (yes, Italy, New York, etc.) this is the best damn focaccia bread and the most authentic experience to be had. Quit your griping, get some good olive oil, heat up the onion (in foil), have a bit of sea salt on hand and go to town. Get there, early, cash only and only a matter of time before they're gone so go now.
author: Elizabeth C.

description:
I don't know what to say except AMAZING! I've been going here since I was about 3 or 4. This place is the best place to get focaccia! No lie. Along with many toppings! It's THE BEST. The Pizza Focaccia is my favorite and the Mushroom is OUT OF THIS WORLD! Also the people working there are extremely nice! 

Love this place. Love the atmosphere. GO THERE! You will not regret it!
author: Aaron L.

description: This is THE place to go for authentic and delicious focaccia. I came here a few years ago during the holiday time, and the line was pretty long in the afternoon. Sadly, they had already run out of a few of the focaccia types, but there was still plenty to go around. I brought them over to a party and they were a hit! I haven't had a chance to come back to Liguria, but highly recommend coming here if you're a focaccia lover! Parking can be difficult in this area, but there is a good amount of metered spots available.
author: Amy D.

description: Came around 11 and they were at their last piece of mushroom, but they were nice enough to let me know that it was missing a lot of mushrooms, so I chose the pizza instead and it was so delicious!!! $5.50 a piece and you can ask for it cut into pieces. Can't wait to try the other flavors!
author: Shabnam E.

description:
I've grown up here in NorthBeach, Bi-coastal, & world traveler, too. Best focaccia, just ck out tomato/pizza, garlic/rosemary, or raisin...some of my faves! Go as early as u can, shop closes early, when square pieces of heaven are sold out for the day.
Loyal "Little-, now Big-boy" hoping Liguria/Soracco bakery will go another 100+ yrs...
author: Rod O.

description:
Let me caveat and say that I'm not even a huge fan of focaccia bread but this place has won my heart over for it's fluffy and delectable little slices of heaven.

Thank goodness I live nearby and can walk over during their odd hours to pick up some loaves. It's cash only.

When you walk inside there's usually two ladies manning the old school bakery. The older lady is always there and seems to be the boss lady. I've seen her get her hair did at a local hair salon too so she's definitely authentic and super italian! 

I've had the pizza focaccia which is essentially plain focaccia with a slathering of tomato sauce and green onion, the mushroom focaccia, and the cheese/jalapeno combo.

I have to say my favorite was the pizza! It was just so perfect with its combo of fluffy bread with a nice smear of tomato -- perfect for tomato fanatics like me! 

The mushroom was a tad salty for my liking. The cheese and jalapeno was also delicious. I think their ultimate winning combo would be some sort of hybrid of the pizza version with a sprinkling of cheese. 

If you peer in the back you can see where the magic happens. I'm sure this local bakery has been here for years so you can really taste the magic and most importantly the love that goes inside every little piece. 

Make sure you ask for them to cut it up if you're consuming on the go.
author: Connie M.

description: This place has been serving excellent focaccia for years. They also carry Italian dessert cookies. Only accept cash, and frequently run out of some of the popular types within 2 hours after opening.
author: Lucy G. K.

description:
Rosemary focaccia I tried wasn't greasy or overly oily but incredibly delicious with balanced ingredients that provided enough flavor to keep me snacking. The texture had a lightness and bounce and after consuming that bread I didn't feel weighed down or bloated. For $5.50 per generous portion I'd consider it a bargain and a great way to start your morning in SF. Next time I'm buying multiple loafs. 

Oh yeah: it's an old school location with traditional real Italian people still running the show. Can't beat that, either.
author: Lew A.

description:
This is the real deal. It's exactly like in Italy.
Get any of their focaccia and it's perfect, soft and with the right amount of fat. My favorite is the rosemary one, which is even a little sweet.
Get it in the morning before they run out, and heat it in the oven for dinner with some ham and cheese. Just perfect.

PS: to the people who complain about customer service: grow up. Nobody is here to listen to you whining about how you didn't get your pumpkin spice latte with the right amount of pumpkin, or about how an old lady (who's worked in a bakery her whole life, totally fluent in two languages, when you can barely say "hola amigo") didn't smile at you.
author: Alberto L.

description: I popped by here on a Saturday morning around 10AM and there wasn't too bad of a line. I was glad to see the foccacia weren't sold out entirely. It was apparent that the women working knew almost everybody in the neighborhood, which gave the place a really homey, family vibe. Anyways, we got the pizza and the pesto cheese. Both were delicious, but the pesto cheese was even better warmed up. They give it to you served in giant slabs wrapped in paper and tied with twine. I'm not sure if they cut it for you if you ask, but we didn't and had to make a mess tearing up the bread with our fingers lol. They also sell frozen ones so you can take home and bake it yourself.
author: Jen L.

description: The focaccia here is still the best in North Beach.  However, they must've fallen on hard times as of late because a member of our family came home with a slab of the usually good'n'tasty focaccia BUT it was noticeably much smaller than the usual size.  A stunning disappointment.
author: Benjamin T.

description:
I haven't been here since I was in middle school. I used to go to school down the hill and they used to sell all day. On the days we would get out early everyone would just walk up and order focaccia for lunch. But this was almost a decade ago. Now it is first come first serve and only until they sell out. Which is pretty fast, latest is by 12pm of you are lucky. We came in at 9 am and I noticed they was already running low. Parking might be hard, so you might have to circle around a few times. But if you go when they open you will have an easier time. They also post if they are going on vacation in the store and the front door, not online. 

It is cash only! Today I order sliced pizza and raisin. The total was $11, $5.50 each. This place is just like I remember as a kid. The focaccia is soft and fluffy, with just a little crisp on the edge. The pizza was super flavorful and delicious. The green onion was not over powering. The raisin had the perfect balance of sweetness. Don't expect great service. This place is a quick in and out. Their service may not always be the best but they are fast and you get a good amount for what you pay for. If you have time in the morning I will highly recommend it.
author: Michelle C.

description: Great fresh focaccia right out of the oven. Made fresh daily. Flavors: Plain, Onion, Pizza, Raisin, Garlic, Rosemary, Mushroom, Black Olive, Rosemary Garlic, Jalapeno Cheese. Get there early, Sold until they run out! If so, check the freezer for leftovers frozen at a reduced price.
author: Les W.

description: A North Beach institution for a reason. This is the perfect place to grab a snack before people watching at Washington Square Park. The focaccia is unsurprisingly way better than any I've had from supermarkets, so my bar was set low before visiting Liguria. In any case, I like the focaccia only-menu, no nonsense service, and spartan look and feel of the shop. The bakery is no frills but the goods speak for themselves. Try the pizza, raisin, or olive focaccia, which are great on their own or as a warm side dish. Don't forget to bring cash!
author: Edwina D.

description:
I too love this place.  The first time a friend brought me here I thought it was some sort of covert place run by the CIA.  Just empty shelves and one woman working behind the counter.

My friend knew what to ask for and how to ask politely and her order was filled in lightening speed.  Pizza is my favorite, but you can't go wrong with any flavor available.  Onion, olive, rosemary, raisin all delicious.  Like everyone says, cash only.  Best bargain in town!
author: Dennis R.

description: All their breads, you cannot go wrong. I'm a fan of the pizza bread myself. Inexpensive and reminds me of what I ate when I traveled to Italy
author: Peter N.

description:
Seriously HEAVENLY focaccia bread. The pizza was not like anything I've ever had, and if this is how they make focaccia bread in Italy, then goshdarnit, it's legit. 

Customer service lacking as others have mentioned, but this neighborhood classic is worth a visit if in the area or having breakfast across the street. The slab of bread is only $5.50 (cash only?) and will easily feed two people as a meal or serve as a great appetizer to any gathering (a serious hit at any party). Also lacking is cleanliness as I saw the bread being handled along with the register and money, but I felt much better eating it after I had toasted it at home.
author: Jan P.

description:
Was in San Francisco last month and on my way back to New York I stopped off at 7:45 in the morning to bring pizza, mushroom, olive and rosemary home as a treat for my wife...needless to say folks on the plane were very jealous....
Have been coming to this spot for about 20 years. The best ever.
Wife happy.
author: N G.

description: Best focaccia I have had in my entire life. I won't even consider trying another bakery for my focaccia. I am never disappointed with the quality. Great staff! One of my favorite parts about coming to SF!!!
author: John M.

description:
My family has been serving Liguaria focaccia at holidays and gatherings since as long as I can remember. It is the BEST! Pizza and Plain onion are my faves. I also really like Jalapeno cheddar. 

I have to say I just read some of the one star reviews and it made me giggle. Please don't go to this place with any expectations other that getting great focaccia bread. Don't expect 5 star service. They don't take cards. Their hours are short and often close early because they sell out. I personally love in this modern world we live in, that this place is a no nonsense establishment that sells delicious bread. If you are looking for a smile with your service, there are plenty of places all over north beach that can help you, but you will be missing out on this amazing bread. Choose your battles wisely.
author: Silvio S.

description:
It's so refreshing popping into a 'no frills' establishment and walking out with high quality grub!

I live in the neighborhood and stopped by on a Friday afternoon. Luckily there wasn't a wait, however, the old woman running the show mentioned that a number of flavors had already sold out.

I ordered the pizza focaccia and boy, was I pleased! Yes, the dough is super soft and spongy and the tomato sauce savory - my taste buds sensed a touch of umami/soy sauce flavoring??

I'll be back again to try out the other flavors :)
author: Christine T.

description: The absolute best Foccacia in the Western Hemisphere.  My Grandparents who came to this country around 1900 lived a couple of blocks from there.  I grew up on this, during WWII my relatives all tried to replicate this recipe!  I miss it so much, I now live out of state but have great memories of this place.  If I'm lucky, my sister sends me some each year.  THE VERY BEST, NEVER TO BE FOUND ANYWHERE!!!  Please stay in business!! I would go back to SF just for this!!  We didn't have all the choices they offer now, but the raisin was to die for
author: Angela V.

description: The food is great we got the onion and the jalapeño with cheese focaccia and both tasted great. Whenever we are in the city we make sure to stop by. It's always the same mother daughter duo. The price might seem expensive but once you see what you get you realize it's not.
author: Albert M.

description: Best focaccia you'll ever have!! I buy my focaccia exclusively from Liguria Bakery. It's just that amazing. My favorite flavor is pizza. The service is terrible though. The lady who runs the place is extremely rude. I just laugh it off though. It adds character to the place. If you're willing to wait in a line that wraps around the block, then I recommend you try some pizza focaccia from Liguarias!
author: Fred B.

description:
Know it well (knew it well). Been in the place since the 1950's when it was old North Beach and just about only Italians frequented Liguria Bakery.  In those days bread and panettone were also baked...good stuff. Times change, the Italians move away...to Colma.
What we have now is the gentrification of North Beach, focaccia is "discovered" and a mother and daughter (whatever their relationship, though of the same ilk), more akin to a WWF tag team have the opportunity to treat curious customers poorly, with their arrogant, take it or leave it attitude.  The old Soracco's would roll over in their graves to see this floor show.
What exist now is a fair product served with attitude!

Ciao!
Bart Solari
author: Bart S.

description:
Best. Focaccia. Ever.

That's all I need to say about this place. Their focaccia comes in large flat sheets and is so incredibly fluffy, soft, and flavorful. I've had the raisin, cheddar jalapeno, and pizza focaccias and my favorite was the cheddar jalapeno by far. The jalapeno isn't super spicy and is actually tangy with just a slight kick.

They only make one large batch in the morning and close for the day once they sell out, so get there early!
author: Tiffany P.

description:
Iconic place in San Feancisco!! Must visit if you have never tried. Been coming here since I was a kid and no place has come close. 

Fresh and amazing pizza bread. My favorite is the pesto cheese which is only available on Saturdays . FYI, this place closes early usually by 12pm or when they sell out. Also closed on Sunday and Mondays.

Why wait in line at Mamas when that place isn't even good. Staff is always the same here so be prepared to order.

This place is a staple to San Francisco and is recommended to any visitors or out of towners
author: Nicholas k.

description:
I've been coming for years to this no-nonsense family-owned place, which is now in its third generation, and it's always a treat. 

This time, we got the onion (scallion), rosemary (the garlic rosemary was already gone), and the olive. All delicious!

Still vegetarian, they now have one non-vegan foccacia (jalapeno cheese).

Highly recommended.
author: Veg V.

description:
This is the best focaccia I've had outside of Liguria. For those who don't know, the namesake of this bakery, Liguria, is a region in Northwest Italy (between Tuscany and the French riviera). Ligurians invented and perfected focaccia. Different cities throughout the region have their own takes on focaccia, but Genova has the best.

I lived in Liguria for about a year, and this is the best focaccia I've had outside the region. It's better than what you can get in 95% of Italy.

Get the plain. Get the onion. Get whatever is left when you're ordering. You won't regret it. This is so much better than the too-thick, not oily or crispy enough garbage you get everywhere else. This focaccia is sublime.

Pro tip: if you're craving something sweet, get the plain focaccia and eat it with Nutella. You're welcome.
author: Dyl M.

description:
I've always past by here in the afternoons and it's usually closed. What intrigued me about this place is how rustic it looked inside. Simple and untouched from back in the days.

Whenever I get a chance to come here, it's always in the morning. Once they're out of a certain type of focaccia, that is it. They are not small focaccia sizes either, it's about the size of a laptop is how I would describe it. Pesto and cheese are a special and they mainly have that during Saturdays or on special holidays. The garlic is good and goes simply when heated and with balsamic vinegar and olive oil. 

Very much a neighborhood gem.
author: Mandy D.

description: The bread is great but the younger lady, if you can even call her that, in the front is rude. She cussed me out after I was trying to open the freezer and she had a couple of preorders stacked on top. She yelled at me that I'm breaking her freezer dropped a couple f-bombs at me. I get it... I probably shouldn't have opened it but you don't have to be rude about it. I don't think I'll be back here for a while. The other customers were just as shocked at how unprofessional she is.
author: Nichole P.

description: We love them!!! I've grown up with them when I used to be a student at Sts Peter and Paul School. That's when the prices were around $1 or so. Regardless, their bread is still great. I always make a special order for parties that I have to go to. My friends almost always expect me to bring them the infamous focaccia bread. My favorite is the onions. My kids favorite is the black olive. My husband's favorite is their raisin. You can't go wrong with what you choose. Yes people always make comment about the staff but they are a staple. That's just them and I wouldn't change it in anyway. I definitely recommend this place.
author: Cynthia L.

description:
I had a day off from work on 12/23 so went to visit the old neighborhood of North Beach.  Stood in line from 10-noon for Italian bread.  (I heard the line is longer on 12/24.)  There was a group of kids, donning Santa hats, serenading us with Christmas songs.  Someone left a box of coffee, cups, and cream for the community.  It was a long wait, but the experience was pleasant.  Moreover, my fond memories of eating this yummy bread in my carefree childhood days made it bearable to wait in line for 2 hours in the rain.  Hubby complained so I send him off to run errands in order to keep him busy.  The prices have gone up over the years, it is about $5 for a quarter sheet now.  They have also added many variety of flavors like mushroom, rosemary garlic, and jalapeno cheese.  I hear January is slow season for them, but that's also when everyone goes back to work.

Pizza flavor will always be my favorite, but all their flavors are good.  Soft and bouncy with a little crispy.  Frozen bread are cheaper, only $3.
author: Connie W.

description: I make special trips to Liguria's for my friends and family.  The pizza's soft dough is unique.  I have tried their other offerings; the pizza is the one I come back for; it's best the first day, or you can toast later.
author: Michael S.

description: They're mostly distributing to other bakeries/restaurants, so their hours are a bit funky.  Luckily for me, I don't really work normal hours so I've gotten to drop by on a weekday morning when there's no one there (and of course went prepared with cash).  I love the pizza focaccia!  But I love pizza.  Well...it's awesome bread.  The bestest.
author: starrynight c.

description: Never been a fan of foccacia bread.  But this place was excellent.  Very yummy.  Moist and tasty.
author: John C.

description: I grew up with this and this is the only place that I will eat foccaccia from.  There are a lot of companies who try to copy this but they should be avoided.  If this review doesn't tell you what you need to know then don't go and buy it there and leave it all for us to buy.  They sell out too quickly.
author: Vicki S.

description: Good focaccia no doubt, but they handle food and money with the same unwashed hands. Money is one of the most dirtiest things you can touch. After seeing this, the focaccia has lost some appeal.
author: H L.

description: I stopped by this place on my way to climb the Coit tower. I walked in and I could tell they didn't need my business. Lady up front told me they didn't have much left. I took whatever I could and she just plopped it on the counter. I felt lucky to to have this bread. I took it and scurried away. Next I started climbing the hill to reach the Coit tower. Let me tell you, it's very hard to stuff your mouth with delicious focaccia bread while you are huffing and puffing for air. Especially challenging when bread is so good that you have to make a hard choice between continuing to breathe versus take another bite of the bread. I could feel I was getting light headed as I shoved the last bit of the bread in my mouth, then I finally took a deep breath. Then... I grabbed another piece of bread. I eventually made it up the tower. Probably only because they don't allow food inside the Coit tower.
author: Mark C.

description:
I have never liked focaccia. 

But on my new(ish) walk to grad school, I passed by this place and decided to try it because the Yelp reviews are so positive. 

Now I like focaccia.

The stuff they make here is buttery, fluffy, savory, and comforting. They'll cut it into strips and roll it up for you, making it the ultimate portable snack/breakfast. They only take cash--roughly $5-6 for a hefty portion of bread that's pillowy enough to cuddle with. The mushroom and pizza are both confirmed delicious, and I'm excited to explore the other flavors.
author: Sarah Z.

description:
Long-time Italian family business in North Beach baking one thing: focaccia (10 types ~$5.50 each). Also sell frozen focaccia and bugia cookies (ok, baking more than *one* thing). Closed when sold out. Take out only. Cash only.

Their focaccia is pillowy soft, but even better toasted (warm, crisped crust). Occasionally too salty. Sometimes add cheese on pizza focaccia or make sandwiches with salt focaccia. Mushroom's my favorite and a crowd pleaser. Raisin is sweet with crispy glazed crust--all others are savory.

Request "cut" to enjoy right away (at Washington Square park). Request "wrapped" to eat later or gift in classic white square package wrapped with butcher paper and string.
author: K O.

description:
It's not the best focaccia I've ever had, but I get its appeal.  The dough is very pillowy and salted well, and the tomato sauce (we got the pizza one) gives it that right balance of tart.  

I wouldn't queue up for this, but it was fun to eat.
author: Lan N.

description:
Liguria bakery.  A true Italian mom n pops focaccia shop.  No other focaccia can ever steal my heart.  

They have been around years before my time... Before Microsoft Windows, before Napster, before MySpace, before Facebook, before YouTube, before yelp, before IG, before SnapChat, before any social media even existed, affording "foodies" to hype up a raw baby carrot and a single split pea on a luxurious plate made of white gold eaten with a silver knife and fork at a pretentious restaurant to be the OMG best foodgasm ever for an inflated amount of "likes" and bragging rights on how deep they were able to dig into their pockets for such euphoric dining pleasures (some tag their sponsors).  

Yes.  Perhaps I have some trust issues these days when it comes to social media's food recs.  Filters can make a bite look alluring like the photoshopped pic of your next tinder date you haven't met yet.  

I took my very first bite into their tomato focaccia when I was a little boy.  It was heaven.  For 8 2x5in. rectangular slices of heaven, it cost me one US dollar.  30 years later... It is still heaven... for 5 or 6 US dollars.  The same lady still hands me that brown paper bag.  With each bite of that tangy sweet fluffy tomato focaccia, childhood nostalgia warms every bit of my soul.  To this day, they still sell out early and close up shop once they do.  The lines are long on the weekends and they operate the same way they always had.  The utterly familiar sound of the large roll or white wax paper cut n slid onto that counter top... The gentle crumple as she wraps my bread snugly like a bundle of joy right before she slips it into that little brown paper bag... Always brings out the excited little kid in me without fail.  For that, my heart belongs to Liguria... Always.  

Go get it before they decide to close up shop for good. 

 As we pray for Amatrice, Italy, it triggered my memories of my very first experiences of Italian culture as a first generation Chinese kid growing up in San Francisco's own Italy, the North Beach.
author: Colin M.

description:
As a native San Franciscan, Liguria focaccia has always been a part of me. I am finally writing about them but mot to make them more popular, but because it is one of those rare places that needs to be discovered through a local contact, not online reviews, not even Yelp.  If you want that, go stand in line across the street at the tourist trap, Mama's.

My grandfather, a Chinese butcher, used to barter with Ambrosio.  Years later my grandfather introduced me to the pleasures of Liguria and I got a tour of their business and learned to appreciate the similarities of Italian and Chinese cultures.  As an Americanized kid, I would sneak down the hill from Chinatown to Liguria when I couldn't fathom eating my grandmother's authentic Chinese cooking of salty fish or thousand year old egg.

Their focaccia has gotten me through cross country road trips, camping trips, pot luck dinners, romantic picnics in Napa, and now most often these days those long cross country flights with overpriced box meals.

My gal recently suggested that we get some for our cross country flight and we grabbed a couple pizza and a couple jalapeno cheese cut up and bagged.  $5 each and so good.  Everyone on the flight was so jealous.   My son was going to sell a slice for a $1!  Nobody likes a five hour flight to visit their in-laws, but the focaccia made it tolerable.  haha.

The place usually closes down for the month of August for family trips to Europe or a Giants road trip so it is nice to stock up.  It is made to sit well in the freezer.  Just thaw it out gently when ready.  I like it fresh from the bakery but it also works well slightly toasted.

For those who complain about the service or lack of friendliness, remember that this is a neighborhood family business that was built on serving the local community.  This community has supported them over the years.  They never intended to become famous.  They supply a basic product to those Italian families and SF restaurants.

The line never gets long because they do one thing and one thing only very well. They don't have idle chit chat and give time or directions.  They have to move the line.  Even after all these years I speak to Mary quickly about the Giants and move on. 

So like many great old traditions in SF, just keep it on the down low. So many things in San Francisco have been ruined by changes in society.  North Beach is full of young techies hanging out and drinking, but Liguria remains one of the old icons of North Beach that has transcended time.  Embrace it.  Savor  it.   Shhhhh!
author: Erik H.

description: What they call focaccia is disgustingly oily and rubbery (hard to achieve at the same time I know) and has nothing to do with any focaccia you could buy in Liguria. What they call onion focaccia, does not even look like the original version, and certainly does not taste like it. What they call pizza is a can of cheap tomato thrown on a focaccia. All in all, this business is an insult to their homeland.
author: Winter M.

description: Wow...If you've never tried the focaccia from Liguria Bakery you're doing yourself a disservice. It's by far the best focaccia in the bay area and arguably the best anywhere. Do your taste buds a huge favor and get a few sheets of focaccia from Liguria, I promise you, you will love it. If you get some and don't like it, give it to me...smile
author: Ang S.

description: Great focaccia bread. They've been there for 107 yrs +. Go early they run out. The old woman behind counter was rude (& she made my husband feel at home -as if it was his own mother in law )
author: Jo C.

description: They have the best and freshest focaccia! I was introduced by my coworker and it definitely hits the spot. I came in around 12:30 on a Thursday and was left with limited selection, but I picked up a flavor of each. $5.50 goes a long way here with a slab of focaccia! I'll definitely be back soon!
author: Stephanie Y.

description: Visited SF back in june. This place is heaven i tried almost all the varieties of focaccia and NONE of them disappointed. We went right when it opened so there was no line or wait at all! The prices were great too!  hands down the best focaccia I have ever had.
author: Jennifer O.

description:
I grew up on Green and Grant in the late 70s and early 80s. I remember stopping by Liguria on the way to school to pick up a bagful of pizza bread (8 pieces if I remember correctly). The warm, delicious, aromatic focaccia was something I will never forget. I highly recommend trying it at least once in your life. 

For best results, get them in the morning as they are coming out of the oven, and eat them right away ;)
author: Albert L.

description: Cash only but worth it! Things sell out so get there early! Onion, mushroom and garlic are my favorites!!!
author: Niaz N.

description: Say no more to this place, this is sooooooooo authentic and I am super picky when it comes to bread, no where in SF I can actually spend money on bread. But, this place!!!!!
author: Julia L.

description: Came early right when it opened on a Saturday.  Same two women that everyone mentions--not overly friendly and kind of rushy  Focaccia is good but wasn't pleased to see that the lady answered the phone, packed the focaccia (no GLOVES either) and handled the money.  This was with each sale with no hand washing in sight! I cringed but stayed and purchased anyway.  Hope we don't get sick!
author: Alias A.

description:
My family and I believe that this is hands down the best focaccia shop in SF! We've been multiple times and have always (until a couple days ago) had a good experience.  

For my mom's birthday, she wanted to walk around North Beach and check out all the street musicians at the Wharf. We were very excited when we realized that Liguria was right on the way! Being that it was her birthday, my dad and I were happy to get her whatever she wanted. Unfortunately we showed up around 12:30 or so, about 30 minutes prior to them closing. My mom was happy to purchase some frozen focaccia from their freezer. The moment that she opened the freezer to grab it, an unpleasant, abrupt woman basically shouted at her asking why she was grabbing it when she had no idea what she had in her hands. My mom was a bit taken aback, noting that she was happy with any of the focaccia they sell. This woman again abruptly and rudely let us know that they were sold out of everything but one type. My mom said she didn't mind, she was happy to purchase whatever they had. 

I was frustrated with how this woman spoke to my mother, a customer, first of all, but it was her birthday! I mentioned to the woman that she must really want business today, given her customer service skills. We walked out deflated and disappointed. How dare this awful woman speak to my mother that way! She was lucky that I held my tongue because it was a special day, but honestly I was fuming. We will never again return if that woman is there, she is the worst of the worst.
author: Alexis G.

description:
Over 100 years old, so authentic, and so perfect. I've come here both before and after studying abroad in Italy and can say without question that the focaccia here tastes just as good as what you can find in the Liguria region of Italy.

What I love about this place is that it's always the same two women working at the counter. It's truly a family shop. People may whine about their perceived lack of friendliness, but I think that adds to the character of the place. I don't want some random bubbly teenager serving me my focaccia and spending forever answering the stupid questions and requests from SF yuppies. (Sorry!)

My favorite flavors are the pizza and rosemary garlic. They're very different, but of course same at the root of it all. Once they neatly wrap and tie it up in butcher paper and string, I head straight to Washington Square Park and tear apart their beautiful handiwork to dig in. I just can't help it. I'd love a lesson in how to re-tie the string. But I know not to ask!

This is definitely a place you have to plan for. You have to go pretty early, and that's just the way it is. If you don't like that, then don't come here. A tip though, in case you sadly make it here just a bit too late: Lucca Delicatessan on Chestnut in the Marina sells their focaccia as well, and you can usually get it a bit later in the day. Better to start at Liguria Bakery itself, but if you need to get your focaccia fix, you do have a second chance!
author: Dylan C.

description: For only $5.50 you can experience really good focaccia bread. It was fresh and tasty. Customer service not great but the bread is good.
author: Kim W.

description: $5 cash only for a generous portion of focaccia bread. You can get it cut up into strips bagged, or wrapped up packaged in string as a whole. This is a family business, take out only (didn't see any tables). The menu is short and simple. I tried and recommend the garlic, tomato, and mushroom flavors. Too bad I couldn't try them all:( Overall a  quick and efficient place.
author: Corinna T.

description:
This is the only place where we would get our focaccia. 

My husband who at the time was my boyfriend used to bring some home after a swim... It was the first time I've ever had focaccia and it was soooooo delicious. He always brought the pizza focaccia home and I loved the slightly crispy bottom and the tomato sauce slathered on top with green onions. Oh man, it was so good. I was addicted. 

We broke up and I never had focaccia again (lol)... 5 years later we got back together and got married and realized that this truly is one of our spots considering we never got focaccia with anyone else. I still love their focaccia here and I know people complain about the customer service which is silly considering this place has been around forever and they make the best focaccia in the Bay Area. 

I only give Liguria 4 stars because recently, I noticed a couple times that it tasted more salty and the bread was more soft and soggy as oppose to having that slight crisp I like so much. However, I still think their focaccia is delish.
author: Reese E.

description: My family has been coming here for over 30 years. Hands down the best focaccia bread I've ever had! I've had the pizza, plain, garlic. All amazing! I always take a sheet home for later and have them slice up some to eat on the spot. Cash only!
author: Michaela M.

description: They make the best tomato sauce and mushroom focaccia. The place is unpretentious and focuses only on selling top quality focaccia at the best price.
author: Ash M.

description: Delicious! Had to stop by and grab some bread before heading home. Good, fresh, homemade Italian bread. I can make it myself of course, but this stuff is as good as I remember my Nonnas being. I got one plain and 2 pizza ones. Would definitely come back if we are in the city.
author: Christine G.

description: My husband discovered the quaint Liguria Bakery when we lived in San Francisco in the late 1980s. We loved stopping by on a Saturday morning, buying a few slices of plain, onion, pizza or raisin focaccia and heading across the street to the park to enjoy our breakfast/lunch/brunch/snack. We were SO happy to return here this month while visiting SF to discover that NOTHING HAD CHANGED! Well, the price had gone up a little, but it's still such a great deal. Also, the neighborhood has really changed. North Beach is barely an Italian neighborhood anymore, which is so sad. But at least Liguria has survived! Believe the people who say that they run out by 11 a.m. on Saturday. And bring cash. Everyone visiting SF should stop here. Or, rather, they shouldn't - so there's more left for me when I visit!
author: Cynthia H.

description: I am a huge fan of Liguria Bakery's heavenly focaccia. It comes in a large slabs wrapped in parchment. Great for sharing. I love the one with olives or mushrooms. The rosemary is okay too on the side of soup, salad, pasta, etc. But my absolute favorite is the pizza. The tangy tomato sauce and generous scallions -- It's perfect!! I can think of few other breads I'd rather have in this world.
author: Jennifer W.

description:
Some of the best foccacia bread I've had in my life.

As a kid, my mom would always swing by Liguria Bakery after school and pick us up a thick slab (or two) of their fantastic pizza foccacia. It's certainly not an item for the faint of heart (or those watching their figures) - it's just a massive slice of doughy goodness, covered in their tangy tomato sauce, and studded with scallions.

I've been meaning to wake up early one morning and drop by with the boy-o (the lines can be fierce), but haven't made it yet. Soon, though!
author: Claire S.

description: Eek. For somewhere as renowned as Liguria, I was seriously expecting something better for arriving promptly at 8am. You would think that the foccacia was piping fresh out of the oven! I think, however, the foccocia was from the day before as it was kind of cold and soggy. Not worth the $5.50.
author: Cindy W.

description:
Molto bene . The only words I know in italian,  need I say more...
 
Now let's enjoy our feast.
author: Michael T.

description:
I came here on a Wednesday morning around 9. Usually, they sell out before they close I knew I had to come early. 

I bought the jalapeño one and the plain. It was really good and I always love to come here.
author: Lydia H.

description:
garlic, jalapeno cheese, raisin  - my top 3 favorites.
Order cut up or whole.  Separate bags or together.
No non-sense place.  

Cash only.
author: Margaret W.

description: This is the best place to go for those that love pizza. Everything is great. Just by typing this make me want to get some but they are close on Sundays.
author: Anthony Z.

description: Life changing focaccia. No exaggeration. Their pizza focaccia in particular is exquisite.
author: Mansi D.

description: this place has it's ups and downs it was really good before and then it wasn't .it was kind of tangy the pizza bread  !!! but last week my husband bought a sheet and it was good again . SO LIGURIA BAKERY don't  over do it on the vinegar/tangy sauce and we'll always come back !!!
author: Nellie J.

description: The best focaccia I've ever had in my life. Honestly, I don't want to move apartments because Liguria Bakery is right across the street and now that I've had it in my life, I can never go back! The only thing better than homemade, freshly baked focaccia (pesto and garlic & rosemary are my recommendations) is having it served to you by a grumpy old Italian lady  (she's not that grumpy, she's actually v sweet)
author: L G.

description:
The bakery doesn't look like much from the outside and on the inside the shelves are empty, with a few newspaper clippings and a San Francisco Giants banner on the wall. It's in the back where the taste treats are found. Each loaf is wrapped in string and butcher paper like a present and is reasonably priced at $4.00 to $5.00 per loaf. Be sure to arrive early as there will be lines and different flavors run out. My personal favorite is raisin, but I've had the plain and rosemary breads as well. 

Unfortunately, there are no seats inside the bakery but just outside is Washington Square where you can sit on a bench and enjoy watching tai chi from different groups from Chinatown. You may have to also fight off a few greedy pigeons in the park who are eagerly eyeing your bread.

Be sure to also bring your own drinks or coffee as Liguria just sells focaccia bread. Every time I've visited the staff is the same and the quality of the bread remains as good as previous visits. 

San Francisco is not a cheap city and eating out can be expensive. For a reasonably priced breakfast, Liguria Bakery is a find. The focaccia is filling and delicious and a large loaf won't last past breakfast. I've tried to carry a loaf in my backpack for a snack later but the bread never lasts long. 

For a taste of the "real Italy" in San Francisco, Liguria Bakery is the place.
author: Steve N.

description:
Is there anything better than fresh focaccia? On the corner of Stockton and Filbert street, this family-owned operation makes the most delicious, chewy, and soft focaccia that melts in your mouth. Their dough has no preservatives and is mixed in an antique machine, which is then baked in a large brick oven that you can see behind the counter when you order. You can buy them in an 8-by-10 inch sheet, wrapped in plain white paper and tied up with a string, or ask them to slice it for you into bite-size pieces so you can eat it before you're even out the door. 

I tried the mushroom, pizza, onion, and rosemary garlic. I must say, my absolute favorite was the pizza. The tomato sauce had the perfect amount of tanginess and sweetness, and the scallions sprinkled on top gave it a great texture. But you can't go wrong with any of the options. I love places that only specialize in one thing.

They close for the day when they run out of stuff to sell so get here in the morning. This place is also cash only!
author: Hana K.

description:
The product is amazing, there is no doubt about that.

However, the customer service is horrendous.  One of my friends tragically lost her husband a few weeks back.  For his upcoming services / reception, the plan was to serve the focaccia - one of his favorites.

Needless to say, Liguria wrote down the wrong day (earlier, not later) and verbally harassed the widow for not being there to "pick up the bread."  She offered to pay today and pay AGAIN on the correct date.  They refused, chastised her and made a simple situation much much worse.

Liguria will keep plugging along and do great business.  There was no hardship on them as they would have sold out what they made (and they were offered payment by my friend).

Sometimes, people just need to remember that no matter how popular you are and how much people enjoy your business, every customer is important and every interaction can result in a customer for life or losing business from the way you treat people.

Shame on you Liguria - you lost more than just a single sale - you lost a few customers as well as some respect.
author: Kurt L.

description: Wonderful. Just perfect focaccia.  Also, I think very good value considering its San Francisco.  Some might find it too salty, but it's authentic and amazing just how it is.
author: Nick T.

description:
I can't believe I've never written a review for this place.   Located in the heart of North Beach across from Washington Square.  My daughter and I were meeting someone this morning at Washington Square.  Somewhere down Geary Blvd heading downtown it occurred to me that Liguria Bakery is by the Square.   And it was opened today.

Found a great parking space at 8:45am.  Walked into the bakery.  They only sell focaccia but it's called a bakery.  All types.  My faves are the green onion, raisin, and pizza ones.   There's like ten varieties.

They'll wrap the sheets up in butcher paper for you and tie it up with string.  If you want to eat now, you need to tell them to cut the sheet up.   Then they'll put the strips in a paper bag for you with a stack of paper napkins.  Take your brown paper bag full of cut up focaccia and go over to the park.  Find a bench.  Snack down and watch the seniors doing their tai chi.  It doesn't get better than this.  Definitely a San Francisco experience. 

The entire place is very old school.   They always run out of focaccia way before end of their business day.

Cash only.
author: Shirley N.

description: I  love the raisin focaccia, but it's very scary because you can easily finish 4 bars and can still keep going.
author: Es L.

description: When I was attending Salesians Boys & Girls Club (at St. Peter & Paul Cathedral) my sister and I use to walk to this joint and it definitely doesn't look like much when you walk in. I've tried most of their focaccia and I gotta say it's pretty darn good -- probably the best I've had (but then again I didn't get focaccia when I was in Italy). My favorite is the garlic&rosemary and pizza. The rosemary isn't too powering which I liked as I know how strong that herb could be. They close when they sell out so don't focus too much on their closing times as it could easily close at 11am if they're all out.
author: Yvonne L.

description: Love their focaccia bread. Have tried rosemary garlic, jalapeño cheese and pizza bread. You can't go wrong with any bread but my favorite was jalapeño cheese. I only wish they were open till late as I never seem to make it to SF early morning. :)
author: Priya A.

description: BEST focaccia I've ever had.  Love the variety of flavors and simplicity of this place.  Definitely 'no frills' service, but I didn't mind it.  They do one thing and do it right every time!  Perfect to have them cut a piece up for you to eat right away.  Also awesome to grab whole and add to your own homemade Italian dinner!
author: Katie M.

description:
Not much to say. They do one thing, and they do it great.

Pizza focaccias are the most popular but I love the olives. My favorite place to stop by on a weekend morning before I grab my orange juice from Union Street Produce.
author: Gokhan T.

description: This place is heaven! I am not a big fan of bread but I ate a whole slab of this by myself then went back and bought more for my family. The rosemary garlic is my jam!
author: Ritza A.

description: Love this place.  Old school.  Yummy focaccia.  Bring cash.  Great appetizer to share while you are in the long line across the street waiting for breakfast.
author: Luv T.

description: Greatest focaccia outside of Italy.  They've been running this family business since my great-grandmother arrived from Italy.  My family has been customers for generations and we will continue to be as long as they keep on baking!
author: A B.

description:
Cash Only.

Takeout Only.

Best 5 Dollars spent ever. 

The Focaccia is very light fluffy and perfect for a dinner party app. or when you want a serious upgrade to your lunchtime pizza slice. My fav was the Jalapeno and Cheese but I'm Texan so what would you expect...

Grazie!!
author: R J.

description:
this is for the fact that I just tried to call ahead and order some, but the person who answered said she wasn't taking anymore orders very adruptly. And to just come on in. which I would, but I don't live in the city, and won't be there til later. which means it will all be gone. 
and I tried them once and liked it, but now I think the shine has worn off.
author: Xiao C.

description: Best Focaccia ever! The owner can be a bit grumpy but that adds to the charm. I have been coming here for 20 plus years whenever I make it up to the Bay Area. Their Focaccia is magical. Especially like the Jalapeno and cheese, pizza, garlic and raisin versions.
author: Carlos G.

description: Before going to my Cousin's Baptism at Saints Peter & Paul Church... I had to make a quick stop to my most favorite place to buy myself some Focaccia Bread at Liguria Bakery!!! Back in my middle school and high school days Liguria Bakery was my most favorite place of all time just to have myself some Focaccia Bread!!! And still today Liguria Bakery has been here for ages!!! And I still continue on to buy my favorite Focaccia Bread which is the Tomato and Onion Bread!!!
author: William B.

description:
The best focaccia in SF?  Most def.  It's debatably the best on the west coast.  No joke.  I worked across the street from Liguria for several years, so here's what's up...

Old school.  Focaccia is all they do.
Mom & pop biz forever.

The smell alone when you walk in is worth walking in for.  I've actually done this.

They close their doors for the day whenever they sell out.  Read: go early.

If you find service to be less than warm & friendly, it is just their way & is not personal.  Don't be so sensitive!  You remember the soup nazi of NYC?  Well, Liguria is the focaccia nazi of SF.  But not quite as intense.

They close every August for an entire month for vacation.  The Italian way.  I told you; old school.

They crush it here, so it doesn't matter what kind you order.  The onion is my favorite.  The garlic is effin amazing slathered w brie.  A perfect marriage.  You can just walk on over to Molinari's a couple blocks down for brie.  Or, if you'd rather Safeway it, that's a few blocks down in the opposite direction.  What have you, just get brie.  You'll thank me.  Everyone loves the pizza, but it's not my favorite.  Really, onion effin rocks; especially for sandwiches.

If you don't want savory, then the raisin w your morning tea or coffee is the way to go.

They supply various businesses; including some famous ones.

People drive here from other cities for this focaccia.  A lot of people.

Worth reiterating...really, the aroma when you walk in is off the friggin charts.  Dreamy.

The easiest 5 stars to give.
Mangia.
author: Veronica M.

description: Don't go to Liguria looking for great customer service, but do go for their famous and addicting focaccia bread.  My favorites are the plain, jalapeño and mushroom.  Go early before they run out!They close at 1 or 2pm.
author: Mike A.

description: Love this place.. I grew up a block away..been here for a long time..best best focaccia bread in town..friends from out of town would buy a lot n freeze it..my fav is the pizza one... Lots of sauce with onions. but do come early to buy.. Or once it's runs out they close ..!!
author: Crisy G.

description:
The best way I can describe the two women who run the front is like this:  When you idolize a famous person or pro ball player as a kid and they are your hero.  Then you ask them for an autograph and they look at you with disrespect and insensitivity and tell you, "NO. Get out of here, kid."  I grew up enjoying their foccacia bread at family functions holidays and even walking in and surprising my family when I was in the city for the day.  Liguria was part of our family traditions.....until recently.

My husband died suddenly on April 29th at the young age of 45.  I knew there would be over 500 friends and family at his memorial service so in addition to a catered function I wanted to order his favorite, pizza foccacia from Liguria.  When I called to place the order the women was already hesitant to take it over the phone since they only take cash.  I told her I'd pick it up on the Saturday before the memorial service (the service was on Sunday) - gave her the specific dates, and off we went.  I get a call the week before from one of the women who was irritated asking when I was coming in to pick up my order.  I told her there was a mistake it was the following weekend - I felt so bad (for her mistake) that I even offered to pay for the order she had that day in addition to the next week's order.  She was rude, crass and just plain heartless on the phone to me.  I had to give the phone to my friend to try to reason with her and she wanted no part of it.  So there I was.  Not able to serve my late husband's favorite foccacia at his memorial service (to over 500 Bay Area local residents who will also never set foot again in your place).   You can have your oily bread.  And your miserable attitudes.  I am so sad that you didn't find it in your heart to support someone who recently lost their husband.
author: Hillary B.

description:
Mama and papa shop that sells the best foccacia bread in the city!!!  

They have stayed true to consistency on quality over the years! 

That fresh, soft bread is smothered with their special, tasty tomato sauce and topped with diced up crunchy green onions.  Everything about the Pizza Foccacia is so savory!  AND YOU GET A GOOD PORTION FOR JUST 5 BUCKS!

They have other toppings: Plain, Onion, Raisin, Garlic, Rosemary, Mushroom, Black Olive, Rosemary Garlic, and Jalapenos Cheese, BUT PIZZA FOCCACIA WINS MY HEART!

Their service may be slow, a bit standoffish, and they have no dining tables or seats, but this place is old-fashioned and one of those bakeries where you take your orders to go and eat elsewhere!
author: Tiffany D.

description:
I stepped in on a Saturday morning and got the mushroom focaccia. It's absolutely delicious! I need to come back and try the other flavors. I'm not even typically the type of person who buys loaves of bread, and in general I try to avoid a lot of carbs.. lol but man, I don't think I'll be able to resist this magical focaccia.  

I definitely like the family owned kind of feel to the place. An elderly lady took my order and I just had the feeling she had been doing this, making focaccia and serving it to the community, for much longer than I've been born! I'll be back. :]
author: Monica B.

description: A San Francisco favorite every time! Can't come into the city without a stop here. From the brass to the sass this place has it all. A bit of nostalgia to the best tasting foccaccia bread. All at a very reasonable price. Yes CASH only but the bread is so worth it. Just be ready with your order cause the owners do not like to wait on indecisive people.
author: S N.

description:
Liguria Bakery Foccacia bread is SO GOOD! My favorite is the Jalapeno Cheese but they are all honestly delicious. Even RASIN which I thought was strange is really good.

I kind of want to take a star off for their service. They are super old school and kind of rude but as long as you don't come around the holidays, there isn't much of a wait and all the flavors are available.

For those that don't live around the area or don't make it out to north beach often, you can totally buy in bulk and freeze them. Surprisingly, it tastes equally good after you defrost and toast it!
author: Clarice C.

description:
When I saw the word "CLOSED" I almost panicked. And I live in the midwest. This place... It's like walking into a time portal to the past. Not that I love a lot about the past, but this place has all the good stuff. Salt of the Earth people behind the counter. Food wrapped in white paper and tied up with string. And the food inside is simply delicious.

We took our focaccia to the park across the street, tore pieces off and ate them while watching all of the tai chi going on.
author: L. N.

description: I'm still loving their pizza!!! I need to try other focaccia!! Lines can be long but it's still worth every minute and every penny!
author: Lily M.

description:
Cash only
Service isn't very welcoming but they're very efficient.
There's just something about the way they make their foccaccia. I haven't found a single place comparable.
Pizza and Green Onion are my favs.
You have the option to take it whole or cut up.

They do close when they sell out, which makes the hours unpredictable and parking sucks. So minus one star for those reasons
author: Denise L.

description:
I've heard about this place since high school, and I've just now paid a visit here. The focaccia bread here is amazing. It's a generous portion for $5. They even cut it up for you upon your request. I ordered a jalapeño cheese and garlic focaccia. I'm leaning more towards the jalapeño cheese! It's so good. The service here is quick. I'm not entirely sure about the cleanliness though. One of the employees went to the back to grab my focaccia and I saw her take it off the shelf with bare hands and proceeded to cut it. She came back, and took my money. Whether or not she washed her hands after cash handling, I think she should've worn gloves.  

PS. Read another review claiming there was a mouse running around.
author: Jeanne C.

description:
Living in North Beach is an amazing thing. If you're lucky enough to find a rent-controlled pad, you have full access to late-night pizza, the only In-N-Out, short commutes to FiDi, etc. It's so amazing that your friend from out of town always insist on crashing your couch (now air mattress).

So when they ask me where to to go, where do I send them?

Chinatown for Dim Sum and Egg Tarts? Nope
Tony's Pizza for one of the best slices in the city? Not initially
Into that ridiculous line outside Mama's? Absolutely not

I always recommend Liguria...they have an honest no-BS charm that truly represents the heart of small SF businesses. Aside from their character, they have the best focaccia bread you will ever taste in the most abundant and savory of flavors. My advice would be to show up early in the morning with cash (no CC), know exactly which flavors/how much you want with backup options since they typically run out, tell them if you'd like it cut into smaller pieces, and go sign up for a marathon...consider yourself carbo-loaded for the week.

LPT: Closed on Sundays, so wake up early any other day. :)
author: Nick W.

description:
Now that they have changed the recipe - Liguria's focaccia tastes as bad as  prepackage stuff found in grocery stores.  They no longer use olive oil. 
No need to drive across town and stand in long lines over holidays since the new recipe tastes like cardboard crap
Bonus: no longer have to tolerate team beeoch on beautiful mornings!!!  Mrs and Ms I look like I am smelling fresh poop will not be missed by me.   I have handed over my last $20 and I am so glad to be done with mean ladies and now crap focaccia.
Hope to see more discover and discuss the crap they are producing and where we all be be going from now on?!?!?!    Pick NICE people who are Friendly to Every customer and for the love of god - put on nice clothes, wash hair and Smile
author: Donna M.

description:
Parking:  It's North Beach so unless you have good parking karma, have someone drop you off to pick it up or expect to spend a good half an hour looking for parking.  

Food:  Been coming here for over 10 years when it was just plain, onion, and tomato.  Over the years, they have added garlic, rosemary, olive, mushroom, etc..  My faves are the tomato and the mushroom as it's delicious the day of and as leftovers.  The tomato can be eaten at room temp while I like the others toasted if I'm not eating it the day I buy it.  

Service:  It is a hit or miss depending on their mood and who waits on you.  

Note:  If you want at least 4 sheets, call in your order the day before so they can put it aside for you to pickup.  Otherwise, you would need to get there early as they close once they run out which is early.  You might want to order one cut up so you can munch on it as soon as you get it.
author: Joyce Z.

description:
Cold pizza may be fine for some. But I kinda hate cold pizza. Fresh but cold. Cold tomato sauce was almost jarring.
Service was a little cold too.
author: Augusto M.

description: Been going here for years for their raisin focaccia bread (I'm not even a big fan of raisin) 5 dollars for a big square which cuts into about 8 pieces. It's delicious especially when fresh! They sell out around 12 pm so come early!
author: lisa n.

description:
Liguria's focaccia is the most delicous I've ever had.  Parking can be a bit tricky, the space is pretty basic, and you probably won't get a smile when you enter, but it's SOOOOO good.  I mean....I'm not trying to be your friend anyway so just give me the goods and I'll be outta your way.  You know what I mean?  

Try and go early because they sell out pretty quickly.  You don't want to leave sad do you?  I speak from experience.  By early I mean before 10am if you're going on a Saturday.  At least then you have a chance.  Their location is right across Mama's where you'll probably see a ridiculous line rain or shine.  Their focaccia prices range from $4 to $5.  Cash only!  My favorite is the pizza, but I've tried the other toppings as well and they are all really good.  I definitely recommend this place!
author: Christine D.

description:
This place has been a staple in the area for a long time. They have short hours, and apparently sell out quickly. This is a great place to pick up fresh and delicious focaccia, especially great if you find yourself waiting in the lines at Mama's and feel like you're gonna pass out from hunger. 

Rosemary garlic and raisin for absolutely delicious. I need to come back and try the pizza bread. 

Cash only.
author: Long C.

description:
LOVE LOVE LOVE LOVE LOVE this place! I could really eat this all day every day! You have to remember it's Cash only. But $5 could go a long ways here! I always get eye hungry when i come and I order a lot. But you can't go wrong here! 
$5 each 
$3 frozen focaccia.
author: Irma R.

description:
The pizza focaccia bread is DELICIOUS.  I usually can't stop thinking about it for days after I have it .. if it weren't for the 2k calories your $5 buys you, this would be a weekly visit for sure.

The craziest thing is that you see a mile long line outside of mama's across the street and NO ONE in this bakery.  Almost feels like a hidden gem.

Customer service isn't super apparent here, but their product is LEGIT and they just dont give a shizzz..don't expect a hello or greeting upon entering, she'll ask you what you want when shes ready.
author: Melody T.

description:
