Best focaccia in the city! I love this place cause it's all about great focaccia and that's all! The bakery comes with the old grandpa and grandma shop style customer service, some people might categories it as "rude" but i think that's what I call the old neighborhood shop charm! 

Try their focaccia and chat with the people who work in the shop ... I promise you that you will fall in love with it too!
author: Eric W.

description: Oh the joy of having fresh focaccia at Liguria in the morning!  I love this place - lots of focaccia is "bready" or dry, but they make this chewy wonderful focaccia that's so addictive. The only draw back is that they're closed on Sunday's and Monday's and close early.
author: A C.

description:
I love food. So when the hubby and I planned a trip to SF I signed us up for a food safari (walking tour) of   North Beach. The tour was super duper cheap so I didn't expect too much...I was soooo wrong! This was one of the many delicious eateries that we were introduced to. We would have never ever tried this little gem if it weren't for the tour. 

This small family run bakery specializes in different varieties of focaccia. I have never been a fan of focaccia because the times I have tried it I found it too hard and flavorless. That was until I found this  amazing bakery. As soon as you walk in the door the beautiful aromas entice your palate. I have never been a fan of the herb, rosemary. I decided that it was time to try focaccia and rosemary again...at the same time. We ordered one (loaf) rosemary & garlic focaccia. I cautiously tried a bite, almost expecting to dislike it, but instantly I was converted. It was so good that I ate a good majority of the whole thing!

 I should have brought some home to my carb loving children...I undoubtedly would have become their favorite parent. 

They only accept cash and we were told they sell out before the posted closing hours. So don't wait stop here before you walk up to Coit Tower, then enjoy it at Washington Square while people and dog watching.
author: Michelle G.

description: This place has the best focaccia bread in the city. I have been coming here since I was a kid. The place still looks the same as it did many years ago. The prices have increased, but I do not mind paying for a piece of nostalgia.
author: Charles B.

description:
Liguria is the only place I purchase focaccia. It is wonderful!  Get here early as they usually run out before closing at 1:00 pm.

The onion is my favorite. I love it toasted with eggs and a glass of wine for dinner.
author: Donna P.

description: Try the pizza focaccia!! We knew this spot was gunna be dangerous when several food tours by foot stopped in for a loaf.
author: Bree L.

description: The best focaccia outside of Liguria, Italy. I travel tô Liguria frequently and can attest to that. You will buy it and start eating right away, it's so good!
author: Elizabeth K.

description:
OMGGG, this place is sooo good!!!

Personally, I prefer the pizza one out of all the flavors!

Wake up early so they don't sell out or close! Meaning you gotta come before noon!
author: Kelly L.

description: Best focaccia ever. This is part of my childhood and a must have for everyone at least once in their lives. And regularly if your lucky!!!
author: Itali C.

description: The best Focaccia in all of San Francisco. They are cash only but that doesn't deter customers. The line always wraps around the block. I love the pizza focaccia. It isn't like a typical pizza with pepperoni and cheese though. The focaccia is covered in a delicious tomato sauce and green onions. Every single one that I have tried there I have loved. They are authentic Italians and don't put up with any BS. I have been going here for 10+ years and will continue to do so
author: Brianna M.

description: Been coming to this family owned business since I could remember. Best focaccia bread out there, hands down!!
author: Jasmine B.

description: They close really early so make sure to go really really early. If you get in close to 1p, it's usually just the onion left. No frill quick counter service, just get in, order, get out and enjoy!
author: Angela L.

description:
To be honest, we came by because Mama's across the street had that ridiculous 50-ppl-long line as usual. Good for us that we did.

Alright alright, that is DAMN GOOD FOCACCIA. They'd sold out of our top 2 choices (rosemary garlic, jalapeno cheese) by the time we came at 10 or 11, but we got some mushroom which padded our stomachs for a walk along the embarcadero.

Do they warm/toast them up for you? Because that would be nice.
author: Vivian H.

description: Pizza bread is gooood.  If traveling, get some and store in the car then keep eating on the way.  Get there fast as things get sold out before the posted business close hour.
author: Seattle Y.

description: I need to remind myself to get only the garlic ($5). I can just inhale it.  The pizza was too salty.  Love the lady!  Love this bakery!
author: Helen L.

description: I've been meaning to go for years, but when a store runs out of product by noon each day, it's hard to find a good time to go. Finally today I picked up the pizza and raisin focaccia based on reviews. The pizza was amazing - tangy tomato sauce and delicious bread. The raisin was good too but not as soft. By noon, only pizza was left and was running out fast. Go now. I can't believe I waited this long to discover this deliciousness.
author: B. Y.

description:
Mice. 

Yes, I saw a mouse scurrying around inside. I had been waiting so long when I saw the mouse that I contemplated staying in line and ordering anyway... but then I realized the line was still moving much too slow and the mouse had me thinking all kinds of unfavorable things. As such, I never ate here. I really hope they get things sorted out because everyone raves about the focaccia.
author: Amy L.

description: I'm not sure if it is proper to classify the Liguria Bakery "pizza focaccia" as pizza, but if it is, it is in my top five favorite pizzas of all time.  The tangy/sweet sauce is perfect, and the oily crust melts in your mouth.  It is best eaten right away, as the sauce will eventually leave you with a soggy focaccia (fyi: It is still pretty dang tasty when soggy).  I've tried a few other flavors, but none can compare to the "pizza".
author: Jocelyn A.

description:
My dad grew up in North Beach and came here for foccacia.Even after moving out of SF, when I visited the city as a kid he took me here. I have tried every flavor except for pizza (if I wanted square shaped pizza, I'd walk down the block to Golden Boy). Every time I go there the raisin always calls to me. And when raisin is sold out, I like rosemary/garlic as a close second. 

Warning: this place closes when bread is sold out so come early. I came last week Monday at 11 AM thinking "hey everyone is at work, who's going to buy any now?". And I was proved wrong...they were closed!
author: Melissa N.

description:
OMG -- Delish! Word's can't fully describe how delicious this place is! Definiately on the list of "Forever Favorites"  Long lines, but with good reason.  They sell fast so, very common to sell out, so get there early!


*Jalepeno Cheddar-- WOWZERS... soooooooooooo good. 'nuff said.

*Pizza - Surprizingly up there.  I'm not much of a fan of red sauce on anything... buy WOW, there is something about it that I can't have enough of.

CON -- worst place to go if you are on a diet.... Shhhhh....will not log this onto MyFitnessPal (lol)
author: Mimi G.

description:
Way way way back when I was knee high to my Nana's apron, I can remember my grandfather bringing home this weird bread from time to time. It wasn't our usual sourdough loaf, and was nothing like the sliced bread in the drawer. It was this flat bread called Fugasa. (or Foccacia) An Italian flat bread that has a ragu of some sort, covered in green onions and baked to perfection. It was square pizza without the toppings. It had a light and airy texture with a salty kick. And I loved every square inch of it. It came gift wrapped in butcher paper with a little string around it, as if it were Christmas. Now as an adult, that first bite always takes me back to those days of fond memories that will be with me forever. 

This past week I found myself deep in the heart of San Francisco. I have been trying to get out to Liguria for awhile and finally found the time. I knew the rules before I got there. There is no room for amateurs, this is the big leagues. First rule...
Arrive early...go on a Weekday.....Cash only....check!......You walk in, state your order, pay, take product and leave. There is a slight element of the "Soup Nazi" syndrome in play at this bakery, but it doesn't bother me. The employee could slap me in the face and I would still say thank you. That's how good the bread is there. The crybabies who complain about the customer service need to grow a pair. Suck it up and be an adult.
author: Ben R.

description:
I think that a focaccia-only bakery is the second most 'San Francisco' restaurant idea I've come across. The first being, of course, artisanal toast.

That said, a store that sells focaccia and only focaccia, and only until they run out for the day, sounds like heaven to me.

Unfortunately, by the time I made it in, my choices were limited to pizza and garlic. While I would have killed to have tried the rosemary garlic, I settled on the olive.

Luckily for me, the olive was a m a z i n g. Everything I could ever want out of focaccia - and more.

Between Liguria and Alimento I don't think I'll need to leave North Beach upon my return to San Francisco.
author: Benjamín S.

description: The bread is to die for you!!! Thank you Liguria for making an extra delicious product!!! I personally love the pizza and chedder jalapeno but all are good!!
author: Tina S.

description:
Really tasty foccaccia but nothing that left me screaming for more. I developed a bit of a love-hate relationship with the rosemary garlic foccaccia, as I found it left a heavy, garlicky greasiness in my mouth....after I devoured half an entire slab. Still, this is great stuff to bring if you're on a picnic. Felt very European as we opened up our butcher paper in the sunlight.

The old lady who runs the place is quite...sour, shall we say? So don't go there expecting service. Nor cleanliness - they grab every oily slab with their marinara-stained hands and then use those same hands to touch the cash you've given them...ah, well. In a way this is part of the appeal Liguria: its no-frills, homemade quality.
author: Clarice W.

description: I didn't know focaccia could taste this good! The portions are huge, but it goes down so easily! $5 for a big piece. We ordered the "pizza", but there is no meat on it. Just tomato sauce and green onion. All I can say is wow.
author: Faith C.

description:
The focaccia here is just delish and I love that there are so many flavors! But go early and call ahead to see what their inventory is like because they sell out quickly! 

I was visiting from NYC and ended up buying 4 huge loaves to take home on the day of my returning flight and ended up eating it for a week! Bread is not usually my choice of carbs, but this calls for an exception!
author: Amy S.

description:
Good quality focaccia, but they do sell out fast and I was hoping that the onion focaccia would be more like they traditionally make it in Italy--oily, dense and with tons of white onions! This is a little more sparse with scallions.

Instead, I'd recommend their cheese and jalapeño focaccia. That hit the spot!
author: Dhwani T.

description:
Yum! Such a hole in the wall (guess not anymore?) place! Every time I come here, it feels beyond homey. I see all these people that come in early (like me because of work) and they bring their children and talk to the owner. It seems like a very community oriented place.

Now, on to the bread. I LOVE their raisin focaccia!! It's buttery and sweet. Who doen't like butter and sweet?? Hah. I also love getting their pizza bread. I remember as a kid living in SF and my neighbor would get some and share some with us. Very found memories!

***TIP****
1.) Go early because I've heard (of course from ppl who's been here and  read on yelp) that once they sell out of focaccia, they close so go early for a for sure journey.

2.) cash only!! so make sure you gots cash to purchase these amazing focaccia! =)
author: Denise L.

description: I have always considered this place to be the place for the best focaccia. Every time an acquaintance comes by, brand new to the city, I point them here for the best focaccia. I used to go to the school right across from them and when my parents pick me up from school with a bag of that mouth watering bread, it was a good day regardless of what happened at school. I do not eat this all the time, but when I do, it puts a smile on my face.
author: Edward T.

description: Owner is not friendly at all, they really have no patience to answer any questions about their food. Focaccia is not bad, but a little too oily and cold.
author: 行凱

description: Want freshly baked focaccia in SF?  This is the place and that's all they make.  After their daily allotment is sold, they close for the day so be sure to get there early if there's something you desire.  Also, you may call ahead to place your order.  Yummy, yummy!  The mushroom focaccia is amazing!!!
author: J H.

description:
A few months ago at the farmers market, I overheard a couple raving about a place in North Beach that sells great focaccia. Glad I kept my ears open because it's delicious!

I woke up early and arrived right when they opened at 7 on Saturday morning. There was already a line of about a dozen people in and outside of this little bakery. It was an odd sight with empty shelves and two women working at the counter with butcher paper and string. Everyone was smiling and ordering in multiples. One guy ahead of me had more than twenty. 

The prices were amazing. At first I was confused, people were ordering these big sheets. The price list topped out at $5. I wanted a sheet, but didn't know how much it'd be. I figured the prices would be for small squares. I was so wrong; it was for the whole sheet!

I'll admit that I wanted one of each so I could find the one I liked best. With the slabs being so big, a rare exercise of self restraint was in order. I bought only two: rosemary-garlic and a mushroom. Both were incredible. The mushroom was sparsely decorated with yummy fungi. The rosemary-garlic had a wonderful pronounced garlic flavor that didn't overwhelm the rosemary. I would get them again, but I'd like to try more.

The two women behind me in line were old-time regulars exchanging memories of their past visits. Wonderful to hear the tales. They'll be back at 4am on Christmas Eve to stand in line that the owner expects to wrap around the block by 5. They don't open until 6.
author: Dave B.

description:
After several trips, I was finally able to make it before this placed closed. This was mainly for the morning people, opening at 9am and closing at 1pm. And sure enough there were the 3 people that everyone described; the older lady to the right, the man sitting in front of the register and the last lady sitting in front of the register on the left. 

So I got here minutes before closing and they had jalapeno and pizza style remaining. I decided to go with the jalapeno because I couldn't see the difference between pizza style and pizza except less sauce and everything else except for the money. After biting into my jalapeno cheese focaccia, it tasted like a piece of bread with cheese jalapeno. A bite on the spicy side but nothing special, except on the price.
author: M C.

description:
No service, no nonsense, no frills... (no soup for you! just kidding.)

I LOVE Liguria. The bread is fluffy, flavorful, savory (but not SALTY) and much more subtly oiled than the goods at the famed Arizmendi Bakery across town. I don't care that it took me 45 min to get here, fighting through hordes of Chinatown shoppers on the street and then took me another hour and half to get back to SoMa, I will do what it takes to get the focaccia bread. Got here on a Tuesday around 11:45 and their shelves were totally empty. My face must have dropped a couple floors, because the woman behind the counter immediately said "I got two left- onion and pizza. What do you want?" Without hesitating, I immediately said "Both!"

No regrets. No regrets even though I carried these soft pillowy food babies and smelled their heavenly scent (without opening it!!) all the way down to SoMa (1.5 hr), then 1/2 hr across town to UCSF and then 1/2 hour back to Caltrain station and then 1 hour down to San Jose. NO REGRETS.

So fantastic, I can only dream of my next visit.
author: Tiffany C.

description:
This bread has changed my life. : ) A co-worker brought some in for a meeting and my last meal has officially been changed from french fries to this stuff!!!

Mushroom- my favorite of the three flavors. It was the most tender, perfectly savory bread I have ever tasted and the mushrooms were PERFECT.

Pizza- My co-workers liked this the best. It was really good

Raisin  - This was my least favorite, the bread is a bit tougher. It was good if you like raisins

I am going back this weekend to try other flavors!!
author: Jazmyn W.

description: I am in line with about 10 other people at 4:30 in the morning to get the best focassia bread  for tonite's xmas party. This line in 1 hour will grow to about 100 plus people.  Well worth the wait.
author: George E.

description:
I agree with most of the reviews regarding the lackluster service. Being pleasant with people isn't painful and it's a part of having a business that offers goods and/or services to the public. Basic stuff. But a lot of businesses that have been around in a city forever don't have to care since they were selling what they're selling back before they invented caring.

There is plenty of good foccacia bread in North Beach, and this place undeniably makes some of the best, but you can find it elsewhere just as easily and just as good and those other places will be open past 11 AM, not be sold out before then, and won't be closed for a month while the whole staff takes a vacation.
author: M M.

description: I never had a chance to write a review for Liguria because I visited when I was in a frenzy trying to complete the 7x7 list.  I still remember the sunny North Beach day as I walked in and ordered the olive foccacia bread.  I love all things olive.  I was in and out of there so I can't really comment on the staff.  I took the foccacia bread home and it was literally gone in a few hours.  It was deliciously soft and the flavors were just so right and delicate.  If Liguria weren't so out of the way and if parking weren't so difficult to find around the area, I definitely would've made frequent trips here.
author: Vivian H.

description:
Hands down the best focaccia anywhere in California. 
They've been doing it for over 100. 

Be warned: parking sucks &cash only. Bring someone to drive around the block do you can get in line. We usually try to get there by 8:30. 
They usually sell out by 10 and what's left will be your least favorites. They close when sold out. 
You won't be able to get to the car before you rip the package. 

Our favs; pizza, olive, mushroom. 
Buy for your freezer and your friends. You will be rewarded in heaven!
author: Dorie L.

description:
Truly a local treasure...moist, flavorful, delectable bread...simply the best I have ever had!!

Thanks Leah and Chris for introducing us to this focaccia. I would like to know the brand of their olive oil....yummy!!
author: Katherine F.

description: We've been buy from them since I was a baby, it's probably changed hands. This is the BEST ever!!!! Don't miss out people.
author: Karen J.

description:
One of the best places for focaccia? Wrong! Try the ONE AND ONLY PLACE FOR FOCACCIA! In fact, I think every Italian restaurant should serve Liguria's focaccia - forget bread and butter, bread sticks and maybe even garlic bread! 

Since childhood, there's only two things that Liguria makes... fresh baked focaccia and Liar's cookies... 

The plain focaccia alone is so flavorful from the brushing of olive oil then lightly salted to the soft and airy bread. Topped with mushrooms or green onions or garlic or rosemary and even pizza (smothered with pizza sauce and green onions only)... ALL DELICIOUS! 

Also delicious, Bugias or Liar's cookies. Bugia is liar in Italian. The story goes that these fried pieces of dough with hints of citrus were always being stolen from the cookie jar. The cookies were covered with powdered sugar so that a trail of powdered sugar would lead to who really stole the cookies from the cookie jar! A sweet tale for these lightly sweetened, crisp cookies.

Some tips:

* Get in early for the best selection- cause they do sell out.
* You can pre-order days before for pick up, but it won't be the freshest cause they pack em in the morning and sit there til picked up. 
* You can request for focaccia to be sliced, but they tend to stale faster. 
* Purchase frozen focaccia - it's cheaper and so convenient for random pasta nights when Liguria is closed! 
* Cash only.

Last tip:
* Enjoy the SF Giants memorabilia while snacking on a piece of rosemary garlic focaccia (my fave)! GO GIANTS!
author: S Y.

description: Doesn't look like much but the most amazing foccacia especially the Raisin one. Even gets wrapped in paper and string!
author: Darren J.

description: All I have to say is GET THE ONION!! I don't give 5 stars on the first try, but I could see how the focaccia here becomes a regular vice for people. They deserve their stellar rep!
author: Anne J.

description:
I heard all the hype about this place and have always wanted to try it, especially after coming back from Italy and tasting what true authentic focaccia is supposed to taste like.  Sadly, I was disappointed.  It taste nothing like what my taste buds have experienced first hand in Italy.  Their focaccia was decent, but not amazing as everyone says.  I have yet to find a "go-to" place to satisfy my craving for authentic focaccia.

Also, they go back and forth handling focaccia and cash without washing their hands.  I guess most people don't care... But that is truly disgusting and unsanitary.  I could have easily dropped a dollar bill on the floor in the bathroom and handed it to them and the next person after me would be having something extra like germs and bacteria (just imagine the possibilities of where your money has been) to go with their focaccia.  

One star for the semi decent (but not amazing whatsoever) focaccia.
author: R. A. D.

description:
I'm a recovering carboholic and once in a while I fall off the wagon.  I know I should take responsibility for my own actions in order to make a full recovery, but it's places like Liguria that just screw me up.

So far I've only tried their pizza foccacia (dry) and their mushroom foccacia.  Everything is so simple yet really good and in a time where every other place is just trying to top one another and getting really crazy with their creations, it's nice to have something just effortlessly delicious.  

Pizza foccacia - I ask for it dry so it's not overwhelmingly saucy and you know what? It's perfect, just the right amount of sauce and flavor with bites of scallions topping the bread.

Mushroom foccacia - This one can get pretty salty and I don't like the edge pieces, it's the center pieces that have all the mushrooms and mushroom juice flavor.  Just give the edges away to someone and eat the center yourself!  

The only reason why I'm not giving this place 5 stars is because parking be a real hassle, but it's SF so no surprise I guess... and also because the ladies who work here can be pretty grumpy.  You wont be walking into a bakery with cute happy ladies baking bread, no they're pretty brusque if you ask me.
author: Priscilla C.

description:
We were introduced to Liguria Bakery on our recent food tour of the North Beach area.  They sell focaccia...and focaccia.  Nothing else.  The store offers the bare minimum both in product and decoration.  I guess it's worked well for them, though.  They've been there for decades.    

We were given samples of a pizza focaccia (bread with marinara sauce on it) and a mushroom focaccia.  We enjoyed both of them, even though I'm not a big fan of fungi.  Some of their other choices sounded delicious, though.  Rosemary garlic?  Jalapeno cheddar?  Sign me up!   Unfortunately, those weren't options for us.  And, apparently, they weren't for any paying customers either. 

Our tour guide informed us that the Bakery opens early in the morning, sells their breads, and then closes up shop by 2:00 p.m., sometimes earlier if they sell out.   I overheard the long line of customers being informed that they only had onion focaccia left to sell.  I looked at my watch.  It read 11:00 a.m.  "Wow," I thought, "they're going to be closing up really early today."

I guess they're comfortable with just making a minimum amount of profit every day, but I think I'd bake a little extra on the weekends to rake in a little extra cash at least through the lunch hour.   I'm just sayin'...
author: Eric K.

description:
Raining Day- while people across the street is waiting in the rain for their food,
I walk into a small whole in the wall, known as "Liguria" 

Best foccacia bread ever. Its completely old school and you don't expected to be treated as if you are a high end bakery. So know what you want, understand that everything will taste good and don't piss off the boss lady. 

Make sure that you check for their posting outside of the door, which is hand written and often foretells all the times they will be closed.
author: Youna K.

description: When I close my eyes, I can still remember the taste.  Perfection!  I cannot remember the name  of it, but the one with the pizza sauce on it is AMAZING!!!  Everything about it is perfect!  The bread, the sauce...OMG the sauce!  If I could, I would fly back for one day just to have this again.  It upsets me to see people leaving bad reviews just because of customer service.  I really, honestly wouldn't care.  Maybe the owners should say "no focaccia for you!"
author: customer s.

description: Pretty tasty fresh baked foccacia bread.  I am not a real fan of foccacia bread but this place makes them likeable because they make them soft and moist.  We will probably return to try other flavors as they are great for sandwiches, pizza, and accompaniment to soups or salads.
author: V B.

description: Hands down the BEST Focaccia this side of the universe. Seriously, it's better than the focaccia in Italy.
author: TJ C.

description:
Fogaccia,  five stars, Service, one star.

I have been patronizing Liguiria Bakery for over 50 years! Way before focaccia got trendy.  Been through all of the changes in staff and prices (once 15 cents a sheet!).  

What I don't appreciate is the surly service from the older woman.  I have had a number of incidences from her.  Once, when I called to confirm that they were open that day, her sassy retort was, "I answered the phone, didn't I?"  Who needs that?  

Got back at her because another time, when I asked for some frozen pizzas from the upright freezer (btw, a bargain at $3, freezes and reheats beautifully), she picked through them for the flattest ones.  It was really obvious since I only wanted 4 sheets and she put back fluffier ones also marked "T" for Tomato. Not to be duped, I sent her to the back to also fetch me a fresh sheet and bought more time by having her slice it.  I then snuck  back to the freezer and switched out the flat ones for plumper ones!!!  When she came back out, she either didn't notice or was too embarrassed to observe how much my pizzas had "risen".  LOL!!!

Today, I phoned and got the nicer younger woman, who said she still had some frozen pizzas still available that I then rushed over to buy.  When I arrived, only the older woman was at the counter and without even checking the freezer automatically said there was no more. Really?  By then, the younger woman remembered speaking to me on the phone not only got me my pizzas but let me pick.

I suppose Liguiria is successful enough to not worry about a Fogaccia Nazi at the front counter.  Because it is a San Francisco institution, customers will tolerate its limitations, such as sporadic hours and surly staff.  I will continue to go because Liguirua is a one trick pony with an awesome product and I like supporting small family run businesses, well, most of their family.
author: Elizabeth D.

description: I LOVE this place! My mother used to treat us with bread from this place when I was little and it is still amazing 20+ years later! The onion focaccia is my absolute favorite!
author: YZF M.

description: The best focaccia I've ever tasted (Pizza and Rosemary Garlic).  Was in line for 2 hours this morning and was worth it!
author: Alma C.

description: This bakery's truly Italian focaccia brought me back to my teenage years in Italy, helping me get over the homesickness brought by two months of couchsurfing across the US. Every single focaccia they make - from the marinara to the plain one - are worth a try. The price is honest and even cheaper than Italy. What more do you want?
author: Carolina V.

description:
I've been eating Liguria Bakery's Focaccia bread since I was in the 2nd grade.  My grammar school used to (and I'm sure still does) sell slices of their pizza focaccia bread for 25 cents a slice (thought I'm sure inflation has driven those prices up since back then).  This was a treat that I looked forward to every where through 8th grade.  Once I moved on to high school I forgot all about the place.

Fast forward 8 years and I had since moved back to San Francisco and happen to live 3 blocks away from a guy I became friends with in college.  One day I'm hanging at his house and he offers me some focaccia bread...low and behold it is the very same focaccia bread I used to eat in grammar school.  My friend gave me the address to Liguria and it quickly became one of my favorite food places.

I have had several of the different focaccia breads they make here (rosemary, garlic, onion and mushroom) and they are all pretty good.  They are fluffily and fresh...but the star of the store is the pizza.  Each sheet is toped with a tomato sauce and covered with green onions.  The end result is a juicy and delicious.

NOTE FOR FIRST TIMERS: Liguria Bakery sells out quickly.  They make a certain amout a day and once they sell out they close so you should always try and get there before 10 am (I usually go around 9) if you want to be able to choose from everything.  Also note that service there isn't great.  The ladies behind the counter aren't the most patient in the world so know what you want.
author: Rob P.

description:
This is my favoritest (I know there is no much word, but you know what I mean) place in SF.  They have THE BEST focaccia bread in North America.  The other place to get this authentic bread is in northern Italy. Liguria Bakery  should be on your Foodies bucket list.  Otherwise, you are miss out. 

They have about 8-10 flavors of focaccia bread, from tomato to olive to raisins to garlic.  My must-haves are tomato, onion, and mushroom.  I usually consume 1/2 within the first day,  and use the other half to make panini sandwiches, which make the sandwich totally out of this world.  I usually arrive at the bakery about a quarter after 8am so that I don't have to compete with the kids from Saints Peter and Paul School across the street.  Free parking is also obtainable within 1/2 block during this time as the meters don't go into effect until 9am.

Be aware that during the year-end holidays, do expect to wait 30 mins or longer in line to make your purchase.  Additionally, they typically close for vacation during the WHOLE month of August.
author: Jean T.

description:
My coworker brought a few bags of these goodies back to the office one morning.  They tasted so good, I asked another coworker to sneak me another one because I felt bad for taking seconds... I instantly searched up this place, book marked it, and went to hunt down these foccacias the week after.  

My two favorite:
#1 Tomato Sauce w. Green Onions (messy goodness)
#2 Mushroom (buttery fatness)

At $5 a slab I think it is a pretty good deal.  I usually put these in the fridge and toss it into my toaster for a snack.  I think you can also get the frozen ones a little cheaper too, and heat it up in your own oven.

They run out before noon sometimes, so come early!
author: Lynn L.

description: Coffee these days costs more than a slab of this delicious focaccia.  For $5 you'll get a healthy portion of authentic Italian, gluten-filled goodness (when your Nana's doppelgänger serves it up with a hint of sass you know it's real).  Jalapeño cheddar for savory and cinnamon raisin for sweet (rosemary for the indecisive or simpler folk).
author: Hans R.

description:
I would have to say that this foccacia, was gosh darn amazing! Light and buttery (hopefully olive oil though) and my piece was sprinkled with rosemary. For $5 it was an amazing buy. Maybe a little too much bread for me alone but that is why I shared the wealth. 

I will definitely be back to try the other flavors soon!
author: Alyssa A.

description: I have lived some time in Genoa, Italy, where focaccia is from, and I can tell you that this one is really good. I don't think you can find more authentic in SF, the plain and onion ones are as close as it gets to the real deal!
author: Benoît D.

description:
Not that this place needs another good review but I just had to comment on the experience.  While waiting in line at Mama's we saw people going in and out with their paper wrapped breads so I decided to yelp the place.  After reading the great reviews about the focaccia and that it is the only thing they sell, and the rudeness of the staff, I just had to go over and experience this for myself.

It was so awesome, like something out of a Seinfeld episode.  The old Italian lady comes into the nearly empty front room and says nothing to me.  Just stares and waits.  So I tell her I would like the rosemary garlic focaccia and she grabs it with her bare hands, wraps it in the paper, ties it up and says "five dollars".  I pay her and leave and later when I try the DELICIOUS focaccia, I laugh to myself about how quirky and unique this place is.  I mean how can they survive for so long in a high rent SF district selling only one product until they run out each day and treating customers like they couldn't care less?  Go for the delicious focaccia and go for the experience!
author: Charlie M.

description: Take it back, take it back...back to the early 1900's!  That's right, they survived the first big earthquake and made it through 89 with no problem at all, and still kicking down the same exact focaccia.  This place is absolutely soup nazi status however.  Those of you who watch Seinfeld know exactly what I'm talking about.  The employees here do NOT fu*k around.  They are there to give you the focaccia, take your cash, and point you out the door.  Believe me when I say however, that this is the best focaccia you have ever had.  My wife and I are Vegan, so we are lucky to be able to experience the famous Pizza Focaccia on a weekly basis.  It's $5 a loaf, they only take cash, and there's no place to sit, they close at like 1pm...but believe me....when you taste this focaccia....your serotonin levels will spike to new levels making Liguria Bakery your new daily destination for a fix.  And just a side note, this place is one of those old San Francisco traditions....don't go ruining it by telling your hipster friends about how amazing it is and that they need to go.  We have to many transplants running around SF making things overly crowded and expensive as it is.  The last thing I want to see is some douchebag sagging his skinny jeans asking why they don't take Apple Pay.  When you find out about this place, do every native in San Francisco a favor and keep it on the hush!
author: Devin E.

description:
Get There Early

Family owned and operated for over 100 years. Olive oil Foccacia made the northern Italian, old fashioned way, wrapped in butcher paper and tied with string. Ask the ladies to cut it to take away. Closes when sold out so you gotta get there early for the best selection--usually around 1 pm. (Stockton and Filbert)
author: Desiree P.

description:
This experience had a very 'soup nazi' kinda feel. You better know what you want by the time it's your turn or else these ladies are gonna be super annoyed. We went the day before they were taking a month off for the summer, so I think a lot of people were stocking up. No jalapeño cheese, mushroom, or olive focaccia by 10am.

We ended up getting the pizza, rosemary, and garlic.  The bread is delicious.  The pizza is my favorite of the 3.  It's substantial without being too dense.  You can easily save or freeze your leftovers for later on.  Try it toasted...it tastes much better.
author: Gina J.

description:
what a find! bf's chef told us about it and we stopped by before heading out to Sonoma. So glad we did (and didn't know Mama was across the street, cool, but they're closed on Mondays)

Got the Pizza and jalepeno. SOOOO GOOOOOD. fresh, soft, topping was delicious.
They lasted pretty well and long. But don't try to keep them for too long..after 3pm or so, the pizza was no good.

but definitely can see ourselves buying them and bringing them to parties and such!
author: Christine M.

description:
LOVE this place. I've been coming to this bakery from k-8th grade. I went to school at SSPP which is right next door. So this is like my childhood place.  Focaccia is always fresh and so tasty! I don't know if there will be another place that can beat the authenticity of Liguria. 

Family owned business and their kids also went or currently go to SSPP. If you grew up in the North Beach area, this place is a gem and well loved.
author: Sheena C.

description: We were in line for Mama's and noticed this bakery. We thought they weren't getting much business in comparison to Mama's and right around noon they completely sold out of most of their breads. We were amazed. Staff is not that friendly but $5 for a pretty big amount of bread. We split the onion one and it was good and simple! Tasted like some garlic in it-have yet to try more!
author: Lauren W.

description:
Came in here after getting breakfast at Mama's because my boyfriend raved about foccacia! We ordered the pizza one! Tomato sauce with green onions on bread! So simple yet SO DELICIOUS! The bread was so soft even after a few hours after we bought it. We walked through North Beach and China Town with the bag and I could not stop getting a whiff of how fresh the foccacia was. Yummmm.

$5 for 8 pieces was definitely worth it. Can't wait to come back and try some more flavors!
author: Cathie N.

description: the absolute best in the world!  miss living in the city and getting that crazy delicious bread!
author: gretchen y.

description: Inconsistent hours. I couldn't find current hours of operation posted online anywhere. I had to drive into the the city to find out they are closed 12/25 through January 4th 2016. 5 stars for the bread , 1 star for communication.
author: Elizabeth C.

description:
I'm surprised I haven't reviewed this place.

The first time I ever tried focaccia from Liguria is in 2008 when my friend brought some home to San Diego after a weekend trip to SF. The bread was already a day old by the time I ate it, but damn--it was good.

Ever since then, I usually go out of my way a bit to get Liguria even though I never have any business in North Beach. I've been to SF maybe 6 times since first trying Liguria's bread, and I've been back 4 times--never have I been disappointed.

I'm in Chicago now, so getting to and from SF is a bit more of a hassle. Luckily for me, the girlfriend's from the Bay Area, so hopefully I'll be finding time to go to Liguria more often. I haven't had any in nearly a year and I'm starting to fiend for some good oily bread.
author: Kenny O.

description:
My most wonderful and handsome boyfriend dragged himself to the store before 8 on a Saturday and waited in line for more than 25 minutes with a bunch of old Italians to get me Liguria's delightful focaccia. He got the rosemary, the pizza and jalapeño/cheddar breads. I love the white paper and string that they package the bread with, very old world. The bread are moist and fluffy, so full of flavor. 

My favorite was the jalapeño and cheddar. The jalapeño really added a kick to the bread and the cheese was the missing ingredient on the pizza focaccia. The pizza one is rather saucy (literally) and can get a bit slimy/soggy. The rosemary is a bit dry, I believe they used the dried herb instead of fresh rosemary, but the flavor is still great.

I love that there are still places like that in the city. Next time, I'll get up early and do the waiting in line :).
author: Alice W.

description:
On a recent trip to SF, Liguria Bakery was a must stop. It wasn't a "maybe if we have time" stop, it was a "someone will die if we don't go there" stop. So we did, right before we hit the airport. I bought a pizza, rosemary garlic and mushroom to go and we also got a pizza sliced up to eat in the park. I didn't know that you could get it sliced up to eat right there. They just cut the sheet into 8 pizza sticks, so that you can grab and munch. I never had the pizza one before so was anxious to try it. GL said that it was good based on the reviews he read. 

Verdict on pizza: eh. It is what you would think it would be, it's only tomato sauce. Mind you, it's good, but it is really wet and makes the focaccia soggy, so the focaccia is really the victim here. That didn't stop us from finishing them while watching a tai chi battle in the park though. 

The mushroom is tried and true. I took a couple of pieces of mushroonm on the plane with me the next day, and it was still soft and so yummy. I wish I had taken the whole thing because airplane food is just getting even more digusting. If that's possible. 

Each piece, which is about 12x5 inches is about $4 or $4.50 and totally worth it. I froze the rest of them so that I can eat it when I get back from my business trip. Aside from my bf, that's what I'm looking forward to the most when I get back.

Tip on parking - metered parking is easy to find in the mornings M-F. But if you get there early enough (it opens at 8, we got there around 7:30), you might luck out and find parking in the residential neighborhood there which is two hours free beginning at 8:00 am.
author: Ming-Jou C.

description:
I was raised up in the city and used to visit them on an early Sunday morning. My favorite  focaccia breads were: raisin;  pizza; and green onion.  

Whenever I am visiting that area, especially early in the morning- I would purchase each of my favorite breads for good memories. Their quality is A1.

Their other selections (i..e, mushroom, garlic,  black olive,  etc.) are also good

Screw the people who have complained about the service,  The owners are quite  nice people.  They should get over their inferior complex.
author: Marshal L.

description:
Best. Focaccia. Ever. That's really all you need to know. If you're reading this, don't hesitate....if you're doing a search for Focaccia, then just go here. They've been making this stuff since before you were born (yeah you!!). 

This is an old establishment. This is all they do. I grew up on this stuff, eating it since I I first had teeth, and it has not changed!! (Well, they did add some new types of focaccia....all of which are still awesome.)

Tips: The business closes when they sell out, so it's best to go in the morning (early if you can). Also, parking sucks. What to order? Honestly, whatever you order, you can't go wrong (order whatever ingredient you're craving). I usually order the pizza, green onion, mushroom, plain, olives, and raisins (and yes....usually all at once when I go there...HEY!...I ain't greedy!!...I live in the East Bay, OK!)

Paolo says: I :heart: this place!!
author: Paolo V.

description:
Excellent focaccia - light and fluffy.  I recommend their garlic bread. 
The pizza bread would be nice if they added cheese and baked their tomato paste.
author: Ivan D.

description:
Any more pizza bread on a Saturday at 11am?

YES! SCORE! So lucky today! I love love love love the foccacia here, and after all these years the taste/recipe has not changed, but so sad to see the price. What happened to the $1.25 when I was a kid, now it's $5! But I remain loyal. Thank you for your yummy foccacia!

Go pizza!! The only way!
author: Vanessa K.

description:
Focaccia so good, it's just about the only thing they sell.

I don't think I was a focaccia fan until I came here. Come here as early as you can because this place is so old school, their closing hours are: until it's all sold out. And they do usually start selling out of certain flavors by 11-12pm-ish. 

Sweet and savory: mushroom, rosemary, onion, pizza, raisin, and more. It's a family run joint and they hand-wrap each order. No seating, just grab it and you can run over to the crappy park across the way to nosh on it. 

Parking sucks. Bring a passenger and double-park it.
author: Sarah T.

description:
Their pizza focaccia is my favorite - super soft. 
Never lasts for more than a day and a half at my house, because I just can't resist. 

The olive focaccia tastes good toasted. I'm not so much a fan of it at room temperature because it's not as soft as the pizza (probably because of its lack of red sauce that keeps the pizza one so moist). But, toast it and it makes for a good breakfast snack.
author: Denise L.

description: It's been a while since I came here. My mommy used to work in this area and would always bring home some foccacia for her babies! We drove past recently and decided to get some for a stroll down memory lane. We got the onion and the garlic and it did not disappoint. Its a decent portion and the taste was amazing. I like to toast it at home and eat it for breakfast or for snack. It also goes well with olive oil? will definitely be grabbing more when I'm in the area.
author: Kristina L.

description: The most freshly prepared bread that I have ever enjoyed in more than 30 yrs of living in SF. A must is to get there early or you'll be out of luck. It's old school but in a good way.
author: Ken I.

description:
A classic San Francisco establishment. A no frills kind of place with a line out the door unless you get there early!

A few of my favorites are: 
Rosemary
Pizza
Garlic


Bring cash.
author: Sara P.

description:
For $5 I made this huge piece last from breakfast to lunch. 

I ordered the pizza one and it was amazing! It was cold (is it supposed to be? I'm new to this). I warmed it up a bit at work and ooooh buddy was it good. 

I'm fortunate in that I live very close to it so I can roll out of bed and head over.
author: Cesie A.

description: The absolute best foccacia in California. In business for over 100 years, this is a landmark. When I think of North Beach, this is the first place that comes to mind. It has been here long before I was born and will probably be here long after I am gone. All the locals come here and I suggest all tourists make this place a MUST on their ititerary. Although I don't live in the neighborhood anymore, I make it a point to stop by for some foccacia whenever I'm in town.
author: Paul L.

description: I don't get it? It's foccacia, and it's good, but it's nothing special. The price is really good for the big slab you get, but it's exactly what you'd expect it to taste like. Maybe it was all the hype, but I really don't get it. I bought the green onion and the garlic right before they closed, and even after warming each of them before eating, it tasted pretty similar to any other Chinese buns. In fact, the green onion foccacia tastes exactly like a green onion twist/bun. I'm glad I can cross this off my list, but I don't know what else to say.
author: Danny C.

description:
We all know the focaccia is outstanding. But so is the whole experience you can have of eating and buying. The cashier wraps your order in plain paper, ties it up with a string, while you try to catch a glimpse of what's baking in the back.
You pay for that substantial package and head across the street to Washington Square Park. Grab a bench and watch folks doing tai chi. Or climb Telegraph Hill and eat with a view of the water. Or both - it's a lot of bread!
author: J B.

description: Glad we popped into this place after breakfast. Luckily no one in line since it was a random Tuesday morning. We got the cheese and jalapeños foccacia. Well worth the $5!
author: Cher C.

description:
Self control - none, when in front of the raisin focaccias. It's not too sweet, sliiiightly sweetened with bits of raisin. 

Same deal with the pizza focaccia. I never knew focaccia can be so soft, and never thought id type focaccia so much in less than 5 sentences. focaccia.
author: Ami Y.

description:
The best Focaccia of your life! I always get the pizza and the onion and then throw in a misc flavor to try.
I have given as gifts, brought it to parties, served it at my parties, sat in the car and hoovered it alone.... ok TMI...

Cash only and get there early, you will no be disappointed.
author: Beebe J.

description: Good focaccia.  I don't know if it's worth a trip out of your way, but its tasty and fresh. I had the rosemary garlic and my son had the pizza. Thought the rosemary was better.  There wasn't a line when I got there and they had everything in stock, but it was only 11am. I only gave three stars due to the rude service. I know it's all about the bread, but when you walk up to the counter and say hello, you don't expect them to just glance at you and turn back to their friend and continue their Italian conversation for another 2 min before turning back to you with an expectant look.  Ok, yes, I know, this is SF, not Austin, but still.  And I know it's not just the cultural thing, because I've been to northern Italy and most there are very  friendly. So go for the focaccia, but don't expect a smile or even a thank you.
author: Danyel C.

description:
This Bakery is one of the old standards of San Francisco.  It is located in Little Italy/North Beach, off Washington Square Park.  It has been around since I first tried it 35 years ago.  They make only one thing - Focaccia and they make it well.  The only change is that over the years, they have added more flavors.  When you go there you have to know what you want or they will go to the next customer.  Like Seinfeld's "soup Nazi".  When they sell out, they close for the day.  
If you are near Washington Square early in day, you can try a taste of old San Francisco.  The pizza and the raisin are classics.
author: Al E.

description: Go early, especially on weekends. Rosemary and olive focaccia run out especially quickly.
author: Debra A.

description: Best. Focaccia bread. EVER. This is a go-to place if you live here or if you're only in town for a short time. They have a bunch of different flavors and they're all amazing.
author: Haley P.

description:
LOUSY NON EXPERIENCE!

We are middle aged couple. Well dressed, clean and polite. This is our experience on a weekday around 11:00 am right after we ate at Mama's. 
We walk in. 
There's an old woman behind the counter who doesn't look at us or even acknowledge our presence. She seems to purposely avoid us.
There's an old man sitting on a chair with his dog that doesn't look at us or even acknowledge our presence. He seems to purposely avoid us.
There's a third person leaning against the wall near the counter that doesn't look at us or even acknowledge our presence. They seem to purposely avoid us.
There's no product on the shelves. 
There are no other customers. 
No one is talking. 
We walked out.
It was like a Twilight Zone episode. If I could give them a big fat ZERO I WOULD!!! How do you run a business like that? I am the other half!
author: Kirk M.

description: The older woman very aggressively snapped at me for plugging in my phone (after I paid, while waiting). Get over yourself! I was one of the few people in the place and had just paid $5 for mediocre bread. Not worth returning.
author: Demadora Q.

description: Kill them with kindness...one of these days I will get her to smile, until then I will just have to keep going back for their deliciousness foccacia.
author: Eve C.

description:
As many of the other posters, have been coming here on and off since I was a kid.   About once a month, when in town, I pick up a couple of slices for business meetings.   

However, time frames in the week have now gotten shorter.  According to the sign in the window,   they are now closed on Mondays effective this month.
author: Bob G.

description: After reading all the reviews on getting to Liguria Bakery before they sell out, I woke up early last Saturday and made the trek across the city to arrive at ~10:30am.  Apparently I had nothing to worry about, as there was no line and they didn't seem to be out of any focaccia varieties.  We ordered a slab of rosemary garlic for $5 (plain=$4, onion=$4.50, everything else=$5) and received a ~10"x13" rectangle.  Soft and greasy in the center, crisper on the edges, it was very good.  Two of us finished off the entire slab in one sitting!  Too bad the old lady that works there isn't the most pleasant person to interact with.  I would probably return if I was already in the neighborhood, but I can't justify waking up early for good focaccia and bad attitude again.
author: Beatrice W.

description:
Hand over a $5 bill, receive giant sheet of springy, decadent bread.

I'm pretty sold. It's best eaten in adjacent Washington Park, so come on a sunny weekend morning and bring a book, and napkins, since pizza's the best flavor, and they don't skimp on the sauce. 

Good breakfast option for two.
author: Cathy H.

description: Arrive early and bring cash to purchase the best focaccia of your life. She sells out frequently before the end of the day and requires cash, but this no-frills shop knows what it does best and sells only that. They have about eight to ten different foccacia flavors. The jalapeño cheddar is delicious. I am contemplating how I can get more to the East Coast. The shop is reminiscent of days passed with just a register, two workers, and paper wrap for your foccacia. Don't miss out. If you decide to wait in line for Mama's Diner, take a second to run across the street to purchase foccacia. You won't regret it.
author: Ashley V.

description:
What a great throwback to a simpler time. Delicious Focacia tied up with baker paper and twine. Looks like a gift and would make a welcome one. 

We scored some garlic Focacia and some mushroom variety. Ended up eating with some tomatoes, basil and olive oil. Delicious!
author: Dusty B.

description: Full disclosure: I am Italian, born and raised.  I live in San Francisco, and my wife and kids spend every summer 8 weeks in Italy, 4 in Milan and 4 in Chiavari, which is a town 3 train stops east of Recco, where focaccia was invented.  Liguria Bakery is not that great.  I know it is an institution in San Francisco, but if you think you're having something special, you're being duped.  Don't get me wrong, I eat it, and it beats many other american focaccias, just like I eat pizza here: because I feel like pizza even if it is not like at home, better than nothing.  And the price is good, but it is nowhere near original focaccia ligure.  Plus, I am sorry, but I cannot stand the sour, crotchety old lady at the counter.  There is nothing salvageable about that kind of behavior to customers.  You would not experience that misery in an Italian bakery, or focacceria.  Would give 2 stars for the value prop, but the strega behind the counter brings it down to a 1 star
author: Massimo M.

description:
This bread will change your life. 

You better know what you want when you're asked; if you don't, they'll skip you. 

Cash Only!
author: dan d.

description:
I guess this isn't fair because I've had the focaccia in Italy, which is what made me seek out focaccia at home. That being said, I was very excited when I found this place and my boyfriend has been here many times. He said it's good, but not that good and I would have to say that agree with that sentiment.

If you're in the area the Pizza focaccia is great, but their hours are frustrating. We tried to come here (usually made it before 12 and they're not so good about answering the phone) THREE TIMES and two of the three times they were closed. Which is a hassle if you live across town. And if you call to try to have them set it aside for you, they don't hold it after a certain time, which I do understand because they want to sell everything, but if you don't even hold it for 30 minutes, that's not cool :( Although, I know they're popular so they can afford to be fussy.

The Pizza is the best flavor since the actual bread can be a bit dry. I like my focaccia a bit more oily than how Liguria makes it, but I suppose that's not good for the diet. But if you're going to be eating a ton of carbs, might as well!! Another thing I didn't like is the canned-type ingredients they use as their toppings. I can't say for sure that they are canned mushrooms, olives, etc. since I didn't see the actual cans, but it certainly tasted like it to me. 

I don't think I would make a special trip for this focaccia again unless I was REALLY craving a fix, but if I was in the area I guess I'd pick one up (if they're open!!).
author: Victoria J.

description: All I can say about this place is HOLY.  Bring your cash and keep your fingers crossed that 1) they are open 2) they have the pizza focaccia still available.  You would think with such a demand that they would produce more to supply the need, nope.  If they are out, they are out, better luck next time.  Hope you get lucky, it's a gem.
author: Zin M.

description:
ON VACATION UNTIL 8/21/2011.

Please give this review 1,000 useful ratings so that everybody knows not to go there before August 21!!
author: Sam M.

description:
I've been coming here for more then a decade, it started off as a treat I'd get on my way to St. Peter and Paul, when I had field trips and had to bring lunch. 

I love love love their pizza flavor, not only is it yummy and filling but it is cheap! The price has gone up over the years but not as fast as inflation would have it so its still pretty damn affordable

The ladies are family and there are times when you'd get a smile out of them but those are far and rare; but they're not rude and quite frankly I don't care

It's that good

Consider yourself warned--go early, they close shop at 1pm but there's been a few times I go around 12:30 and once around noon and they've closed for the day because they sold out 

And having seen a guy go in with this little wheely cart..and walk away with more then two dozen sheets

You snooze you lose
author: Whitne Y.

description: I've been enjoying their bread for over 40 years!!  My grandpa had a store on Columbus St and Union St, so I was a regular at age 6.  It's been consistently delicious since then and they are still using butcher paper and string to package it up...so awesome...pls don't ever change.
author: Ta P.

description:
I can now purchase the focaccia from Lucca Ravioli Company located at 1100 Valencia St (between 22nd St & 23rd St) and no longer have to deal with the horrible women that own/operate Liguria Bakery :o)
I just don't understand how anyone can be miserable ALL the time, specially as much money as they're making.
author: May G.

description: Really, who cares if they don't smile!!! They have been up at the crack of dawn for a billion years pumping out the greatest  Italian bread you will taste in the USA!! This bakery has been a part of our dinner table for 46 years. I get conversation and a smile. They are no fuss! So if your not going to come back because you didn't get a smile and a lap dance, well then woot woot for the rest of us! No line and more for us!
author: Lisa A.

description:
I would eat this focaccia anytime, anyday!

The focaccia makes my mouth water and I can polish off half of it within a few minutes. But then I'm sad that it's half eaten. Next time, I'll order several to last me throughout the week.

Here's what you need to know:
- cash only
- the focaccia rectangles cost $4-5
- when they sell out, the place closes

I've had the flavors pizza and rosemary garlic. I like the rosemary garlic better, but I also like the pizza too. I think it's better to warm up the pizza.

I love the touch of wrapping up the focaccia with wax paper and tying it with twine. Adds a nice element!
author: Josh O.

description:
Yummy foccacia bread!  This was my first time visiting with a friend.  We came all the way up from San Diego to bring some back home.  I ended up ordering the Garlic along with a Black Olive bread.  The bread was packed in white paper for us to take home, so I really didn't get to have a bite until we got back to San Diego.  

My only wish was that I bought 5 more loaves of bread to take back, since they don't do online orders.  Ugh.  A lesson to be learned for next time.
author: Ulysses M.

description:
I always get the pizza focaccia along with the jalapeño one.  I love the mother and daughter at the cash register.  The mother reminds me of my grandmother, God bless her, all business with no time for tomfoolery.  I love to buy the focaccia already cut and go eat at Washington Square.  Be sure to get there before 11am or earlier otherwise they may be out of some of the more popular kinds.

I get a laugh out of people complaining about the service.  This is a family run business for 100 years.  That's part of the charm.  Edsel Ford Fong at Sam Wo's would bring these people to tears.


I always wonder if all the people waiting in line at Mama's have any clue that some of the best focaccia in the states is only across the street.  I think not.

For 5 bucks it's a great snack for a couple of people.
author: Scott B.

description: What can I say about this institution???? Brings back childhood memories... North beach, Washington square park, and focaccia bread! Best focaccia in the city hands down. Whenever I am in the neighborhood, I always stop by to get some.  Unfortunately, the prices have gone up over the years but the quality has not been compromised. A must if you are in the area.
author: Alicia A.

description: Ok, I been coming here since I was 16 years old when the Foccacia was .95 cents.  Now its $5 buxs and I still am coming for mypizza fix!  I show up very early in the city (coming from east bay) as my mom lives close by and even 8am there's a line.  Folks, you gotta put this place on your bucket list.  LOL
author: Donna H.

description:
Oh my damn....

I really don't know where to start....

while waiting in line for mama's across the street (2 freaking hours) my friend started talking about the dealio with this place. Only a certain number of focaccia made a day and they close. Why yes I will have 2 please. Still warm? ok, cut one up, i'll eat while we wait. We got the rosemary and the pizza. While waiting we inhaled the rosemary and it was absolutely delicious. It was the perfect thickness and the right amount of spices. The pizza had to wait until the next morning; there was a lot of eating to be had that day. The pizza was drenched in tomato sauce and riddled with green onions. It looked a little funny but toasted up to a nice crispiness and it was divine. 

The place is super cool. Simple, vintage look even comes with a disgruntled italian woman behind the counter too. Well aren't you a ball of sunshine at 830 in the morning. I hope everyone in SF experiences this place at some point in their lives. cash only.
author: Melissa W.

description:
Praise Buddha. This is the best thing around. All you food truck-tracking posers take heed. These people do one thing incredibly well, sans fanfare. You could not find a less inspiring interior that turns out more incredible food. Not food. BREAD! Ya year me? BREAD! 

This place is just incredible. When you walk in, you feel you have stepped into something that has sustained generations. The women in the front look bored off their a$$es, and they wrap that paper and string with an efficience unmatched. 

Whomever is working those massive black ovens in the back....SUH-LOOT! Bravo! 

Have you noticed how cool (BASIC AND FUNCTIONAL) the menu is?! If the plain interior doesn't tell you that you are about to taste something amazing...the simplicity of that menu, likely hung a generation ago, hints at it. 

Onion and tomato are my favs. I don't like onion, so ultimately I pick it off...but I love the hint of flavor it leaves behind. Wow Wow Wow.

Everyone should be going here at least once a month. You will be both fatter and happier. I'm issuing a guarantee!

Hella Hella Goooooood!
author: Opinions Are My Own, G.

description:
Their focaccia is great, but the pizza focaccia is the best...EVER!

This place has been around for decades and there's nothing fancy the decor. They make only one thing - focaccia bread. There are a handful of different kinds though like garlic, mushroom, olive, plain, raisin, rosemary, jalapeno and pizza.

I believe their stuff is also vegan if that matters to anyone. Anyhow, be sure to get here by noon, because they run out of the focaccias very fast and close up shop once it's all gone. This place only accepts cash, but it's not expensive at all. It's between $4-5 for about a 10x14 sheet depending on the kind you order. 

If you're in North Beach, do yourself a favor and stop by...before noon.
author: Lloyd B.

description:
My aunt said Liguria bakery is the place to go to when I have a craving for focaccia bread that tastes like it was shipped over from Italy.  I came here at 7:30 AM on a Saturday, yes you read right...7:30 AM  to grab some delicious slabs of bread.  Since I traveled about 25 minutes to this bakery, I ordered almost the whole menu: pizza, rosemary, mushroom, and jalapeno cheese..to be exact.  Each focaccia piece was about 10 inches by 6 inches for $4.50-$5/each.  Not too shabby if you ask me.  My favorite one was the rosemary...it had SO much more flavor than i expected it to have.  I also enjoyed the mushroom and jalapeno cheese (watch out..it's pretty spicy).  The pizza was my dad's favorite and he thoroughly enjoyed that one was well.

Tips:
-If you get there around 7:30 AM (although I know it might be painful), parking will be like a walk in the park + FREE
-Bring cash! no credit cards accepted!
-If they have frozen focaccia, get it!  It's only $3 and all you gotta do is reheat in the toaster oven or microwave and it still tastes great!
-they're going to be on vacation during the month of August 2011..call to make sure they're open!

Seriously, come here if you enjoy authentic focaccia bread, you surely will NOT be disappointed. =)
author: Kristen T.

description: I eagerly drove to Liguria Bakery to buy some focaccia and some pizza. When I got there I noticed that the ladies at the counters touch food and money back and forth as it is completely normal. I think touching money and food is disgusting and unhealthy. I now wonder if there are regulations for handling food in San Francisco. I cannot tell what the focaccia or the pizza taste like because after seeing how food and money were handled I lost the motivation. I award 2 stars to Liguria Bakery for the handling of the goods but also for the coldness and unfriendly attitude of the ladies at the counter who don't have a particularly nice attitude (they don't really need to care about their reputation with 4.5 stars on Yelp).
author: X. Y.

description:
Nondescript interior, no signage outside, thickly accented cashiers, surly service, delicious specialty.

Those not hiding under a rock through the '90s (and who are also extremely nerdy) would surely think of the 'Soup Nazi' Seinfeld episode off the bat.

What's great about Liguria is that it is all of the above, but you WILL get your foccacia, under one condition.

GET THERE EARLY. Don't casually stroll out of brunch across the street at Mama's, lackadaisical and hungover, and except to buy the city's best foccacia.  Lucky for me, my friend lives around the corner, and I can roll out of his bed on a Wednesday morning, grab my favorite rosemary foccacia, and munch on the way to work downtown.

I've been hesitant to share Liguria with Yelp, but it has almost two-hundred five star reviews, so I suppose the secret's out.  I just never want to hear "no foccacia for you!" So save some for me.
author: Joanna M.

description:
It pains me to write this review as this has so much nostalgia for me since I used to go to Sts Peter and Paul Church for grammar school and Liguria's was a staple.

When it's good, it's still damn good.  Slightly warm, perfectly salty and "golden" in flavor.  It doesn't get any better than the pizza foccacia.  I could wolf down all 8 slices in an order in one sitting.  The raisin one is damn good too.

But here's the rub.  It's not the same anymore.

The consistency is off.  I got a bag today and all the edges were dry and the foccacia was hard.  And the thicknesses were all over the place.  There used to be thick and thin pieces, but this time it was THICK pieces with not so light bread.

And finally, you could see giant jugs of canola oil stacked in the baking area.  CANOLA oil.  Ooof.  I feel for them as they probably can't charge much more than the $5 for their foccacia but ingredient costs have skyrocketed.  But, alas, it is definitely noticeable in the final product. in replacing olive oil with canola oil.  The flavor isn't quite what it used to be, the bread isn't as light and moist.

Sigh.
author: J M.

description:
This is a good, no-frills place to get some solid foccacia, if you don't mind the somewhat cold reception that you may receive from the people behind the counter. 

Over our last few trips, we've tried the mushroom, the pizza, and the rosemary garlic varieties. I'm a funghiphile, so the mushroom is always a strong contender. I found the pizza to be a little messy. This past time, we tried the rosemary garlic. No garlic powder here! This is the real deal, so if you're worried about your breath (I'm not), give this one a spin.

No matter which variety you choose, you'll find the foccacia to be nice and chewy. The counter staff will cut it into strips, which make it a little easier to take on the go.

We've been here on a number of occasions, and as others have said, they do tend to sell out quickly, especially for the most popular flavors.
author: Safford B.

description:
What a gem in North Beach! I grew up at the school down the block so I remember when the focaccia options were limited to plain, pizza, and olive. Pizza was my favorite, especially when the bread was still warm inside the little brown bag. 8 rectangular slices of tomatoey goodness... YUM.

I've since moved to LA and have tried focaccia breads at many, many other places in hopes that it'll be just as good as Liguria Bakery. No such luck because nothing compares. When I'm home in the city again, I'm definitely dropping by for a nostalgic focaccia fix.
author: Michelle C.

description: Awesome focaccia.  Jalapeños & cheese is our favorite. A little spicy & cheesy.  Raisin makes great breakfast. While we waited we scarfed down a box of liars cookies.  The foccasias reheat well in the toaster.  I wish have some right now.  Cash only.  Grumpy service but worth it.  Go early because they close up shop when they sell out.  I've been there at 11 am and everything's gone.
author: t d.

description:
My boyfriend has been talking about getting this pizza  foccacia bread in the north beach area but we would have to wake up early to get it, like 7 a.m. early on a Saturday. Ew. Somehow he got me up and we drove bright and early to get this amazing bread everyone keeps talking about. 

As I line up, an annoyed employee walks out with the bread and vents to another employee about phone orders. Low and behold the phone rings and she picks up the phone and painfully takes another order. 

The way she talked to the customers on the phone made me feel uncomfortable because she was taking her frustration out on them and making them feel uncomfortable when they just had questions about their products. What's worse was she told them you need to make up your mind or you have to call back because we are busy. The menu isn't that complicated at all but if you are a little confused it can be your first time and a grouchy employee will not help you make your decision.

I understand that people have bad days and maybe it wasn't her day but that is not how you treat customers. No matter what day you are having, you have to be presentable to the customer and show your business in a good light. 

Moving on to important things, the foccacia was sooooooooooooooo freaking good. I was a newbee and decided to only order one sliced rosemary and garlic foccacia bread. It was so warm, fluffy, chewy and flavorful. It had no crunch whatsoever so if that was what you were looking for go somewhere else. It is not like pizza bread but if you like fluffy bread, definitely swing by if you are close by. Oh and if they run out of bread they WILL close early so come early!

So all in all it is a good place to get foccacia bread but don't expect anything more than that.
author: Jayne A.

description:
Another childhood favorite.  I remember stopping by Liguria with my sister on our way to school for the "pizza".  We'd order it cut and they would hand us a brown bag full of heaven.  Yum!  This bakery is probably one of the best places that started my love of bread.  And the focaccia was cut to the perfect size for eating for the walk to school.  For whatever reason they would only cut two sheets.  No more.  And you just knew not to ask why!  

There are more flavors to choose from nowadays. Pizza will always have a special place in my heart but rosemary garlic is a new favorite.  Apparently I'm not the only one who likes it because I've walked in just after 8am and they were already sold out of it!  

So when I get a craving for their focaccia, I have to temper my heart just a bit in case I show up too late and they're completely sold out or I have a brain fart and show up in August when they're on their annual vacation!  But if its the former, I can always pop over the Lucca Ravioli and possibly pick up some of their focaccia there to satisfy the craving.  Unless its a Saturday night like it is right now then I am just plain out of luck!
author: J. P.

description:
I think the dialogue I had with the woman running the counter sums it up:

Me: You have the best foccacia!
Woman: Yes, I know. We are celebrating our 100th anniversary this year.

Case closed. This place has been open since '11...1911.

Delicious pillowy-soft, airy foccacia.
author: Alex C.

description:
Liguria has the best focaccia outside of Italy!  It's a San Francisco institution and always a good stop if we're on this side of town.

At 12:30 on a Saturday, only plain and green onion were left in stock when we stopped in.  Well, it made the decision easier.

I like the focaccia here b/c it has the perfect blend of olive oil and salt seasoning.  It's also tender.  Can't wait to go back.
author: alli t.

description:
Wonderful fluffy, oily, well-flavored pillows of dough for roughly $5 each (seems like the prices have been rising slightly as per the past photos).

The owners are lovely older folks who are willing to help cut the foccacia into strips.  

Flavors to try:
# Black olive
# Garlic rosemary
author: Jennifer Y.

description: I. Love. This. Focaccia. The onion is probably my favorite but the garlic rosemary is also amazing. The earlier you go in the morning the better because the bread is fresh and warm. They're also a great deal at between $4.50 and $5 for a good amount of focaccia. I also just love the packaging, wrapped in paper and tied with string, makes me feel like I'm in Italy picking up my daily bread.
author: Grace P.

description:
The jalepeno cheese is da bomb!!! Also da bomb is the raisin focaccia and then the tomato is a good treat too, but you have to eat it when it is fresh.  I will someday go back and try all the diferent selections. I have never had it tastes this good until yesterday. yummers yummy yum yum!!!

This place is a small place on the corder but people are waiting out the door just to get it. This is a to go place and there isn't anyware to sit and enjoy but there is a park outside you can sit and enjoy there.
author: Tim E.

description: lived in SF for 20+ years and found out about this place for 1st time today. authentic, delicious, cooked perfectly. this place has long history.
author: Pauline P.

description: Great foccacia but get here early because their more popular flavors run out. And have an idea of what you want to order, the employees are not helpful and very very impatient. Also, bring a driver or take the bus because parking near this place is close to impossible.
author: Andrew W.

description:
Everyone in line at MAMAS, made a trip across the street. I yelped the place and it had great reviews and stars, so I decided to make my way over after breakfast to order their famous focaccia bread.

There was a line at 9am and tons of people pre ordered batches of focaccia bread.  

I had the jalepeno cheese, olive and garlic.  It was bomb!

It paired well with the wine I was drinking that night. 

I will be back!
author: Chanel L.

description:
The focaccia is so fresh and delicious, that I want to cuss on here to get my point across.  I'll refrain...but, you MUST come here and try the focaccia.   It's so simple, yet so amazingly focaccia-y.  I had a dream about it the other night, but before I could take a bite, I woke up.  Needless to say, I cried myself back to sleep.  

Anyway, it's a great place to grab a snack to take with you before hanging out in San Francisco or biking the Golden Gate bridge.  

We tried the black olive and the rosemary/garlic foccacia and both were fantastic and highly crave-able.   This will be my first stop upon my return to San Francisco.

Bring  cash, as they don't accept credit cards.  And why should they?  VISA and MasterCard don't deserve a cut of their hard earned money.  Screw them.

If they're busy and it's late morning, don't expect them to shower you with faux friendliness.; this isn't TGI Fridays.  Accept the fact that not everyone likes you and take your food and leave. 

Go early and avoid the lines.  Go late and you lose, sucka, cause they sell out around 1 pm everyday.  The early bird gets the foccacia; the late bird is stuck eating worms like an a-hole.  Oops...pardon my letter.
author: Evan S.

description:
I dream about this place. I think about this place and my mouth waters. I come here at random times because I have a neverending craving that makes me want this at all times.
I love their pizza focaccia and their rasin focaccia. I also love their olive focaccia. Pretty much if I can get my mouth on it I'll eat it. I could live here and never leave. I love you oh great focaccia place.
author: Christian L.

description:
While waiting in line for Mama's, I checked my Bookmarked in Yelp to see what other grub I can get my hands on since I was in the area.
