According to my Bookmarked Liguria Bakery, a 7x7 finalist of the "100 Things to Try Before You Die list", was directly across from Mama's. As I looked around, all I can see where Yelp says it's located was what appeared to be an empty laundromat. Little did I know that this store would be the place for the best Focaccia Bread in all of the Bay Area. 

Before Liguria Bakery the only time I eat Focaccia Bread would be with my pasta whenever I go to some Italian Restaurant. I never realized that it would be a great meal all on its own. 

So after a wonderful breakfast at Mama's, my wife, daughter, and I walked across the street to this empty shop. I didn't really know what to order because they had so many different flavor. I decided to take the safe route and got the Garlic Focaccia Bread since that was something I tasted before. So I got one full order for $5 and took it home for our late snack. 

My first bite of this Garlic Focaccia Bread, I was already hooked. This was the best G-- D--- bread I ever had. Nothing else with it, just the bread, and a glass of San Pellegrino, mmmmmmmmmhhhhh. It was just bursting with flavor, it's so good. Next I got to try their Pizza, or the Onion, oooohh ooohhh the Rosemary, no the Rosemary and Garlic. Hell for $5 each I'll get them all.
author: Mel B.

description:
First of all they are not rude here as other reviews suggest!  The person who helped me was pleasant and the other worker was helping another customer and making small talk about people they knew.  

Now, on to the important stuff...the focaccia is to die for.  I find most focaccia a bit bland and too thick but not at Liguria.  I narrowed down my selection to the pizza and a green onion.  The green onion was excellent plain as well as sliced for a sandwich.  The onion had a lot of flavor and overall the bread had a savory buttery taste.  I added fresh mozzarella and pepperoni to the the pizza and broiled it and will never order pizza delivery again.  I'm keeping this on hand for those cravings.  The tomatoes and green onions were so fresh and made for an excellent pizza base but would be great on it's own too.

I think I'm going to need to make lots of return trips to work my way through their entire offering.  As many other reviews suggest, make sure to get there early because they were already sold out of the rosemary before 9 am.
author: Lisa K.

description:
Their focaccia is absolutely amazing! Try the rosemary. It's to die for! Sucks I have to come too early, most of the time, if not all the time, they're sold out by 10am. 

The focaccia is so amazing, it'll spoil you for life!
author: Jaclyn A.

description:
This is a review by a vegetarian

I want to order a queen sized garlic foccasia, sleep on it until it gets moldy and then do it all over again.

How's this for a quintessential San Francisco weekend morning: Sit on a bench in Washington square eating Liguria foccasia for breakfast while watching old Chinese people do tai-chi. Then walk up and over filbert street and down the stairs on the other side and take the ferry to Angel Island.

At 8:45am there are 100 morons in line outside for Mama's while there is no waiting for foccasia across the street? what kind of messed up world do I live in?
author: Bob R.

description: Everyone tells me the 'pizza' foccacia bread is to die for. I tried it and for $5 for about 8 slices it's only decent. To be honest, I won't be coming back. It's not that special. The bread was really cold and had nice hints of rosemary and fresh tomatoes, but that's about it. I wasn't impressed. I would have preferred warm, I have no idea if people like it cold or what, but that is how I received mine. Skip.
author: Chuck N.

description: Worth a walk from wherever you are waking up in San Francisco!
author: Erika W.

description: It's just focaccia folks. It's cute the store is old. It's cute the people have been there a long time. The focaccia is very fresh and comes in different flavors.
author: John H.

description:
This is another one of those places that just make me stop and say, "Thank you, Yelp, for showing me the light yet again..." 

I had been dying to try this place for the longest time and finally had a chance to come in yesterday. I came in around 1 o'clock and immediately the lady behind the counter says, "All we have left is pizza."... "Well then," I thought to myself, "I'll take it!" 

For $4.25, i got a medium sized sheet of some of the tastiest bread I've ever encountered. The bread is ridiculously soft and squishy, like brand new play-doh. The sauce tasted great and the green onion dices were nice and big. All my life I'd been getting my focaccia from trader joes or farmers markets... but Liguria has now shown me what I've been missing- and there is a difference. 

I'd say this focaccia is probably the best I've ever tasted, however i haven't tasted that much focaccia in my life... so who knows. The only thing i didn't like is the bread was WAY oily... not disgustingly oily, but more like 'I should use a napkin for this' oily. 

For what it is- A store that ONLY sells Focaccia- It's a solid 4 stars!
author: Greg G.

description:
I had been here before, but remembered how amazing the focaccia was there, so we decided to go back and at least grab some to take home one morning.  When we arrived at around 11am, there wasn't much left - only the pizza, onion, plain, and rosemary, raisin, and black olive I think.  We got the pizza, onion, and rosemary and walked across the street to the park to devour it.  Sooooo good. 

Love love LOVE the focaccia here.  All of it.  We ended up eating most of it in the park across the street, so didn't have very much to take home after all.
author: Jenna L.

description: Excellent focaccia bread but extremely rude staff.  I've been twice, both times was either met with overtly rude comments or was ignored while the lady carried on a conversation with another worker.  Customer service is everything to me so regardless of how good their bread is, I won't be back.  I'll spend my money at a more deserving bakery - another one up the street has larger slabs of focaccia for a dollar less, nearly as good, and much friendlier staff.
author: Ben Y.

description:
I've been wanting to try this place for a while after hearing about the amazing focaccia. I can't say I'm a huge focaccia person to begin with, but I love anything breadlike. I don't live close enough that I would be able to pop by first thing in the morning, but I've just started going to a new yoga place and realized this place was just a block away. I left early from work for my 12noon lunchtime yoga class, hoping there would be something left. I'm happy to report that on a Friday, around 11:50, I could get a pizza focaccia (they also had raisin). They didn't have any on display (I don't know if they ever do), but I didn't even need to see it after hearing about it. I also picked up a box of their cookies, although after an entire focaccia, the cookies will definitely have to wait until later.

Overall, for not being a focaccia fanatic, I thought the pizza was really good. The sauce, and red sauce isn't my favorite, was absolutely delish. I did have it packed up for about an hour and a half while I went to yoga and had to heat it up in my work kitchen. It was good, but I'd like to try it toasted up a bit like others have recommended. I really want to try that jalepeno and cheese one too! Will definitely be back, although I'm not sure when I'll be there that early!
author: Lauren M.

description:
I've always bought their fresh focaccia, but I never knew they sold frozen as well!  

$3 for a frozen slab, about a $1.50 savings when compared to the just baked.  So now my freezer is fully stocked with parchment paper wrapped focaccia, waiting to be popped into the oven whenever I get a craving.  And it tastes just as awesome- I really mean that.

If you haven't tried the mushroom yet, definitely do.
author: Joanne G.

description:
I have fond memories of going here since I was a child and has been a family favorite  for decadese..now living outside of SF, getting Focaccia from Liguria is a treat that makes everyone in the family get real excited! So amazing! 

The grandma working at counter always reminds me of my noni and makes the trip well worth it every time!!

Be warned, it is cash only and sells out by 11 or 12pm during the holidays!
author: Domenica G.

description:
In my experience places that only sell one thing and do great business have some amazing product. Either that or they're fronting a drug operation.

I came early on a Saturday morning. There was already a small line trailing out the door. I saw a good amount of customers spending $30-50 on focaccia bread?! I've had good focaccia bread but not good enough to buy sheets and sheets of it. So my expectations rose dramatically.

The menu surprised me. There were about eight different kinds of focaccia. Two women work the front. They run this place with true veteran's gruff. It's an odd pleasure to watch two women wrap up up stacks of focaccia like bundles of newspaper. What's strange is that once a customer makes their order they have to walk into to the back room and pull off the bread from cooling racks then walk back in to wrap it. There's a lot of storage space in the front where they could put the bread yet it's kept empty. Maybe it stinks up the place and makes the bread stale faster? There has to be a reason. They're don't rush because people are willing to wait.

I ordered the raisin as well as the rosemary garlic focaccia bread. I expected better. Yeah it's good but it's just like eating pizza sticks. They don't put on a ton of toppings so the flavor isn't anything "wow". I imagine if you're a huge lover of garlic bread you'll love this place. I did like the raisin focaccia much better than the rosemary garlic. Butter and raisins, yum. If you toast the focaccia it's twice as good since you get a crunchy warm bite.

_____

I enjoy eating it in the morning as a quick fix but I think I'll stick with my bagel with cream cheese and lox.
author: Michael H.

description:
Who doesn't love a 100 yr old SF family owned gem! Especially fresh and warm focaccia! Can't do any other than Liguria's. 

Every flavor is damn good but the faves are:pizza, mushroom, olive and jalapeno! Come early they sell out fast! OR pre-order ahead. Get a few flats wrapped or have them sliced and bagged. Take them home to the kids, share them at a potluck or be greedy and eat them all to yourself! 

Also get your Liar's cookies....you'll be lying to have more!
author: Ro M.

description:
The lady at the counter had a stick in her butt.  I was having a good day, but when I asked her about the focaccia bread my smile turned upside down.  You don't have to be mad at the ENTIRE world mama.  

Thankfully, the bread made up for it and it helped my wait for Mama's seem a lot shorter since I got to nibble a bit before lunch =).   Try the pizza flavor, it's yummy.  The marinara sauce they use is homemade.  You can taste the fresh tomatoes and the wine!
author: Char C. B.

description:
My update is just like my original review-the place is great and doesn't really need yelp to justify it's existence.

I wish I could get there early enough to more than just the pizza focaccia.
Do come early and order often because at 12:30, she was about to sell out of all her breads. 

Do pay with cash, and don't be a smart ass and sass the lady about why she doesn't have more to sell. Don't be the guy kicked out of the soup kitchen basically.
author: Jessica K.

description: Best foccia. Use to come here all the time with my dad when I was...10? I'm 32 now so they've been doing well for a long time! Best is the original with red sauce. Its really flavorful. I believe they charge if you want the bread sliced
author: Rater 1.

description:
Yummiest Focaccia ever!!!! Yucky customer service but yummy focaccia - Even trade off? Who needs customer service anyways - Hello, how can I help you?  is so overrated....
I love the Raisin - it's just the buttery focaccia and raisins - no sugar crap sprinkled all over it.
My new favorite is the Jalepeno Cheese- So damn good!!!!!
The Mushroom Focaccia - YUM!!!
The Pizza sauce on the Pizza focaccia is salty good- This is my BF's favorite. FYI- The Pizza Focaccia does not have cheese on it, just tomato sauce - but you won't miss the cheese, I promise.
So far I've listed everything that I've tried there and there wasn't one that I didn't like. 
They also have these crispy type of cookies sprinkled with powdered sugar in plastic containers that say they were made in North Beach- I brought a few of these home to people and everyone loved them- I was told the sugar crisps reminded them of Taco Bell Sugar Twists but way better.....
I always make a trip to Liguria's when visiting S.F. - just know what you want when the lady looks at you or else....

FYI- depening on what has not been cooked yet , you can get frozen focaccia to bake in the comfort of your own home- I'm just worried that it won't taste the same, c'mon- we all don't have large fire brick ovens at home....
author: Ursula U.

description: How the heck do they bake the amazing, earth shattering focaccia bread to perfection day after day??!  More addicting & harder to get than crack bc of the huge, early morning queue + running out daily.  They close when they run out - which is early.  I'm a fan of the cinnamon raisin version (sweet) & olive.  Well worth the parking nightmare.
author: Kim S.

description:
Thanks to a new Yelp buddy, I decided to try Liguria Bakery. I happened to be in the North Beach for work and thought I'd drop by to see what the hype was about.

I was surprised that I've walked by this location a handful of times, noticed the old-time bakery equipment in the window, but it was always closed when I was there.  I had no idea that they had amazing foccacia.  The service was efficient, not especially warm, but I needed to get out of there because I was parked illegally in front of someone's garage door, so I didn't mind.  It's cash only, so carry some green.

I left with a white paper parcel of 2 pizza and 1 mushroom foccacia.  As I drove home, i was tempted to rip into the package and try it, but I was able to resist.. for a while.

I put the package on the kitchen counter.  I just had lunch, so I wanted to wait until dinner, so I could try it with my husband.

Transcript of the next 15 minutes.

- I walked by and eyed it.... got a glass of water, walked away.

- I went back and slid the string off, just to look inside, rewrapped it and walked away.

- I passed by it again, opened it and took a pinch of the pizza foccacia.  Wow, it was so deliciously tart, the soft foccacia, the green onion combination...mmm, mmm!

- I wrapped it back up, wrote a few emails, then went back, unwrapped it, and tore off a piece of mushroom.  It was so TASTY. I love mushrooms so this was a hit.  I left it unwrapped this time.

- I came back and took out a knife and cut a skinny slice from the pizza and ate it.  Then I tried to read a book.

- I put the book down and cut a piece from the mushroom foccacia.

This continued until thankfully, my husband walked in the door.  We both enjoyed the foccacia for dinner.

This is a great bakery with irresistible foccacia. It's like Pandora's box or Sirens or something, you just can't resist.
author: Catherine W.

description:
Sure, the foccaccia is tasty. But the service is seriously subpar. When I asked how the onion foccaccia is, the lady answered "It's onion." Sure, I know that, I can read, but maybe tell me if it's really oniony? What kind of onion? Is it your favorite or do you recommend something else more? Nope, nothing.

Also, I noticed the price has gone up. Is $5 for a square of foccaccia really worth it? I think I'll work on fresh baking my own next time.
author: Cathy S.

description:
I woke up this morning and was CRAVING this delicious focaccia bread.  We literally rolled out of bed, got dressed and called the bakery to see if they were still open....10:30am!  Yup, i said it.  We thought there was a slight chance this bakery would already be closed before noon!

They make their focaccia fresh everyday and it's a ticking time clock until all the focaccia is sold and then they shut the store for the remainder of the day.  LUCKILY they still had their pizza focaccia which is one of my favorites!  

This is a CASH ONLY mom and pop bakery so go in with cash, preferrably exact change and you will be in and out in minutes.  There are LOTS of regulars...while we were waiting in line the Mom and daughter said hi to a few people that they were familiar with.  Definitely a good feel vibe inside.

I think the only part that grossed me out was that they touch money and your food... one after the other.  definitely not sanitary.  BUT, i think i can make an exception this one time as I have never had better focaccia than this spot!

I really need to wake up earlier if I want to try their garlic, jalapeno or olive focaccia.  I can never get there early enough!
author: Sandy L.

description:
Omg yum! I was around the corner running errands this morning and decided I may as well stop in to get some focaccia since I heard it was amazing here. They were out of the ones I wanted (Rosemary and garlic and plain garlic), but I got rosemary and mushroom.

Both were so good! The bread is really airy and filled with Olive oil and just the right amount of salt. SO tasty. The mushrooms and rosemary were also the right touch. YUM!

I will definitely be coming back here.
author: Lisa C.

description:
Pizza Bread!!!

As a child growing up in Chinatown my older brother would bring home these fabulous sheets of pizza bread (focaccia) wrapped in its simple white wrapper for the whole family to enjoy.  Oh what great memories!

One recent morning while waiting to meet an old friend in North Beach, I decided to drop in to this familiar storefront.  I hadn't had Liguria's freshly baked pizza bread in well over a decade, but now more frequent visits to North Beach are a must.  I've had the onion version as well, and it is very good.  I enjoy these right out of its wrapper or lightly toasted in a toaster oven.
author: Wilhelm Y.

description:
A classic neighborhood bakery that does one thing, and they do it very, very well. So who cares if they don't take credit cards? Who does in this city? And plus, nothing's all that expensive anyway. As my father would say, "for that quality, it'd be a bargain at twice the price". 

And as for the hours, it's a bakery people. All good bakeries close early. Don't believe me? Go ask your grandmother. Plus, it gets you out of bed and on your way to starting a day that you know is going to be good because you have a paper-wrapped slab of Liguria foccacia in your hand.
author: Amanda S.

description:
love,
love,
LOVE Liguria Bakery.  

My review is for the pizza focaccia bread as this is the only one I have purchased.  It was absolutley AMAZING!  I took it home and added various toppings making four different types of pizza.  I also held onto the bread for over a week on one occasion in my fridge and it was still delicious when I put it in the oven.

There are so many more to try... if I can get away from the pizza!

Great bread + great people = A lifetime consumer!
author: Jenn J.

description:
Holy focaccia, Batman! This wonderful bakery cooks up some stellar Italian flatbread. Choose from many flavors, including cinnamon raisin, cheddar jalapeño, marinara, olive, and mushroom, and bite into the soft, greasy bread joy. 

The staff can be a little crotchety, but the bread's so amazing, it doesn't even matter. That whole "service with a smile" thing is totally overrated anyway.

Hint: Get there early. They run out fast, and will close up shop when the focaccia is all gone.
author: Christina S.

description:
I went around noontime on Saturday. I asked for plain... sold out... What wasn't? Pizza focaccia. So I had that... You see, I'm not a pizza fan... also I never intentionally go out to seek focaccia. I usually get french bread. 

I brought the focaccia back home and ate it without heating it up (cause I'm lazy like that) and it was delicious! The sauce on top with the green onions were a great complement to the focaccia itself. It was delicious. I ate the whole flat focaccia....

Tip... go early. I was listening to one of the ladies behind the counter saying how raisin sold out by 10 a.m. and others were selling out at 30 minute intervals!
author: Vera W.

description:
Liguria's focaccia is the original focaccia and all other attempts to make focaccia pale in comparison.  The dough is one of those family secrets, bathed in the coolness of the fog rolling in nightly from the Golden Gate.  The ovens as well as the ingredients are old school, but what do you expect from the best focaccia in the world. 

Got a couple of slabs of the pizza focaccia yesterday and YUMMMMM!  Everything is the same (except the price).  Many decades ago, my mom would venture out of Chinatown to go see some Italian ladies in North Beach.  She'd return to our little flat with some focaccia.  She just called it "I-tal-y bread" and it was always a hit.  

If you can, cut them up in 3"x3" squares and toast them.  Wow!  You can really enjoy the unique bread that would have a light crispiness and the flavors of the topping is greatly enhanced.  

This is a hidden gem that is worth the time and effort and take it from this native San Franciscan.  Simply the best!
author: Stefan L.

description:
So what do you do after finishing up a wonderful carb coma breakfast at Mama's?  Head across the street to load up on more mind blowing carbs for later.  No brainer!

My group stopped by Liguria to get focaccia for lunch/dinner later in the day.  We went with the black olive and rosemary garlic breads which were $5 a piece tax included.  The nice lady behind the counter wrapped them up old school style with paper and string.  Walking in this place is sorta like stepping back in time.  I seriously don't think they have updated anything in the whole place in 30 years, but it must be working.  The focaccia was so amazingly good.  Soft and chewy with just the right amount of olive old and toppings.  The garlic rosemary was definitely my fav, but the olive was in a strong second.  Lay some italian meat on this bread and you have an experience!
author: Tripp W.

description: I went home and ate the entire thing by myself.  No remorse.
author: Rachelle P.

description:
Two words to describe Liguria:  Yum Yum.
(aka what I said verbatim after I finished my foccacia.)

Liguria is one of those places that you wouldn't know about unless someone told you specifically about it.  For me, that person was my friend Agnes who used to live a block from Liguria over 30 years ago.  (Thank you Agnes!)

A bakery that sells only foccacia?  Wowza.  Do we live in a great city or what?      

If walking by, I probably wouldn't stop in because it's nondescript on the outside and if you peer in, you'd see just a long white counter and some mostly bare shelves behind it.  But if you go inside, then you'd see a board (old school style) that lists the types of foccacia (pizza, plain, raisin, rosemary, black olive, mushroom, etc.) and prices (around $4).  You can also get frozen ones.         

The foccacias are about 8 x 10 inches and you can get it cut up into pieces if you like.  Agnes remarked that back in the day, it used to be $0.85 for the foccacia and $0.05 to cut it.  Whereupon the old lady sitting in the corner piped up and informed us, "We haven't done that in YEARS."  Now they cut it for free.  (Nevermind the fact that it is no longer $0.85.)  One thing that hasn't changed?  The foccacia selling out.  Get there early!    

I had the pizza foccacia which was topped with tomato sauce and green onions.  Now being a fervent devotee to all that is cheese I was skeptical of a pizza sans the good stuff but it was delizioso!  (Note to self:  Mention this "pizza" to lactose intolerant friends.)
author: Amy C.

description:
I think of the guy from the 300.

THIS.

IS.

FOCACCIAAA!!!


closes early (as soon as they sell out). Get there before 2pm during the week, before 11am over the weekend.
author: Jen N.

description:
Closed. Closed. Closed. Closed. Closed. Closed.

Open. Finally

Persistence and patience will net you some of the best focaccia in the city. The menu is simple. Five varieties, including my rosemary seasoned slab of carb goodness.

Cost is four or five dollars each. And patience. Plenty of patience.
author: Jason B.

description:
Come before noon because they sell out! They start baking at 4am. This bakery has been running for 100 years. Before the earthquake, the building was a church. They still use the original brick oven.

I was stupid enough to think that I didn't like focaccia because I didn't like it in Starbucks or Panera sandwiches. Farina was the first place to set me along the path of focaccia enlightenment but Liguria's really made me crave the stuff. I tried the raisin and the cheese varieties - both excellent. Beware, this place will totally spoil you once you know how real focaccia is supposed to taste.
author: Marina N.

description:
OK, maybe the service isn't the best you can get but it's not like if you're staying there. 

After all the reviews I've read, I wake up early (yes, 9 is considered early on a Saturday morning ^^) and took the bus to find the Liguria Bakery. I arrived at 10h30 and didn't find any customer inside (while there was this enormous queue outside for Mama's, I have to try it too). 

I ordered a rosemary and garlic focaccia and  weren't disappointed. The focaccia was big enough to feed two starving people and tasted really good. I think this will be part of my new "almost home-made Saturday brunch".
author: Virginie D.

description:
The best Focaccia bread!!!  I remember going to San Francisco and my parents always stopping there first and buying at least 5 sheets of it.  My favorites are: the plain, the pizza, and the green onion.

Growing up never did I realize what a joy it really is.  As I got older I remember going in with my mom to purchase this.  I remember the simplicity of walking in, only having a few choices, making that tough decision of how may to buy and paying.  And of course the attitude of the lady, she never smiled or said thank you, but who cares!! She could have 4 arms and 6 legs and i'd still buy from her.  

Even as a child I remember not wanting to wait to cut the string, tear open that paper and just have at it.  

Now that I've moved across the country that is one that I always ask someone to get me when I come home.  I've even purposely flown into San Francisco just so we can be close enough to stop and get some on the way home.  

I recommend this to anyone who likes Focaccia or who wants to spoil themselves.  The one thing I learned from my parents was always get there early or it'll be gone.
author: Daryl C.

description:
Best focaccia EVER!

You must try the the jalapeno and cheese.  Makes for awesome sandwich bread too.
author: Brian M.

description: Unreasonably good.  I'll never go to the city again without stopping here if their open.  My life will be incomplete if I don't eat this focaccia at least once a month.
author: Aaron B.

description:
Best Foccacia in the Bay Area, hands down!  They have been around forever, read all the reviews.  All true!  Grumpy old grandma at the counter, but best Foccacia bread around.  

These folks know what there doing.  If Grandma learns how to say hi and bye (have a nice day or something) this would be a 5 star vote.
author: Maria R.

description:
3.5

Honestly, I liked the focaccia. The lady was grumpy. I don't particularly see the merit of treating customers like shit. The focaccia was light and airy and good but I didn't particularly love it (I got the pizza and the rosemary garlic). I think I am going to try different flavors (just garlic, and mushroom!) and come back for another review. I LOVE carbs, but I don't know why I didn't devour the two slabs that I got.
author: Emily H.

description:
Real focaccia, not the real best ligurian one you get at the sea side but pretty close.

Incredibly cheap!
author: Paola M.

description: Go early if you want options! I got there around 11:30, one Saturday in the fall and I thought I was in the wrong store. It looked empty. That's because they only had plain and pizza bread left. The lady haughtily replied that they had been baking since the wee hours of the morning and we were obviously there too late. Service aside- the bread really was great! and I loved how they packaged it up with brown paper, I felt like I was in a small town way back in olden times.
author: Sarah S.

description:
The foccacia bread is good, probably the only foccacia I ever want to eat and worthy of 4 stars.  But, by the time I arrived at nearly 1PM, they had sold out everything except onion (green onion on naked, salted bread) and jalapeno cheese.  What did I expect since I didn't arrive early enough while the North Beach Festival was going on this weekend.

What I've never really liked about this place is how mercurial the staff can be.  They're usually lukewarm with their customers, almost the attitude of "we can do w/o your business", "take it or leave it".  There were 2 women in the store, the younger one was reading the paper and the senior was standing there, bored out of her mind.  No one greets you and the older woman didn't even offer to cut our foccacia.  But, another woman came in after us and the younger woman suddenly perked up and greeted her.  Talk about schizophrenic. 

While we were departing, I heard the other customer remark that she's a SF native and never even knew about the bakery.  Well, as a native myself who's been there a heck of a lot of times, I'll tell you... they're a pretty unfriendly lot.
author: Ry T.

description:
I left my heart in Liguria Bakery! 

This place is amazing. What other establishment do you know that CLOSES UP SHOP when they sell out for the day? Probably none because most places don't even come close to selling out!

The lines are long (but not as long as Mama's across the way). The foccacia is FRESH, warm and tasty. And it is SO good no one else can come close! 

CASH only (as the sign says). Wake up early because they might be closed later in the afternoon. And don't mind the rudeness, they're just Italian :) (or so I've been told my Mario my co-worker who knows the family as if they were his own!)
author: Lisa L.

description:
I love that I have a corner bakery now. Every day on my way to work I pass by Liguria Bakery. For the first week or so I was convinced that they were a bakery that also sold fresh ravioli. They have boxes on display in the window with some yellow things inside but it turns out those are Bugia cookies. They are kind of like fried dough sprinkled with confectioners' sugar. It took me a while to finally walk in to order something because they are open  from 8 am-2 pm. I would usually walk by when they were beginning to bake but before they opened and in the evening after work they were already closed. One day I left a little later for work and they were open! It was Friday morning and they were very busy. They were taking phone orders and there was a small line inside. I waited my turn and I noticed that they are Giants fans. I ordered the Bugia cookies and I discovered that they also bake foccacia bread. They make great foccacia. I ordered the cheese and jalapeno. 

I took my baked goods to work to share and everyone loved everything as much as I did. We didn't finish the cookies and they actually kept very well over the weekend. 

The foccacia was gone by the end of the day. That bread is so addicting. I'm looking forward to going back and trying their other flavors. Maybe this Friday?
author: Daisy S.

description: Have been going here since as long as I can remember! Tradition in our family was to go right after church for some fresh focaccia. Red sauce and onion. It is simply the best focaccia you will ever have.
author: a b.

description:
I used to think this bakery was a front for the mob because they are never open and there is never anything in the window. Then one day i saw people going in and out during a wait at mama's so I popped in. Turns out all they make is focaccia, several kinds, and when they sell out (which is early) they close.
Many of the nicer north beach restaurants serve their bread, and it's a must for your home-cooked italian meal. I adore the onion flavor, but my co-worker makes a mean bread pudding out of their raisin bread. I guess i got sucked into the mob.
author: Nikki M.

description:
Here's the deal, my mom has been going here since she was a little girl and I have been eating this focaccia bread since practically birth (not including the time in the fetus where my mother ate this like a mad woman). It's in the genes to love this bread.

I've had a ton of focaccia bread from other places and hand to God i swear to you this is the best i've ever had. If I were on deathrow and could have one last meal, this would be on my list next to my grandmother's pancit bihon. 

You have to show respect for a bakery that's been doing this for generations and does it right. Everything is fresh, has been the same for ages, and is the most delish you can find in San Francisco. Every San Francisco native knows this place and everyone respects it. Go, pay homage and mangia!
author: Kristen R.

description:
Folks, if this place was good enough for my Nonnie (RIP) for over the many many decades, then it's definitely good enough for you!

War Pizza Foccacia
author: Scott N.

description:
Talk about old school!  Don't let the spartan decor fool you...it doesn't look like much from the outside, but this place has some of the most incredible, most amazing, foccacia bread you will ever taste.  Been coming here for years and have had pretty much all of the different varieties they make.  The pizza one is my all-time favorite, but I also love the ones with garlic.  Even the plain and green onion ones are really good.  The pizza one is celestial when heated up in the oven, perhaps with a little high quality mozzarella cheese.

I read somewhere a while ago that Liguria Bakery actually used to sell bread when it first opened in 1911.  Apparently, in competing with the big name bread companies of that era, they discovered that the larger bakeries were intentionally selling at a loss and giving free bread to new accounts to gain their business.  The grandfather or relative of the current owner was said to have told the others that they were not in business to make it, just to give it away.  At that point, they decided to specialize in foccacia instead and history was made!

Two things to keep in mind...Come Early and Cash Only.  If you go late, it is pretty much certain that they will be sold out.  Once they sell out, they are closed for the day, sometimes as early as 1PM if the weather and sales are good.  

Here's two more lesser known things that you might not be aware of.  If you're craving Liguria Bakery's foccacia bread, but don't feel like driving to North Beach or fighting for parking, Andronico's recently carries a couple varieties of Liguria's foccacia bread.  Pretty convenient!  Also, if you go to Gino & Carlo's (bar) early morning on weekends, they often have free Liguria bakery foccacia bread for their customers there although it is served cold.

I could totally picture Tony Soprano walking in here with a smile and picking up a slab or two tied with string for his friends at the Bing.  Liguria Bakery is another of many reasons why San Francisco is a true food lover's paradise.  If you like foccacia bread, this place is a must...the best ever!
author: Roy N.

description:
They sell mostly just focaccia bread and that's enough because it's probably the best in town.  It's deliciously chewy and soft, topped with just the right amount of salt and oil. They have a few different flavors including onion, jalepeno, garlic, plain, garlic Rosemary, and pizza. Am I missing a few? Anyway, go before noon because they sell out fast. Five dollars will get you a big enough slice to share. 

As for service, they look pretty grumpy a lot of times but you're going for the food.
author: S. D.

description:
This is another place I notised the sticker on their window that says "People Love Us On Yelp!"

I needed something substantial besides a cream puff.  I could not believe that there was a focaccia place right there on Stockton and Filbert Streets. I went in to get a business card. I had to wait until after mass to pick up a slice of mushroom focaccia! It was well worth the wait!  The older lady, I think the mother of this family bakery, helped me.  She was a bit too grumpy for my tastes. I ordered the mushroom focaccia. I had to ask her to slice it up for me, it was too big for my little mouth. She was not too pleasant about my request for cutting it up. Uh, first time here Lady. S'cuse me, Grumpy Lady, give me a break!  

I munched on a few slices. . .mmm, heavenly focaccia! It was SO GOOD-- mushrooms, olive oil and soft bread to the bite and taste.  Despite the Grumpy Lady, I will be back and try the other focaccias.  Especially the garlic one, though garlic first thing in the morning.  A little too early for me.
author: Chiara A.

description:
The Italian ladies are a bit intimidating, but they make a hell of a bread!  The focaccia bread here is delicious.  Fresh, soft, chewy in a good way, and very flavorful.  I tried the pizza but wanted to get the cinnamon raisin too.  It's definitely worth the $4-$5. Ask them to cut it up for you if you need.  You can also call in large orders.  (You can also buy bread and munch on it with your friends as you wait in the painstakingly long line across the street to get into Mama's.)  When I came here early Saturday morning there was no line.  

Cash only!
author: Michelle P.

description:
There's not a whole lot of food for which I'll go completely out of my way, but the foccacia at Liguria is. Mushroom, garlic and rosemary, plain--I'll take it all. 

Yes, they do run out early, but I like that it means the bread is always fresh. And yes, you could take it home to eat, but it's really too good to wait that long, so why not have it sliced up into strips for easy eating over in Washington Square Park?
author: Katie I.

description:
My sister used to go here in college 20 years ago when she went to UC Davis. It's great that they're still around and serving delicious focaccia. They sell out of certain flavors early so expect to be slightly disappointed if you go in around noon. Also, this place is across the street from Mama's so a lot of the customers waiting in line stop in to get some focaccia to munch on in line.

I'm honestly the biggest fan of the pizza focaccia. It's not actually like pizza because there's not cheese but it's all tomato based with green onions and it's my favorite.

I love how it's a family establishment and they wrap it paper and tie it with string. Definitely worth going to if you're in the neighborhood or waiting in line at Mama's.
author: Jackie T.

description:
HEAVEN.   

SERIOUSLY HEAVEN.

I am still craving it.  I first heard about this place on bay area backroads about 4yrs ago or so, when they did a show on san fran.  I took notes of the food places and this was on the top of the list.  My life doesn't get me to San Fran too often, but when I knew I was going to GGpark recently I dug up the episode online and tracked down this bakery.

It's in a very old building, its been family run and operated for YEARS and YeArs.   

It was so delicious I am still not even sure I can capture how delicious with words.   The bread was creamy, light and fluffy and had SUCH a good flavor.

I called in and ordered in advance since I had read hear how they sell out.  I got one of each flavor, and I think the olives one is definitely my most favorite.  Between the sweetness of the bread and the savory of the olives it was the marriage of two lovely flavors.

You are seriously flawed in life if you don't take the time to experience this bread.  failzilla !!!!!!
author: Jennifer C.

description:
This place has been floating around on my bookmarks for ages as I'm a huge bread lover, and I walked into work today to be happily surprised with samples of this yeasted delicousness in 3 varieties - the pizza, mushroom & cinnamon raisin!  What a treat for one of the most dreaded days of the work week.

The pizza is ever-so-soft and just about melts in your mouth.  The pillowy focaccia is topped with a thin, luscious salty layer of tomato sauce and sprinkled with green onions.  It was so good I contemplated taking the bus out to North Beach just to buy a slab.  The next was the mushroom which was brushed with olive oil and sprinkled with mushrooms.  That one was more delicate in flavor, and paled by comparison to the more assertively flavored pizza focaccia.  Then I bit into the cinnamon raisin and ooh-boy ~ so tasty!  Plump raisin studded bread, sprinkled with cinnamon sugar, is just what I want to eat first thing in the morning!

I'm definitely going to swing by Liguria Bakery for a couple of slabs of the pizza & the cinnamon raisin!
author: Janet L.

description:
Pizza focaccia to live for!  

But you need to get there early or you will miss it....this place has no hours.  Once the focaccia is gone (they sell several varieties), they close. 

Definitely old school, very good.  Eat it and you are in for a special treat.
author: Katharine A.

description: What's not to love??? All types of foccacia are great. Love the old-timeyness and the way they tie everything up with paper & a string.
author: Claire b.

description: The pizza foccacia was okay but I've had much better. Surprised at how highly rated this place is. It's really not anything special.
author: A A.

description:
The foccocia at Liguria has been a staple of every family (Mom/Italian side) wedding and funeral for as long as I can remember. I think its a North Beach Sicilian tradition....

Our cousins Vincenzo and Sarah Jane are still in charge of getting it as they are the only ones who still live in the neighborhood. They actually own the place I was born in (Francisco and Grant). Well, specifically the hospital was Mt. Zion, but I had the living room (alt. title: "the front room") all to myself for the first 2 years of my life. No wonder it's my favorite room! My entry into the family forced the move into bigger digs down the peninsula, which sucks cause I would have loved to have grown up calling this city home.

Nani made two kinds of home-made foccacia. The margarita (which is the standard flavor of awesome at Liguria) and anchovy. The only thing wrong with the anchovy kind was...well...the fucking anchovies....I'm not sure if the fond memories of grandmother cooking and cleaning for us (man, that lady could iron!) lean me towards any bias or not, but I'll note here that Liguria comes a close second. You see, my grandmother never had to use words to tell us she loved us. She just fed it to us.

And that's that for the wistful melancholy...

I kind of fell into this entry on the list. My sister Stephanie's surprise 25th anniversary (holy shit!) party was a couple of weekends ago and this was being served in plentiful doses. Once the surprise ended and the drinking started, I got to mingling with old family. As far as my mom's family goes, I'm known by two characteristics:

1) "Sarah's Son" which may make it onto my epitaph.
2) "Computer guy"

Only Vince allows me a third dynamic. Now, I haven't played league soccer in 20+ years. But our conversation since the time I was ten has always been (verbatim, I'm not shitting you):

1)Sarah's Son: Hi Vince, good to see you.
2)Vincenzo: How are you? You still likedah soccer?

Now from the age of 15 to about twenty-five, I argued my case:
I do not play soccer.
I do not enjoy soccer.
I do not likedah soccer. 

Around my mid 20s (someone's funeral or wedding likely) the battle of wills had been lost and Vince could claim victory. I now answer that I love soccer, and play it every chance I get...

I also no longer have any convictions about anything else. At least Vince doesn't gloat. He's a good man, Vince.

Overall - the party was a success. Tears were shed for those who left us in the last 25 years and toasts were made over those we welcomed into our lives.

And - I got to take home about 30 pieces of foccocia! It only lasted about 2 days between Earl and I.

Must go back there soon.

Summary

Food: I likedah foccacia! 5/5 2nd cousins on my mother's side twice removed.
Drink: I fluidly eased between beer and wine like a gazelle sprinting on the safari plains. I don't know where that came from either... 3/5 irrelevant analogies.
DB factor: Love seeing old family, unless they ask me to fix their computer. Sarah's son can be kind of a DB sometimes, but he's cool enough to have a beer (or 6) with. 4/5 jars of anchovy paste.
author: mark q.

description: Fluffy texture. Rich flavor. Walks in the early morning. Rewarding. Better hurry and go here...
author: Lucy M.

description:
Amazing!  I drive 20 mins every weekend from across the City and run through tai-chi-ers and joggers and Mama's restaurant patrons JUST so I can get some delicious, buttery, moist, tomato-y "pizza' Focaccia.

Oh, yes, it is WORTH it.  I bring it to my parents house (god bless them, they live a 5 minute drive away) and we devour it like it's food from the goods (sic. ambrosia).  

Oh yes, not-so-happy Italian (I presume?) woman YES I want YOUR PIZZA FOCACCIA!  I am sorry I am so dumb-asian i didn't know what it was called and had to ask. 

But so delicious!  I recommend you to everyone!  I have never, EVER, tasted more heavenly bread.  To all you dis-believers, DISPERSE!  Leave more room for the asian-who-apparently-does-not-know-what-good-food-is-compared-to-teh-Whites.  

I will continue to come here.  Yes, I live for the weekend now!
author: Kimiko Q.

description:
Best focaccia in the city. Period. Get there EARLY especially on game days/before holidays, etc. They usually sell out well before lunchtime, so don't wait! When they sell out, they close up.
Here's a tip- if they're sold out, you might be able to get Liguria focaccia at Lucca's on Valencia (assuming they haven't sold out, either)

Garlic rosemary is so good I have to get two at a time so I can insure one makes it home without being devoured. My Italian friends prefer the raisin or the tomato.
author: Aaron N.

description: I like when a place does one thing really, really well and doesn't try to deviate. Go to Liguria early (they often sell out and close), or call ahead to place your order. Know what you want when you get to the front of the line and have a back up in mind, since they are often sold out of a flavor (personal favorite: green onion). Yes, service is brisk and no-nonsense, but I think it adds to the charm. Make sure you have cash, they won't take credit cards.Their focaccia is now my go-to item to bring to parties, picnics, or just going to someone's house. Trust me, you'll be more of a hit than your friends who bring expensive wine or homemade desserts! :)
author: Alison S.

description:
Left South San Francisco at 9 am to pick up foccacia for friends and family (11 pieces total).  When I asked for 8 pieces of the pizza the women said she would just give me a larger slab.  When I requested the 8 pieces instead she rolled her eyes and gave me what I wanted.

After paying I gave her my business card and told her to call me if she needed my services (most food service businesses use my expertise).  I would seriously consider a significant discount just to be closer to their fantastic foccacia.
author: Axs S.

description:
I have been purchasing focaccia from Liguria Bakery for at least the past four years and it seems to get better and better each time.  There are nine different types of focaccia and the plain, pizza, and garlic are hands-down my favorites.

This place is about as old school as Mary Jane's and penny loafers, right down to the way they wrap the focaccia (with white paper tied with string) to the no-nonsense counterperson (she is there to only sell focaccia and take your money and the only words out of her mouth will be how much you owe her).  It is spotless inside with minimal decorations and product (focaccia is the only thing they sell, nothing more), however, you can tell Liguria has been around for quite some time by the old time equipment and the way things are worn.

Get there as early as you can as the focaccia sells out fast, especially around the holidays and make sure you bring cash as this is the only type of payment they accept.
author: Kevin L.

description:
Another case of a date that goes bad, but introduces me to a new love that lasts forever!!!

I had been living in North Beach for a few months, would pass by Liguria every weekend on the way to Trader Joe's, but could never tell it was a bakery inside. It seemed like an odd store, with some weird toys in the window, and a faded sign. But one day this guy asked me if I had been there and told me they had the best focaccia on the planet. And he was right!

There's nothing fancy about the place - it's small, one sign with the menu (the types of focaccia they sell), and two grumpy Italian ladies on the other side of the counter. Cash only. I started with the pizza one, recommended by the date. It was UNBELIEVABLE!!! It's been over a year since that moment in time, and I have tried all of them - mushroom, black olives, green onion, garlic, rosemary, rosemary and garlic, jalapeno and cheese and raisin. They are ALL very good, but as I love garlic, the garlic ones are still my favorite, before the pizza one. It really depends on your taste, but I think it's worth trying them all!

Everyone already said it, and I will repeat: get there early as they always sell out, especially if you want the garlic or pizza focaccia. Bring cash, a little patience, and anticipation for an AMAZING Italian bread experience!

This is one of the fabulous perks of living in SF - if you are serious about great food, this is the place to be!
author: Simone W.

description:
Luckily for me, I am a morning person. That  said, there are places in town such as Liguria Bakery where the adage "you snooze, you lose" is very apt. 

Liguria only sells focaccia bread. Period. Been doing it for about 100 years, and I do believe they have perfected the process. They have plain, onion, rosemary and rosemary and garlic. I buy 2 loaves at a time, and they are gone in 2 days. They I go and buy some more. When I have visitors, I drag them out of bed early to walk to the bakery. Then we go and eat the bread in the park across the street.
author: Jimbob P.

description: the best foccacia bread this side of Italy. All they sell here is foccacia - Pizza (tomato paste and green onion - no cheese), mushroom, raisin, garlic, plain. Made fresh daily. when they sell out, the family closes shop and goes home. this is a classic North Beach family owned and operated business which serves up a quality product. Your tourist friends & family will thank you for taking them here!
author: Jeff W.

description:
Best focaccia ever!

I love it. 

Plain.  Tomato.  Scallion.  Big flat sheets of it.  Moist and full of flavor.

Trust me...it's worth going there for a trip.  Come early, or else, they're sold out!  Everytime I get it...it doesn't make it home.  lol
author: Fannie S.

description:
The only reason to be at the corner of Filbert and Stockton at 7 AM on the weekends is for the foccacia. Will never understand the people waiting in line for hours at Mommas across the street. WASTE OF TIME..

Anyway.. the lack of charm from the Liguara matriarch (if in fact she is!) who works the counter makes it even better. Like the non existent decor and the 'sold out' sign, the place is all about the square goodness. If you don't get your ass out of bed, its your own damn fault. Pick up a mushroom and a pizza Saturday morning and you'll be set for your weekend nosh.

It is fantastic. Maybe the #1 reason I refuse to leave North Beach.
author: Nigel E. S.

description:
Love the tomato/green onion and the garlic!  My favey fave is the tomato and green onion though. Been coming here for years.  The older lady and her daughter may seem a bit surly but that's what I love about this place. They're genuine and real. No pretenses here. Just be prepared to say what you want and if you want it cut up. 
Best focaccia ever!
author: Lucky P.

description: Very good foccacias at a reasonable price. I have tried most of their foccacias while working near by. The pizza foccacia is vegan and good for a quick lunch.
author: Sid P.

description: On a lazy weekday, the Manpanion and I played hookie and decided to have a quiet morning in the area. I've been wanting to try this bakery for a while now. Unfortunately, the Manpanion and I usually visit the area on Sundays, when this bakery is closed. We were lucky to visit this total Northbeach gem! The bread runs about $5 per piece and it's cash only. They have a list of available flavors. We opted for the garlic rosemary, pizza, and jalapeno cheddar flavors. All three were amazing, but my faves were the first two. I can imagine strolling around the park and stopping by the bakery for a delicious $5 snack. The pieces are hearty and flavorful. The bakery itself has been around for over 100 years. Given how delicious the bread is, I can definitely taste why!
author: Joanne R.

description:
My Dad used to make French Toast (Italian Toast?) out of cubes of the plain.

The raisin is incredibly good.

A little rosemary-garlic, with some fresh mozz and some thinly sliced prosciutto??
yes please.  

slice it to go for the car?  Make sure to pick a hand to eat it with, and the other to hold your steering wheel with.

If you have low expectations of friendliness from the team there, you'll be pleased.

Closed on Sundays.  Is that new??  I feel like that's new.
author: Glenn F.

description:
Pauline showed me this tasty place.  The pizza focaccia is like sinking my mouth into Italian heaven.  All the sauce and olive oil, thanks Pauline for taking me.  There are other styles, we are going to try Rosemary, Garlic and Plain.  

It is a mother/daughter duo.  They are tough, don't mess with them.  Or your meatballs might be in the next pizza sliced or cut.  Yeouch! Oh yea, CASH only.
author: Michelle M.

description:
Sitting at home now and craving for those amazing foccacias!

Stumbled upon this place while waiting in line at that infamous Mama's Cafe across the street! Lol. Hmm??? There seems to be a line forming in that lil bakery across the street. Wondering what's going on in there so I "yelped"  the place. Oohh good reviews!  Left my lil party since line is longer and confident I'll be back in time. Ran across and got in line and befriended a couple of nice ladies telling me how they been going here for years and telling me how good it is. Ordered the pizza, garlic w/rosemary, and raisins. Oh so soft and yummy! 

If only I live close by and not thousands miles away....sigh
author: Ilikefood N.

description: Focaccia to die for. Our favorite is the Raisins...it's just perfect!
author: Chester R.

description:
Foccacia, or foccacia?  Or would you like some foccacia?  Maybe a side of foccacia to go with your order of . . . FOCCACIA?!  *dances around*  It's got a nice sound and beat to it . . . foccacia foccacia, doncha know i wantcha . . . 

Ok, so perhaps I am not a poet.  Or songstress.  Or whatever it is.  

. . . moving on.  :D

In case you couldn't tell, this place sells foccacia.  Just foccacia.  But it is some AMAZING foccacia.  I got the pizza and the plain, and basically polished them off within two days.  I want more now.  MOAR!  I love me some foccacia, and so will you, when you go here.  So stop listening to my bad poetry and wake up early tomorrow and grab some fresh FOCCACIA!
author: Jeanne Y.

description: Their fucia pizza is so good it is worth a one hour drive to SF just to go and stock up.  They also taste decent frozen.
author: Jim P.

description:
Just had their pizza one and Rosemary garlic. Crazy amazing. Ive been coming here for a long time now since I was in elementary school (won't say how long ago that was..) since I went to garfield, just up the hill. That was our treat afterschool from mums and pops. Delish.

Still is Delish. This was the first time I tried the Rosemary garlic. Oh man intense garlic, like spicy. So they must roast it right. And when you're eating it it's so light! Then you look at your fingers and the parchment paper, and it's just covered in oil. So worth it! It's not like super soft or airy, seems just dense enough. The Rosemary isn't overwhelming, which I think Rosemary tends to be. The super garlic countered it, so works very well together. I would not suggest eating this right before an important meeting or a first date, or meeting a vampire. Knock someone out that garlic!

The pizza is my fave. Its just so juicy and and just savory enough. Can't get enough. Its not super herby or bursting with extreme tastes like the garlic one, but it's very light so you can eat a lot. This is also the one that brings back the good ol kid days.. And that's something I can't just find at any old place.

Make the trek, you won't be disappointed. Then walk over to Washington square park or up to coit tower to savor it all while taking in the peace.

Remember kids: Cash only!
author: May Y.

description:
Two thumbs up for pizza foccacia.  

First discovered this place while waiting in the ridiculous line for mama's, and had to quench my stomach pain with some bread.  The foccacia was obviously freshly baked because it was so soft and moist, and even when I took it home and ate another bite 8 hours later, it was stayed pretty soft.  

At $5 for a whole flat bread is not bad and since I'm not around this neighborhood often, I do like to indulge everytime I do and put in an order.  But it still isn't delightfully cheap that I want to come here all the time, because lets be frank here ....it is just bread.
author: stephanie c.

description: The focaccia here is TO DIE FOR!! You know it's the finest focaccia when it doesn't even need cheese or lots of other toppings to please your tastebuds! You'll mostly find one topping choices here like mushroom, raisin, olive, onion, or the most popular: pizza (which just has some tomato sauce and sliced scallions on top). The bread is soft and airy...it doesn't take a rocket scientist to figure out why Liguria sells out of focaccia before it hits afternoon! So although I (or my boyfriend) have to wake up early just to get here before all the goods are gone, Liguria is more than forgiven when I take that first bite of focaccia!
author: Caralisa L.

description:
When your focaccia is the best in the city, it sells itself.  
The focaccia is golden, perfectly crispy around the edges, with a good crumb, lightly chewy with large bubble holes attesting to the fully developed yeasty flavor.  I got the onion, which came studded with sweetly caramelized onion, brushed with olive oil and sprinkled with coarse grains of salty goodness.

They sell it in slabs for $5 but will cut it up for you if you ask, since you'll want to eat some right away.  In fact get one slab for later and one slab to munch on...

They have the traditional Italian line up:
plain
rosemary garlic
onion
pizza
olive

Plus the San Francisco influenced
jalapeno cheese
mushroom
raisin

The packaging is parchment paper and brown paper bags (Go Green!) 
The store front is plain and looks almost deserted from the outside.  The service is abrupt and may be influenced by the fact they got up early to start baking at 4 am... Plus the bakery has been around for 100 years and uses the same recipes and techniques.  So you know its the good stuff.

The lines in the morning can get a little crazy.  They stay open till 2pm (10 hour day for the ladies!) or whenever they sell out., whichever is earlier.  
Take away.  Cash only

Parking in North Beach sucks.
author: SatisFahYing A.

description:
hands down theeeeeee BEST foccacia bread! i ordered the pizza one and i sandwiched it with a mushroom one for a complete pizza! It was sooo good. the bread was incredibly soft and and delicious even into lunchtime. 

I didn't personally pick them up but i hear the elderly women isn't pleasant, but thank goodness she can make delicious bread! They usually run out by lunch time so definitely go early and it still tastes good all day!
author: Connie C.

description: Hands down best focaccia ever!!!  All options are great...my favorites are the raisin and the pizza.
author: Fatemah N.

description: "No foccacia for you..." That's the feeling you get when you enter here. The woman in line in front of me was afraid to change her order for fear they would yell at her to get out. Dont expect smiling faces here...old style family run...However, the foccicia here is wonderful!  So fresh.  so many great selections. It is made in the back room old fashioned bakery in huge slabs. The slabs are sent through to the front room through an opening to the sales room which is stark white with minimal shelving. Old style wrapping in paper and string. Sometimes there's a line out the door sometimes it's like there's no one else there. An absolute must if you are a foccacia lover. They last for days I take them home and on the road with me all the time yum!! CASH
author: Anthony A.

description:
I love everything about this place. The giant ovens in back. The salty folks behind the counter. The paper and string they use to wrap the bread.

There's something addictive in the fatty sheen over each slice of focaccia. You can't eat just one piece. The first bite? Yeah, it's good, you might think to yourself, but what's the big deal? Then another bite, and another. And soon you've eaten the entire slice. It's kind of magical. Faintly crispy on the outside. Just try it.

All the versions you'd expect to be good are good, but I'll give a special shout out to the raisin, which is great for breakfast, and the pizza, which has tomato sauce but no cheese and is surprisingly awesome.
author: Brian C.

description: This bakery is a North Beach institution.  They've been around for over 100 years and our family has been going here for as long as I can remember.  Luckily, my younger sister now lives about 3 blocks from this place because on a typical day, they will sell out by 2pm.   Liguria specializes in one thing, focaccia.  The dough is mixed in an antique machine and the bread is baked in a brick oven.  Slices of the different flavors are sold in 8x10in sheet and wrapped up in white paper tied with string.  This place is old school too.  No credit cards, no websites and like I said before, when they're sold out, they close down for the day.  Flavors range from pizza (tomato sauce topped with green onions), to rosemary garlic, plain green onion and a sweet raisin.  I am partial to the plainer versions because I love the taste of the bread itself and I think the tomato sauce can sometimes mask it.  I also love the soft fluffy texture of the bread and I always eat mine plain.  I wish I had some photos, but as usual, the bread went very quickly.
author: Katherine C.

description:
What a great throw back to yesteryear! They make one thing and they make it very well. More shops should do it Liguria Style!

I LOVE the pizza foccacia! Best around. 

Great toasted with some cheese too. Actually, Liguria....have you ever tried selling a foccacia with cheses?  Bet people would eat it up!

Well, our whole family loves what you do, so keep it up!  And when you don't feel like doing North Beach, you can usually buy the foccacia at Andronico's as an alternative. Yummmmm.
author: Karen L.

description:
Best foccacia bread hands down. Been coming here since elementary school days where I didn't care if I was late for school b/c my mom would get this for my lunch (they opened @ 8 and school started at the same time) 

*sigh* I'm drooling from the thoughts of it now..excuse me..
author: Jocelyn W.

description:
I've been coming to Liguria Bakery for years as has my family. This has got to be the best Focaccia I've ever had. I bought some for an Italian friend from Italy (from the region where Focaccia comes from)  and he said that it was the best he's had outside his country. I love the Pizza and the onion focaccia, the garlic not so much due to the huge chunks of garlic. The ladies crack me up every time. They're very stoic and somber but I love them. It's part of the appeal. At times they'll flat out ignore me while talking to each other or on the phone. I love it! I'll keep coming back for abuse........at least until they kick me out LOL.


*Update*

I go to Liguria's yesterday to get my Focaccia Pizza fix and sit on a bench at Washington Square and watch the Chinese old ladies do their dance routines. I go in there and it's packed on a Friday as usual and so I'm waiting in line to place my order when the lady in front of me tries to pay for her bread with a debit card XD  The look on the woman behind the counter's face was priceless! She goes,"It's cash only!" and rolls her eyes with an exasperated expression.LOL Man, I wished I videotaped that exchange. I laughed to myself and thought,"Yeah,get a clue lady!"   Frickin' newbies........

Yup, it's still the Liguria I love and the ladies are awesome! Unpretentious, what-you-see-is-what-you-get attitude. They rock!
author: Kolohe C.

description:
I was finally able to get some focaccia bread from here today! The line wasn't so bad, and 2 of my coworkers were already standing in line @ Mama's across the street, so I decided to stand in line here. Yes there is a line before 8am! Crazy, but at ;east it was wrapped around the block (as I had previously saw it.)

There is nothing fancy about this place at all. In fact the name on the store front window is all faded. I would have never guessed there was a focaccia bakery at all! The only thing they sell is focaccia bread. And there is one board that lists all the different types and prices. That's it, no frills and thrills about this place at all. Nothing spectacular about the service at all, just buy and go. 

I ended up getting the garlic focaccia - which you can get in a sheet, or ask them to cut it for you. I got it cut, and it comes out in 8 pieces. Very fresh and tasty! The focaccia bread prices range from $4-$5 dollars, and they do sell frozen for $3! Get here early tho, as soon as they sell out, they close the store!
author: Betty S.

description:
We stayed in the city for four days.  We picked up focaccia bread everyday we were here.  It is the best.  

Who needs service when you are in there only for 5 mins?  I think at the end of our fourth day, she recognized us and we both smiled.  I purchase 6 focaccias to take home.
author: Lori L.

description:
I stopped by at 12:30PM yesterday. Ohnoes..is it..? Yes, yes it was.. I peeked inside. The ladies instead were cleaning up and looked up at me. Silly rabbit, bread is all sold out!

When I told my coworkers, they looked at me like I was psychotic. Of course, they'd be sold out by then. My bad. I have no idea why I've never heard of Liguria, but, I'm not easily defeated. No, I will have my bread, and it WILL be tasty.

So, this morning, I made sure to stop by before work. I recruited another coworker I bumped into on the bus, and off we went. The lady was patient, even when we were indecisive. They can slice it up or wrap up a whole loaf, so we decided to share. I tried the pizza bread a few times before at work, so this time we ordered the green onion. OMG...a few nom noms, num yummies, and other various incoherent noises later, I've got two slices left. The green onion bread reminds me of the green onion pancakes. It had a slight crisp at the edges, not crunch, but just right. Deliciously seasoned to perfection... I hear the Raisin bread is really good (though I'm no fan of raisins). I like the Tomato and Green Onion and those are the only ones I've tried. They also have a new Jalapeno one, which I hear is decent too. I can't wait to try all the other flavors! 

Prices range about $4.00 - $4.50 for a loaf depending on the type. They also sell it frozen as well!

Liguria is focaccia carb heaven!!
author: Donna H.

description:
I've read the Yelp reviews about how this famous foccacia spot in North Beach closes whenever they sell out and how it tends to happen before their listed closing time of 2:00pm.

It took four visits to this place until I was able to catch it open around 11:30am, with fresh loaves of foccacia available for purchase.

Since I was a newbie, I asked the curly-haired woman behind the counter which was was her favorite. "I have no favorites," she said. However, she did point out that the pizza and onion are popular.

I went with the rosemary that was pretty salty (but not too much so) and left very satisfied that I finally got my hands on a loaf.
author: Valerie L.

description:
This was the ultimate holiday morning delivery.  So often, I've had overly greasy or too-soft focaccia, but Liguria Bakery's is just right - with a savory crust on top (I had the onion one) and a soft but still chewy center. 

I love how all they do is focaccia, so they do it well.
author: Marilyn T.

description: great faccacia and cash only! If you live in the neighborhood than you're lucky. If you don't live in the neighborhood then you are also not missing a lot.
author: Ricki H.

description: I love the Foccacia here.  I practically grew up in North Beach and in the summer i would always get lunch there. I've had each type of foccacia and i love each one.  the newest type is the cheese and jalapeño. Service is fast and very friendly! The bakery gives off a family atmosphere which I love. I suggest everyone to come and order the best focaccia in San Francisco!
author: Kevin L.

description: Been going here for the past 30 years, and my parents and grandparents have been going there before me they always called it "Sirocco's" which I think is the family name that runs it. I absolutely love this place. I remember the early trips here when I was just a kid getting all excited for a piece on the way home. They have added some new flavors over the past few years and they are all AWESOME!! I love the Garlic and Mushroom but you can't go wrong with the Tomato! They are only open until they sell out which doesn't take long so get there the earlier the better! $5 a sheet for any flavor Cash only.
author: John C.

description:
Plopped my salami (from Molinari deli, you sick bastards!) on my freshly cut pizza and sat in Washington Square Park.

Pure bliss.

Yeah, the grumpy, old, cantankerous lady still works there.  Give her a break, though, she came to the US by water.....she swam here from Genoa.

Ya feel me??
author: Johnny L.

description:
MMM, focaccia bread!  I've only had bread from this place twice, but I've been there probably 4 or 5 other times when they've been sold out and/or closed by the time I got there.  I even showed up once around 10am, and they were already out!

I had heard about "the place across the street from Mama's" so many times, but I had never been to Mama's before, so I never ventured into the bakery.  When I finally took the trip to Mama's, the line was probably an hour long, so I went across the street while my friend was in line.  I went into Liguria (I didn't see a name on the storefront, but I eventually found out the name of the place) and saw the simple menu of bread choices, ranging from $3 to $4.  With that price, I assumed they would be relatively small pieces of bread, so I ordered 4 of them, since four of us were waiting to eat.  Imagine my surprise when the nice woman at the counter handed me four huge slabs of focaccia bread!   It was so soft and chewy, with just the right amount of salt.  It ended up lasting about four or five days, and it was still good by the time I finished it.

I've had the plain, onion, pizza, garlic, and rosemary garlic.  The rosemary garlic and pizza ones were two of the best pieces of focaccia bread I've ever had, while the other ones weren't too shabby either.  

This place is highly recommended, but I would show up early, before they sell out.
author: Pilan C.

description:
I wouldn't call this the friendliest spot in North Beach, but they do sell some damn good focaccia. It's cash only and each piece of focaccia ranges from $4-5, but the pieces are large. Parking in the area can be difficult, but on weekday mornings empty spaces are plentiful.

The only problem is not binging on the focaccia... I'd recommend cutting a piece and having a friend hide the rest. (Friends don't let friends eat a 12"x10" slab of carbs)
author: Amanda C.

description:
This is one of those "The Departed" hole-in-the-wall-old-school corner bakeries. The lady was rather rough, but efficient. 

Take-aways: 
- You can't really eat there. 
- The most expensive ones are the pizza foccacia at $4.25. They offer to cut it up or just give to you on a big-ass slab. Choose the former. 

My ONLY peeve was that they gave me a cold one vs. a fresh one, but I'm not bitter. I oven toasted it a little and microwaved a few of the pieces, and it still tasted yummy.
author: Abel L.

description:
Their garlic focaccia is so good that even the vampires in their windowsill bask in the enticing smell lingering in the store. 
While you're waiting in line for Mama's, run across the street and grab a loaf. The wait time will fly by. It tastes amazing whether it's cold or warm. I'm gonna make me some tomato bisque tonight and use it as a dip. I can finish a whole loaf easily in one sitting. I don't even want to consider this as a carb!
author: Hana J.

description:
They don't need you and could care less so just shut up make your order and go out and enjoy. 

I got really lucky just before I got married and scored an apartment on Greenwich just around the corner from Liguria. Most thursdays for the years I lived there I would stop and buy panettone still warm from the oven, damn it was good but sadly they quit making it a long time ago. The focaccia on the other hand was, is and will remain forever delightful. Get up somewhat early on a saturday morning go around the corner pick up an onion and a pizza and take them home still warm from the oven and watch your wife and two young children devour them in a few minutes. One can feel like a real provider. 

They don't stay open late because they sell out so fast. It is a limited brick oven heated by this blast torch of a gas burner. They do not have to be nice because they don't need you to sell out so live with that. Don't go after noon and expect to have your choice of all the types. They are a family business their focus is the product. If you don't like that go elsewhere and get a lesser product from obsequious minions. 

Go to Liguria if you want the best focaccia I have ever tasted.
author: John H.

description: I used to go to this bakery when i was married years ago. It is the best ever focaccia bread you will ever eat. Call ahead and order your breads cause when they run out you're out of luck. I love the Pizza and only the best. I wish I could give em 10 stars but 5 will have to do.
author: Nancy W.

description:
If they sell out, they WILL close for the day. For an well established place like Liguria, I don't think you would really judge them on their service. But I will say, it is not friendly. The ladies that work there aren't mean people, they are just a bit intimidating. They will not smile and welcome you with loving arms. But if you want amazing foccacia, deal with it!

The foccacia here is amazing, nice and buttery and not too thick. My favorites would be the garlic and jalapeño cheese. But if you are not there early enough in the day, you'll have to deal with what is left. The prices have gone up over the years but it's not too bad. They also sell frozen foccacia that you can store in your freezer and heat up yourself at home that is still delicious. 

I am drooling just thinking about it...
author: Angela T.

description:
I hate mushrooms, don't really care for focaccia bread being usually too dry for my liking....but, the mushroom focaccia bread here is to die for! I think each loaf (or sheet) is around $4. Its super moist and perfect for a quick and easy appetizer if you're entertaining.

This is, by far, my favorite little find in the city. Yes, I traveled out of the Marina....can you believe it? It MUST be good then!
author: Meredith M.

description:
I remember my dad coming home with this white bundle when i just kid. 
When he unwrapped this bundle i remember smell pizza foccacia  and 
taste was delicious. Now it my turn to bring this bundle of joy to my parents. My only advice get there early. They will sell out fast.
author: k j.

description: MAMA! ...oo oo ooooooooo.  Bless you for bringing this little North Beach culinary delight into our lives at a young age.  When she had a day off and could beat the sold out sign, we would get this as a treat.  Only like the tomato foccacia and only when its fresh.  Few days down the road doesn't really cut it, as the sauce dries up when you bake it.  I did precariously put the pieces on top of the toaster to maintain the wet saucy top and bring out the crispy bottom when I could not bear to give up on the days old bread... Not bad, if I do say so myself.
author: Tony And Candace T.

description: One of my favorite things to do upon waking Saturday morning is to head on down to Liguria Bakery, arrive by the time they open the door. I only double parked once in over 30 years. Only had plain and pizza back then. Ficcocia is the only thing they make, and its so good, they get orders to air frieght across the country.  They sell them packaged in supermarkets now, but you must get it right out of the oven, eat immediately, and you will know why this is the rave of San Francisco.
author: Michael A.

description:
This is hands down the absolute best homemade foccacio you will ever enjoy. Come to North Beach, walk over to the Bakery, order a fresh pizza foccacia and the scallion/olive oil foccacia, have them slice it all up and put it in a little brown paper bags and walk over to Washington Square Park, sit down on a bench and eat it. Bring lots of napkins, the pizza foccacio drips with delicious olive oil. And bring some water. 
Just being inside this Italian place is an experience......sparse, white-washed, just the facts. When I used to live in the neighborhood, a sheet was $2.00......two dollars. I think it's a little over $4.00 now. Can't beat it and everything spells A.U.T.H.E.N.T.I.C.I.T.Y.   What a heart-warming deal. They sell-out quickly so get there early.
author: fused g.

description:
Tried foccacia bread... the raisin one... 
mmm oily is dripping down your side of your mouth... the taste of garlic powder mix with raisin.. did not go well... I'm sure the garlic stuff would be better by itself.. not mix with sweet....
author: Monika T.

description: Awesome foccacia bread. I had the pizza flavor and ate it as a snack driving back down to LA. Still fresh with the green onions and everything! I give them a three though because their customer service wasn't the nicest. I guess they can afford that since they sell out everyday! But I always believed that being gracious was very important in a business
author: Sherry T.

description:
