This place has the BEST focaccia I have ever tasted! My father used to buy copious amounts of the plain and pizza versions of their focaccia and we would hoover it down like there was no tomorrow. On a recent trip back to the bay area I made sure I stopped by so I could grab a yummy piece of nostalgia. 

Get there early and bring cash with you. The store name is gone so make sure you keep your eyes peeled when looking for this store. Also...you might want to call before you go to make sure they are open. I believe the close for a month or so during the summer when their whole family takes a vacation.
author: Shari d.

description: Still just as good as my childhood memory serves.  At $5 per sheet, the pizza flavor is still and will always be my fave.  I also tried the jalapeno & cheese for the first time and that was ok.  Fortunately I didn't have to wait in line on a Saturday :)  I'm in hearts all over again...sigh.
author: Meredith K.

description:
Focaccia Bread with some Anger on the side

I wish this was a review of the focaccia bread I hoped to enjoy on my visit but alas, the bread never happened.  After visiting once before and enjoying I returned on the 5th of February.  When I entered there was an older woman behind the counter.   When I received neither eye contact nor a greeting I didn't panic.  I'm originally from New York City where indifference accompanies most transactions.
I ordered the rosemary and garlic and requested 4 quarters for my expired parking meter.
Her response, "If you want quarters go to a bank."
I paused for a moment, swallowing hard and thinking that perhaps I was misunderstood.  
I repeated my request, being especially clear that I wanted to purchase Focaccia, that my car was just outside the door and that I wanted to feed the meter to avoid an expensive ticket.
The response, "if you want quarters go to a bank."
I then attempted to go the creative route and I got very specific asking if in my change she might be kind enough (I mean this literally as I asked "if you would be kind enough") to give me 4 quarters.
The response, "you didn't hear me the first time?  If you want change go to a bank."

I'm a reasonable man.  I understand that Liguria is not a bank and has no obligation to give a customer change or even to be nice.   However, I was at a loss to understand the contempt.  

Our exchange ended as I told her she was a real charmer.  She told me to "get lost."

I realize that the Focaccia is good.  Heck, I enjoyed it the first time which is why I  returned in the first place.  But at over $5 for a piece of bread who needs the abuse?  It's clear to me that business has gotten so good over there that they have adopted the puzzling "we don't need your business attitude." 

I ask you Yelp readers.... with all of the great food and grateful restaurateurs serving us in the bay area why would anyone give business to a place that is not only unfriendly, but also contemptuous of its customers?  


Your wish has been granted Liguria......No Focaccia for me!!!
author: evan b.

description:
Yelp pointed me in the direction of this amazing bakery. Thank you Yelp!

I stopped by yesterday before coming home to LA, and I must say I'm willing to drive back to SF just for some more bread! This place is awesome.

I got the green onion, and pizza bread. Both of which are delicious!

I wish I had bought more bread, but I hesistated, and now I'm kicking myself in the rear for it.

If anyone from the LA area is going to be going up to SF, will you please bring me back some Foccacia from Liguria's? I will gladly pay you! Haha.
author: Khristine S.

description:
This is short of heaven.  A hot piece of Pizza Foccacia - that's it - heaven!!
This is a food that you will dream about!  I AM NOT KIDDING!  This would have gotten a 10-star rating if possible.  parking tough - get somone to ride shotgun and send them in while you double park and hope for the best!
author: Julie B.

description:
Oh my lord!  This is some darn amazing foccacia or as I call it, FO-KA-CHIA!  I found this place as I was waiting in the neverending Mama's line.  I walked across the street to make a phone call and noticed a small line outside of this store.  I decided to go in and check it out since I had at least another hour of waiting at Mama's.  Inside is completely bare bones.  An old Italian lady behind a counter and a single sign listing 10 types of focaccia.  You just tell her what kind you want and she goes in the back to get it.  Very old school packaging as well.  The foccacia is stacked and wrapped in wax paper and then tied shut with string.  

The best part is when you get to eat it!  Absolutely amazing!  The best foccacia I've ever had.  I've tried the pizza, jalapeo no and cheese and rosemary foccacias but my favorite is the pizza.  I even went as far as to go back to buy several slabs (each is about 12x10in) and hosting a pizza party with it.  Just get some nice mozzarella and some toppings and people can make their own personal pizzas.  

Also don't forget that they close as soon as they sell out so either call in early to put in an order or else make sure to get there before noon.  Also, if you aren't going to eat the bread within that day, you might as well get their frozen ones because instead of the regular ($4-5) they are only $3 each.  If they have leftovers from their daily production, they freeze them.
author: Susan L.

description: Delicious focaccia that comes in different "flavors" and in a huge square (that can be cut into many strips for you). Cash only though, and very basic/slightly grumpy customer service.
author: Melody L.

description:
LOVE their focaccia. Go in the morning when it's just coming out of the oven and have them cut it up for you...you will not be able to stop eating until it's gone so make sure you buy enough that you'll have some by the time you get home. Talk about a San Francisco treat!!! This stuff is the absolute best.

Liguria has been around for years and the quality does not deviate...never disappoints.
author: Dee Z.

description: They were sold out of everything but the pizza focaccia bread, but that's okay because it was absolutely delicious!!!! I can't wait to go back and try the other kinds.
author: Cary Elizabeth L.

description:
This focaccia was synonymous with Sunday mornings in my house growing up. Come morning I'd hear my dad coming home and rush out of bed to enjoy the delicious spoils, focaccia and farmers market fruit. As I got older there was less rushing, because hey, it was already in the house, it's not like I wont be able to hunt down who stole the last piece and demand justice if it comes down to it. But the deliciousness never changed, now that I live mostly in Santa Cruz I have dreams of this focaccia, and have decided to go on a focaccia hunger strike because nothing will ever EVER compare to how great this bread is. 

I grew up in the city, yet North beach has always been a sort of bermudas triangle to me, once I'm in I have no idea where I am and how to get out again. But I brave these perilous sees with only two purposes, one being  obligatory concerts at Bimbos (I've found the land easier to navigate with the help of the stars, or night fog in most cases) and desperate attempts to claim my focaccia.

I seriously have no words to describe how delicious it is. It is moist and delectable, basically, the stuff dreams are made of. If you have never had the pleasure of trying this bread, drag yourself over to north beach in the morning (early as possible) and snag yourself some dough, you WILL NOT regret it.
author: Allyson S.

description: On a tip from their neighbor, we bought a piece of garlic focaccia. So sad the were closed the following day. Will make the trek to Liguria next time we are in town.  Best focaccia ever!!
author: D D.

description:
The soup nazi of bakeries.  

They can close any time they want,  treat you any way they want, you will still line up. 
They are the testimony to the virtue of doing just one thing and doing it right.  So have your order and your money ready and stop whining, no one is going to nurture you once you made it to the counter, unless you grew up in North Beach, in which case it's gossip city, and everyone behind you can wait.  The family who runs the place is so over running the most successful focaccia place in history of humanity, yet they cannot stop--I cannot believe no one has done a reality show yet.

Usually one has to pay up to get the truly the best in any category, this is a notable exception.  

Plus they wrap it up in paper with string just like in the old country, it's really a piece of art inside and out.  Really, no point of endorsing them.

Always check first if they are open, since if you got a day off, they are probably closed.
author: Lucy Z.

description:
Right at the moment, I am in Skokie, IL. I ate dinner at a really good Italian restaurant here called Maggiano's. While there, I was telling my dinner companion about Liguria Bakery in SF. BEST foccacia I've ever tasted and the best anyone I've ever treated to the place has tasted. I try to get there anytime I visit SF from my Sacramento home. 
Unless hints have changed, the family vacations in August and the place shuts down. Call first if you go near that time of year.   Get there early and watch the local residents do their morning tai chi in Washington Square Park across the street. Then hang out in North Beach while you're there. 
Enjoy!
author: Rick S.

description: I spent a few hours in North Beach with my mom because we wanted to relive her Italian family's history (specifically on Stockton St). Her family immigrated in the early 1900s and bought a market right down the street from Liguria (the Napoli Market). Being that she was raised in SF as a child, we both thought it would be fun to go back to the authentic establishments that she remembered as a child. Liguria has AMAZING focaccia bread. We ordered the pizza, olive, onion, and rosemary garlic. All of these were so delicious! My favorite was the rosemary garlic because the garlic was roasted before baking with the bread so the flavor was out of this world. The fresh focaccia is just amazing and so fragrant, and I can't wait to get more! They do sell out quickly so you have to come in early to get the best choices.
author: Sheeva G.

description: I absolutely LOVEEEEEEEE the pizza focaccia here and its only $5!! It was so good I'm almost feel guilty eating all of it within 2 days .. yes I said almost! I have to go back and get some more soon .. I've been craving it ever since. Best $5 I've spent in a while. You won't regret it!
author: Jen P.

description:
This is one of the reasons why I love living in North Beach.  Right across the street  from mama's is this little mom and pop bakery called Liguria Bakery.  THEY MAKE THE BEST FOCCACIA BREAD.  They always sell out quick so once they sell out they close up.  Meaning.............they close early all the time.  Been going here for over 30 years.

pizza
onion
plain
garlic

You can't go wrong with any of those choices.  

As a neighbor and a side note aside from the bread... they always have the nicest window displays during the major hoidays.  I don't know why I just wrote that but it's true.
author: jason g.

description: While in my nostalgic mood, this place came to mind.  A small corner store that hasn't changed in the last thirty years, this bakery defines "hidden gem".  While the lines are usually long across the street for breakfast at Mama's, I learned that they can get as long here during Thanksgiving or Christmas.  After all, where else can you get fresh baked foccacia?!  You cannot go wrong with anything here as there are several variations.  Today, I picked up two pizza (gift for friend), one mushroom (gift for co-worker), and one each of pizza and mushroom "cut"... this means that they cut the sheets into small edible slices that you can munch on in your car or office desk.  Wait a second, why is my bag empty?  The pizza reminds me of the pizza slices at Woolworth's on Powell and Market, now the Gap store, with plenty of tomato sauce and sliced green onions.  Sigh... memories.  I heard rumors that they supplied Mario's Bohemian Cigar Store for their famed sandwiches, but later learned that they have several suppliers besides Liguria.  The pizza was $4.25 each cut or uncut and the mushroom was $4.50.  Definitely worth the stomach space and memories of the old days.
author: Mike C.

description:
Liguria's green onion focaccia. 
Oh.My.God. 

It's so good. I have a colleague who lives in North Beach, and about once a month (sometimes more, when we luck out!) he stops at Liguria on his way into work. He brings a sheet of the green onion focaccia and everyone swarms around it 'til it's devoured. I think it is actually one of the very best things I've ever had. 

Giant Super Yum.

Can't wait to go in person myself and try some of the other varieties.
author: Kandy P.

description: The best focaccia bread. Great family run business and my favorite place in North Beach. Go early for the best selection!  They sell out by early afternoon.
author: Karla R.

description:
When I saw the mammoth line sprawling for blocks for brunch outside mama's on Washington square- I decided there were many things I'd rather do on this particular Sunday morning then wait in line for breakfast food. I've done it too many times for the sake of eggs. I'm over it.

So I walked across the street and got a homemade foccacia from Liguria. And found a nice patch of grass in the park to enjoy it.

I recommend. This place seems like it's been there forever and has some of that "true Italian" North beach charm.  They just sell foccacia in various forms (raisin, garlic, rosemary, etc) and its delicious in that pure and simple way.
author: Liz S.

description:
Fond memories of coming into this bakery early in the morning to pick up the foccacia for our company.The smell drives me crazy and theirs is the best on the west coast.
Family business is just that, and they excel at it for years.
John Wolfe
author: John W.

description:
Wow, what an unexpected surprise! I love a business that does only one thing, and does it well. In this case, it's foccacia bread. 

I was there a little before noon and they were out of a few flavors. I opted for the green onion and was greeted with oily, salty, oniony yuminess. 

They wrap the breads in white butcher paper with string. Very old school and charming.
author: Lee H.

description:
I literally stumbled into this bakery in between going from point A to point B. I was hungry and didn't get a chance to eat breakfast or lunch. I smelled the aroma of freshly baked bread/pastries and initially thought it was from a restaurant named Mama's (across the street). I went into Mama's and while there was a crowd, I realized quickly that I was at the wrong place. By the time I walked across the street, the scent of fresh bread lingered and I realized that it was inside a somewhat dimly lit bakery.  The storefront is a bit drab, but what an amazing world inside.

I was so hungry that I wanted something quickly. I looked at the list of breads baked (around $4.25 for the loaf) and asked for the raisin bread. I got the raisin foccacia "sticks" for $3 and got a total six pieces. Amazing stuff. Store worker said it was the last set of raisin ones for the day and it was around 1pm.

I ate one while walking and I was amazed at how tasty it was. In fact, shockingly fresh and totally awesome. The store takes cash only and has a truly "local" and Italian feel to it. It reminds me of why the tag line, "truly San Francisco" and with that a truly North Beach experience.

Great price and awesome bakery! Truly 1 of a kind!
author: Tina C.

description:
A friend told me about this place that I would never recogonize otherwise.  In no way does this place look like a bakery! They have decorations on the outside and empty shelves on the inside.  You walk in and have NO IDEA what they sell except for a tiny vague menu.  

Ive had the onion, garlic and pizza foccaccia bread and totally love the pizza bread! It's so good and fresh! I hate walking over there and having the bread run out, which isn't uncommon.  The plain breads are great on the side of pastas or other entrees, and the pizza is just delicioso itself. For under $5 you've gotta atleast try it once :)
author: Shafaq C.

description:
Best focaccia ever, even raisin, mmmmm!

Only to go and get there early before they run out , no mmmmm!
author: Aaron I.

description: I have been eating their foccacia bread for YEARS, I mean like 25! My family has a tradition on Xmas Eve morning of standing in line for hours (i.e. 3-4) for this bread and it's worth it! love love LOVE it! the pizza is my fave!
author: Melody T.

description:
There are many reasons why i just couldn't leave SF to Hawaii like my brothers did in my youth...and well, what weighed the most heavily is not being able to have my freshly baked focaccia.  I have been raised on Ligurias since elementary school days in Brisbane and the excitement i get from devouring some pizza, raisin, onion, or garlic  focaccia from here is still shiny and new (a 'la Madonna).

I don't care how mean and nazi-ish people feel the Liguria family are cause i love them anyhow.  There really is no other place where i eat focaccia except here.  I don't even eat focaccia period unless i know it is from here cause i don't wanna put myself through the disapointment.  

You will love this place, it is just so magical how the Liguria family still keep their traditions of making a certain amount everyday and close(usually b4 noon)when they are all out.  As Jason said b4 me, be sure to ask for what amount of sheets u want sliced when ordering and recommend not to ask 4 too much cuz u are already lucky enough to experience these tasties.
author: omar b.

description: Reminds me of my mom's focaccia. SIL brought us the garlic one, and onion focaccia. Delicious! Simple with just the right amount of saltiness and flavor. Nice and crispy when toasted up. Made sandwiches and so good!
author: Trish B.

description:
$4 for their pizza focaccia is still a steal!  Nothing like the fresh taste of focaccia straight from the oven (racks).  Worth the drive from anywhere in the City to get it fresh.

PS...lay off the salt please.
author: JeFF T.

description: Before there was pizza, there was focaccia. A naked pizza made from melt-in-your-mouth bread and a minimum of topping. Sometimes just olive oil and salt. I would venture to say that the Liguria Bakery is one of the few places in the entire world outside Liguria, Italy you can get this perfect focaccia.  The Liguria Bakery is unique as they essentially sell nothing else. Naturally, they close when they run out. So, get there before noon.
author: Gasper S.

description:
Alright, alright, YES! I agree with all of you! It's the best! What a treat. I actually discovered this place through an Italian friend of ours who woke up at 5:30 am Christmas eve to rush over this place so he doesn't run out of focaccia! 

The two Italian women behind the counter don't mess around. Don't ask them any questions or they'll eat you alive! When I was ordering, the phone rang and the lady with the big hair yelled, "OH SHIT!!!!" Hahahaha! I have no idea why I even commented, "I've heard so much things about your focaccia!" They didn't even glance, but I still love 'em!
author: Lauren R.

description:
It's two (2) blocks away from my apartment... I really should be going here more often!  Why don't I?  I dunno!

If you want freshly baked focaccia, this is the place to go.  They open 8am everyday, but hurry because once they run out, they close their doors.  The times I've gotten a sheet of rosemary-garlic, I was very pleased -- it was soft and filled with flavor!  Soooooo good!

Even though you only have a few choices of the kinds of focaccia bread, it's a very hard decision to make. There's plain, pizza, rosemary, garlic, rosemary-garlic, olives, and a couple others.  You have the option of getting your focaccia sliced and/or wrapped to-go!  

Go here!  Why?  Because I said so :-)!
author: Celeste M.

description: We have been coming here for 45 plus years and they have the best focaccia hand down.    Anytime we are in town we make sure to stop in and get some.   If you arrive after 11:00 chances are there are slim pickings especially during holidays. Cash only
author: Grace F.

description:
I have been coming here since I was a fetus. Hopefully that gives some credibility and credence to this review.

What else is there to say? If you have not been to Liguria to sample their wonderful planks of foccacia bread. Get moving! What you will find here is a few options on this wonderful bread. My favorite are mushroom and the rosemary and garlic ones. Of course you have to get here early to get those. Otherwise your stuck with the ugly sister foccacia options. By early that means 9 am on a weekend. So no sleeping in. Parking is a piece of cake around the square around 7 or 8 am. I mean people are stupidly waiting in line at Mama's at that hour. 

Bring cash only. You are not going to get congenial customer service here, count yourself lucky if you get a smile or even a "Hi" back from the old lady behind the bar. I mean that in the nicest way of course. Squares run around $3.50. Order a few since it will only last you through the afternoon. Experience carbohydrate bliss.
author: Ryan G.

description:
THE BEST foccacia...my nonni approved!  My family's been buying foccacia from Liguria for as long as I can remember.  Like others have said, you gotta go early b/c they close when they run out / around mid day.  My favorites are the raisin, pizza and onion.  They'll pre-slice it for you as well if you like.  If you're a regular, you may even get a smile from the nonna or the younger woman working there.  Otherwise, it's all business and the best quality foccacia around.  So soft and flavorful and just a little chewy as it should be.  

Insider tip:  I believe Mario's Bohemian Cigar Store down the block uses Liguria for their amazing sandwiches.
author: Jeff H.

description:
High Quality Foccacia Bread.  This place reminds me of "Old Italy"...  The storefront could be from a scene in Godfather 2.  A place Vito Corleone himself might frequent or even own...   

I was always used to the Foccacia bread you picked up at your neighborhood grocery market as a kid but this doesn't compare to those.  

The hours they post say they are open until 2pm but they will probably often close earlier because as many have mentioned, once they sell out, that's it for the day folks...  

So advice is to go early to first guarantee yourself some foccacia bread, and number 2, it will also ensure you get the freshest batch possible....
author: Mark W.

description:
I've been lucky enough to have sampled some of the foccacia from Liguria, but today was the first time I've actually had the time or inclination to come by the store and actually pick up some slabs of fresh foccacia.  The storefront is surprisingly void of any sign that this place sells some of the best foccacia I've ever had- the shelves are bare and empty.

In any case, I decided to get the pizza and the mushroom out of the list of about 7 varieties.  I was there at 11:30 am and the garlic was already sold-out- I guess I have to endeavor to get there even earlier to make sure everything is still in stock.  They did have the rosemary garlic on hand so I ordered that as well.  I'm glad I did because the rosemary garlic was my favorite of the three.  The rosemary smelled great while the garlic was fantastic and carmelized, though not particularly good for your breath.  Mushroom was a close second and my least favorite was the pizza- I thought the tomato sauce was a little too sweet.  Overall though, Liguria bakes some kick-ass foccacia- great toppings, with perfect texture, and a crisp bottom.  

My only complaint- it can be a little oily with a little too much salt sprinkled on top, but that's minor.  4.5 stars rounded up to 5 and I'll most definitely be back.  Remember its cash only and don't be surprised if you've finished your sliced foccacia within a block of the bakery- its that good!
author: Angela H.

description:
Panetoni breads,dinner rolls, donuts, pies - no longer are made there,  but their ever famous focaccia is still baking.  Your best bet is to call your order in on the day you pick them up.  My favs are the plain, onion, and pizza.  (they have expanded their pizza menu to garlic, rosemary too).  Price ranges from: $3.50 -$4.00.  Frozen foccacia are $2.50 each. I'm not sure but you can check.  Around Easter, they use to do special orders of hot cross buns and panetoni (also around Christmas).  They are closed when they run out of fresh focaccia---sometimes before 2;00 p.m.  Bona appetita.

Update:  Liguria Bakery has added new items:  Mushroom pizza, Rosemary Garlic pizza, and Black Olives - $4.00 each.
author: Marian G.

description:
I reAlly don't know what All the hype is about this place. So after reading the reviews about this place & having heard mentioned many a times, I decided to journey out on Muni to this place, waited in line for 40 min and bought a couple loaves of foccacia. 
Now raisin foccicia really isn't all that great. There was an over abundance of raisins and barely any dough. I pretty much felt like there was a handful of raisins and olive oil in my mouth.
I Also tried the onion foccacia, & I'm still not impressed. Too plain.

I say save yourself the effort & time cuz it's really not worth it.
I've had better round here.
author: Viv D.

description:
I was raised in North Beach, and I have very fond memories of this place.  I remember when they sold other baked items such as biscotti and bread along with their focaccia.

My favorites are the tomato and the green onion.  Cannot wait to take a bite into one after a buying a few slabs.  Focaccia from the other local bakers in the Bay Area are decent, but in my opinion, Liguria sets the standard.  Their focaccia has a nice soft top, but the bottom has a little bit of crustiness to give it that pleasant crunch.  The tomato, mixed with green onions, is absorbed deep enough for a complete taste.

It's difficult to find parking around Washington Square, but this focaccia is worth it.

Note: If you have any leftovers (hard to believe), you can freeze it.  When you're ready to eat it again, take it out and stick it in a toaster oven.
author: Steve L.

description:
Calling all you carb lovers!!!  Liguria has the best damn focaccia.  The crust is always a beautiful golden color, brushed with olive oil, and the bread itself is so amazingly soft.  The smell will make your knees weak and excite the taste buds!  I've had the pleasure of trying several flavors, all of which are excellent!  

My favorite is with the tomato sauce and green onions - best tasting ever!  The sauce has the perfect amount of acidity and sweetness!  

In second is the mushroom - perfect for anyone who enjoys eating fungi.  I love that they don't skimp on ingredients, as the top is completely covered with thin slices of button mushrooms!  yummy!  

Other flavors highly recommened are green onion, and garlic.  Just make sure you have several sticks of gum if you're gonna indulge yourself with the garlic - it's diced and toasted to perfection!

The focaccia is sold in sheets that are approximately 12" x 9".  Follow the advice of other yelpers and COME EARLY - you'll get the best selection!  Otherwise, you just may leave empty handed as they usually sell out pretty quickly.
author: Cynthia H.

description: Hello Focaccia lovers.  If you find yourself in North Beach you must try Liguria Bakery  fociacca.  They make about  ten different kinds.  It's a family business so you can interact with the people who make it.  Some days Grandma seems a bit on the grumpy side but don't let that put you off.  You won't be dissapointed.
author: Jim B.

description: Love the focaccia bread.  Onion, garlic, plain, or mushroom.  I still have to try their pizza-flavored bread.  Not the warmest people at the cashier but who cares when the bread is this good.  Perfect for an afternoon snack.
author: John H.

description:
I love this place!  It brings back old childhood memories of eating pizza-style foccacia bread.  It has been decades since I've had them and the only place I remembered selling them was at the Alemany Farmer's Market.  Unfortunately, on latest trip, I could not find the stand.  

Recently, someone told me about Liguria and their foccaccia bread.  I never heard of this place...so I ventured over there around 1pm...and they're sold out!!! Boo!  A week later, I show up around 8:30am.  To my surprise, there was a line outside the door!  Eek!  People have raved about the raisin bread, so I decided to give it a try on top of the pizza.  The pizza foccacia brought back those same memories...mmm...good!  Could it be the same company who sells their goods at Farmer's Market???  Either way, I was happy.  

On the other hand, the raisin bread was ok.  Not a big fan.  Gotta go back to try other flavors.  And defn arrive when they open!!!
author: Lisa W.

description:
This place is off the charts for authentic focaccia breads- tomatoe/ green onion is my fav.  this is a long standing establishment that i still believe is family owned. kinda like the KFC or COCA COLA  secret receipt thing.  i grew up here when their sheets would sell for 50cents.  

prices are up but so what --still great.  i think many of the old traditional Italians would be proud of this place. oily good-olive oil/tomatoe paste

the secret is in the crust no matter which item use choose.  they have saute onion, a sweet raisin, etc.. the items sell out usually within 3-4hrs so get there early or call in to see if they can hold you a few sheets.

i've come 2-3hrs after and my fav was sold out.  try to finish it the same day as next day is different.
author: Dan W.

description: I dream about this focaccia. If all you do in San Francisco is eat sheets of this bread, your trip will be worthwhile. Go early and get the pizza kind.
author: Elise S.

description:
I've been grubbing on this focaccia since I was a kid!  It all started when my grandparents immigrated to SF and settled in North Beach...grandma started buying it, then mom was buying it and now I'm buying it!  They only make one thing and they make it perfect!  

5 stars for the quality, quantity and the price - no places beats Liguiria!

1 star for the extremely slow service, lack of smile and customer service, and the worst part of all...handling money and food back and forth without gloves and without washing in between...

But the focaccia is so freakin out of this world good, I try not to think about how insanitary it is...
author: Tina L.

description: Pretty amazing focaccia! Old lady is pretty rude haha. They sell out pretty fast so get there early!
author: H N.

description:
GET THERE EARLY!

When I got there, they had two varieties left. I went with the pizza... still freaking delicious but for the price/portion, I wondered if I was better off getting actual pizza from a local establishment. Still some damn good focaccia, but remember to get there early if you want to be able to try some of the other varieties!
author: Tyrone B.

description:
I just want to confirm that they deserve the 5 stars.  Got there around 11am today and they were all out except pizza and raisin.  I decided to just get the raisin and the lady asked if I wanted it whole or cut?  I was puzzled - cut?  As in cut into slices?  She said yes, we will cut into 8 slices?  YES, please do!  In a few minutes, she came out with a little brown bag with 8 equal sized strips of goodness...it was still warm too!

I ran back to the car where my hubby was waiting and said he was in luck!  Before the car can take off, I already have a strip out and took a bite!  What a way to start a morning and our drive down south, delicious!
author: Gloria H.

description: This place is damn good. I may or may not have bought a Rosemary Garlic Foccacia, walked across the street to Washington Square Park, sat on a bench and eaten the whole slab. May or May not. I'm not going to lie, it happened and I'm not proud of it, but that doesn't mean it won't happen again.
author: Rhiana M.

description:
Definitely one of my weekend luxuries.  This is one of the best family owned businesses in the city.  

Yes, it's for the morning crowd.  Once everything is sold out, they shut the doors.  Plain and simple.

Getting the frozen focaccia is great for bringing the special treat home for a late night snack!  And, a bargain.
author: Nadine J.

description:
Holy heavenly foccacia!!!

This place sure does make some delicious flat oven baked breads!!  We got there at 10:30 am and they'd already sold out of most their bread.

"One garlic please" says we

"NO" with an uncomfortable pause.  "I'm out of garlic" says the grouchy old Italian woman behind the counter.

"Ok...well one onion please" we said

"Out of the onion." she snapped.

"Well which ones do you still have?"

I swear she would have lets us rattle off the whole list instead of just telling us which ones she had left.  We ended up with one Pizza and one mushroom breads...and let me tell you they were so great!!  I could have eaten a million pieces...if they weren't  so incredibly filling.  SOOOOO good.  And they don't lose a star for the grouchy woman, she's pretty much necessary.
author: desiree n.

description: They've been in business for 100 years, since 1901....need I say more?  Another of San Francisco's hidden jewels!  But you better get there early because they sell out of everything, and once you've tried their focaccia bread you're hooked.
author: Honeya O.

description: Wow, really worth it for $4!  My two girl friends and I shared one pizza focaccia bread and nibbled on it for breakfast for 3 days straight.  Each loaf can be cut into 8 rectangular slices, and they taste even better after heated up in a toaster oven.  The dough remains soft and airy, and the crust just a little crunchy.  Don't be alarmed when you first walk in and don't see any bread in the cases; they store it all in the back where the bakery is.
author: Nancy Y.

description:
I don't know how many times I've walked pass that place without knowing that store. From the outside it looks pale, I thought it was a tailor store or something.... not until one day my friend who lives close-by told me it's a really good bakery, thus I walked in with skeptical mind....
and OMG! I was totally shocked.... from looking at it you can't really tell the difference among the others...but once you bite on it.... you are hooked!!!  You can say I learned this word "FOCACCIA" from that store, and has become my standard of the focaccia whenever I come across one....

Pro: They are really delicious and isn't that expensive, whenever I visit the city I will for sure get some on my way there (not on the way back cuz they sells out early and closes early)

Con: 1. Most of the Five-Star store I visit somehow has this attitude, that they sometimes doesn't really care if you want to buy it or not cuz they know it will sell out anyways... 
2. They sells out very fast, and closes too early.
author: Jake H.

description:
The service here sucks. Have you ever seen the episode of Seinfeld where the gang goes to the soup place. There they find the "soup nazi". You aren't supposed to talk to the person behind the counter or he will tell you no soup for today and give you back your money and tell you to get out? Well this place is definitely that with focaccia bread. I walked up with my friend and I was a little scared because we didn't get a greeting when we walked through the door. There's a woman standing there behind the counter with a scoul on her face. Perhaps one from focaccia slabs that burned in the oven, or perhaps a jilted lover who hated her focaccia. The woman now turns her attention to me and I'm stumped as I give my friend some money and push her to order. She orders and the woman disappears to the back and we hear some rustling around. The woman then yells from the back do you want it cut and we hurridly say no. She then reappears with these focaccia  squares that are wrapped in paper and bundled up and ready to go for us. She barks out the total and we pay and get out of there.

Quite easily and simply the best focaccia ever known to man. When taking it from the slab it instantly melts in your mouth and you are transported in time to a simpler time. A time when ingredients matter. I never knew that so many different flavours could come from a piece of bread.

Will always recommend this place to anyone who stops in city. You must get there early because when they sell out for the day they pack up and go home. Cash only
author: ryan n.

description:
My first experience of this heavenly bread was two years ago. My fiance and I waited 3 hours on the eve of Christmas so we could buy some foccacia bread for our party. First, I was hesitant to wait in such a ridiculously long line, but then again, I figure there must be a reason why so many people are here. So finally we got our bread...and WOW, let me just say it was so worth the wait! The bread was soft and moist. Favorite of all time for us is the pizza, but the garlic and onion comes close behind. 

I tried the jalapeno cheese was ok, spicy like how I like it, but a little dry. I still love the pizza and garlic better.

Go early because once they sell out, they won't make more. We tried going at 11 on a Sunday and they were already closed. 

If we lived in that neighborhood, we would be going there every week!
author: Jenny T.

description:
If you're looking for great foccacia, this is the place to come.  Honestly, the only one I've had often enough to talk about is their tomato and green onion foccacia.  It is absolutely the best anywhere.  I've tried foccacia from other bakeries and they are so far inferior it isn't funny.  This is one of those places that has no real set hours even though it's stated on their door.  When the foccacia runs out, and it often does, the doors get locked.  I drive up from Foster City to get this stuff.  Talk about addiction, one can easily get addicted to this stuff.  As much as I hate to freeze food, this stuff freezes great if wrapped properly.  I don't know if you've discovered this, but it seems that the fresher baked goods are when they are frozen, the fresher they'll be upon defrosting.  Other bakeries don't seem to put enough sauce or olive oil on their tomato focaccias.  

This place has been in business since the early 1900's.  My father use to buy this regularly when we lived in Northbeach.  The only negative about this place is the scarcity of parking.  The same can be said of any neighborhood in San Francisco where the shops are located.  This place is located at Filbert and Stockton catty corner from Washington Square park.  Once you've had this foccacia, no other will suffice.
author: geoff k.

description: This place is hands down the best foccacia in the bay if not the west coast. I have been to Italy on many occasions and only they can hold a candle to these old schoolers. Be here early or call and reserve what you want, yes you can do it. It is hard to park. I think they only take cash. They do sell frozen if that is what you want. They sell out of many of the daily made products, but you can get frozen... They also slice them if you want a snack. I usually get garlic rosemary and maybe onion cut up (a driving snack).
author: Mike D.

description: Seriously good foccacia. I love to order the pizza foccacia, have them slice it, after which they wrap it in paper and you can walk the streets of city happily munching.
author: Eve C.

description: This is the best foccacia I have ever had.  I wish it wasn't so high in pure carbs so I could indulge more often.  What is funny is that I never cared much for foccacia until I discovered Liguria and WOW.  Melt in your mouth, light texture with perfect flavoring.  Tried several - the pizza and the green onion are my favorites.  The garlic was a little too raw garlicy - maybe if they had roasted garlic I would love it as much as the others.  As to the negative comments about the staff, I say engage them kindly and they will do the same.  They have been pleasant with me.
author: Mimi C.

description:
I remember coming here when about the time I learned to walk. I think it was called Sarocco & Co. then but I think the same family still runs the place.

Then, when I was tall enough to reach the counter, my parents would send me in (so they wouldn't have to get a parking spot) and get 2 pizzas wrapped, and 2 cut up. 

Yes, I was their focaccia gopher. And became addicted early. 

Now ingrained in me is the following: get there before 10AM on the weekends, and before 2PM on the weekdays else they will be sold out or closed. 

Pizza is the best, and in addition to the plain, onion and raisin, they've since added rosemary and garlic and olive bread which rocks when making Italian sandos with prosciutto and fresh moz. 

The local italian delis pick up their focaccia bread here and mark it up by at least a dollar or two, so cut out the middleman. 

And enjoy...it's unlike anything else.
author: Kelly R.

description:
A little salty.  Not the focaccia, the older lady who runs the place.  I never see any reason for such a bad attitude.  If you're at a point in your life where you're this salty all the dang time, retire already.  Time to let the daughter take over.  She is much more pleasant and plenty capable.

The focaccia is tasty, but can be a wee bit oily at times.  It never stops me from devouring it in large quantities though.
author: Squirrel L.

description:
GET THERE EARLY OR YOU WON'T GET ANY. The pizza foccacia is SOOOOO good. I always buy two, if there're any left. The plain is good to use for sandwiches.  So, are the garlic and onion, but plain is no joke. It ain't plain in terms of taste. I love a menu board that has only a handful of items on it. Point and go "Uh huh-huh!". But not really, they'll probably get mad. 

Go early! Or don't. Then there'll be more left for me!
author: Michael R.

description:
Mmmm....focaccia. Mmmmm....pizza focaccia. If I could, I think I can eat a sheet of pizza focaccia everyday for the rest of my life. And maybe a raisin one every week.

That makes me wonder if the folks that own or work at this place eat a sheet of focaccia everyday. Hmmmm...

Get there early, they sell out quick!

Oh, and their panettone is great as well. Not dry like the stuff you get in the box. Very yummy.
author: Pippi L.

description:
Mmm....warm pizza bread in the mornings!  Yummy!  

I used to frequent this place when I went to school at the big white church down the street.  When I'm feeling nostalgic or have a hankering for some yummy focaccia I head over here.  

It's family owned and operated and they have several different kinds: garlic, onion, pizza (my FAV!), etc.  

Only thing is if you come too late, they sometimes run out of certain ones. ...LESSON OF THE DAY:  Get it while its hot!
author: Row M.

description: Nice selection of bread that they've been making for years. Very well known in SF from people all over, including restaurants. The prices are great and the service is just as good. My favorite is the pizza bread. I grew up on this and it's the BOMB!
author: T L.

description:
This is the place that has brought me back from my Yelp hiatus. BC and I were on our way to pick up a friend this morning when suddenly he yelled, "STOP! It's open!" Totally unplanned but totally wonderful!

I had to flick off the green onions, but the pizza focaccia was amazing! It was slightly doughy, slightly crispy and very very tasty. Next time I'm in North Beach before 8am I will definitely be swinging by here again.
author: Karla G.

description:
Simply: likes focaccia.  I could have the focaccia alone and have been satisfied. Would definitely want to try the other toppings they have to offer. Only wish is that it's warm when we buy it, nothing beats fresh focaccia out of the oven.

Picky: Are you gonna wait in line at mama's?  Grab an appetizer here!  Did you just walk out of Mama's not satisfied? Grab a second meal here! I never knew focaccia could taste so good until I came here.  MINUS ONE STAR FOR THE NOT SO PLEASANT SERVICE.
author: Simply Pick y.

description:
After hearing about this place from seriously everyone who knows I live in North Beach, I finally took the two minute detour from my walk to work and stopped by this tiny little store.  

Pure HEAVEN, I bought the pizza and the raisin and decided to share with my office, big mistake, after my first bite I wish I had them all to myself.  This is how addiction is born.

The grouchy lady was there like everyone promised, but I've made it my goal to make her smile....someday.
author: T V.

description: Hip hip hooray for the Rosemary Garlic bread! We wanted a light dinner so I made a salad with romaine, cucumber, red onion and avocado. Plopped on some ceaser dressing, served up a slice of the rosemary garlic bread and it was a hit! The raisin bread is also very good. Stop in early cause they often are out of many flavors by 11 am.
author: Cindy J.

description:
I visited Liguria Bakery for the first time this morning on my ride in to work since it has so many great reviews... and at only 4 blocks from home, it was a short diversion. 

Holy crap this is good bread.

I brought the focaccia with me to a meeting, expecting to have plenty left over to take home to devour on my own. Once people started eating it, they couldn't stop. This stuff is the culinary equivalent of crack. I've promised to pick up no less than 10 slices of focaccia for co-workers tomorrow morning on my way in. It's that good. Even if you're not a big fan of focaccia, try it.
author: Brooks S.

description:
Liguria Bakery  place definitely has some nostaglic appeal to me. My dad used to take us here everytime we came to visit SF and I'd watch the bakery ladies wrap the incredibly fresh and delicious focaccia up in paper and string. Still the same 10 years later! 

I *highly* recommend the green onion focaccia. 

The bakery is located near Coit Tower(get some bread and take a hike up to see the view!) and across from Washington Square park. 

My only caveat-- cash only, and very likely to sell out before 12pm
author: CHERiE Y.

description:
Although I haven't been to this place in a couple of years mainly because I swear they are always closed, I grew up eating this focaccia. I went to school nearby  for 9 years and lived a couple of blocks away for 16 years so needless to say I was here ALL the time. Whether you get plain, tomato, or scallion, it's all good. I just wish they were open "normal" hours and for a "normal" amount of time. I swear they are open for like a couple of hours really early in the morning so if you want to try this place you better get there like at 8am.

Minus one star for hardly ever being open.
author: Diane M.

description:
Hello there. I am an addict of this place. How much of an addict? Well, I am 31 this year. If you take out the years I had to eat pureed foods, I would say I have been eating this stuff for about 28 years. Amazing, yes?

Being born and raised in North Beach is one of the best things that can ever happen to anyone. It's quiet apart from the fire house that's on Stockton. And the location is ideal to just about everything you need. Chinatown? Just a few blocks away. Little Italy? You're in it, son. Fisherman's Wharf? Just head towards the water. Awesome, ain't it?

And along with the fine neighborhoods that are around me, there's this gem of a place. Liguria. Making focaccia for as long as most people have been around. Still the same white interior but no longer are the shelves and windows lined with raisin bread and the Stella cookies. And Mr. Scirocco is no longer working as much as he used to. But he deserves to take it easy. Dude's been making focaccia for forever. Now, his wife and kids run the place. Mary runs the front of house with mom and her brother makes the bread with other people in the wee morning hours before the crack of anything. And the prices are very decent. Not like they were before when a pizza was a buck and a quarter and cutting is an extra nickel. What a bargain. Times have changed. No more butting charge and the most expensive is 4 and a quarter, I think. Still a great price for the quality they produce for you.

Sure, it may be greasy but that's the love and olive oil they drizzle on the pan and dough to make it taste sooo good. It's okay if it stains your fingers with the red sauce. Just lick it off and show off the proof of eating a Liguria's focaccia, the best in the City if not the US, in my opinion.
author: Anthony L.

description:
Speaking of things you can really get addicted to! The focaccia is so fresh and as is more typical Italian practice, they close when they sell out each morning.

For $3.75 for a sheet (or 3 for $10) - you can have your choice of rosemary, garlic, onion, pizza, olive, plain, raisin, and maybe one more. Perfect for making panini at home, cut up as appetizers for a dinner party, or load it up with more things at home and create your favorite meal. This is one of the most authentic artisan-produced items in the city at such an incredible price!

OTTIMO!
author: Mariangela S.

description:
Possibly the best food item to only be found in San Francisco.  I'm so happy that nothing's ever changed in the recipe since I first tried it.  

I've tried all the variations, but the pizza's my favorite.

Young and old all love this bread - still a favorite of my grandma's and a favorite of my kids - can't go wrong with this stuff, except that it's all carb and completely addicting.
author: s z.

description:
A-mazing.
Have not had foccacia this good since visiting Cinqueterra.
Go early, though- when they sell out (sometimes by 11am) they close!
author: Cole P.

description:
Love this place. Doesn't help the waistline that I live half a block up the street.

Rosemary garlic foccacia has the perfect infusion of rosemary herbiness with a nice hint of garlic. Neither is overpowering. It's fluffy (at least the day of), and...super oily. Which makes it scrumpdiddlydumptious. I've had all the flavors sans plain actually...other great ones are onion and raisin. The garlic always turns out flat for some reason.

Negatives? The women who work here are like the soup nazi. But the bread nazis. Very brusque in attitude, no nonsense. And, there's no care in wrapping up your delectable foccacia then picking up the phone, then handling your money, etc.

All good, strengthens the immune system right?
author: serena l.

description:
Are you kidding. This is the best focaccia I've ever had. Even better than when I was in Italy. (Well, almost) They are all good but my favorite is the raisin. My friend introduced this place to me last year and we would get one of everything and gorge ourselves in the park. It closes once the bread runs out. One of the ladies told me they use the same yeast strain since they started, making it the same way for decades. Damn good stuff. It's one of those secret gems that you would find only if someone else new about it. I love that.

I probably shouldn't tell anyone about this but oh well.
author: Suzanna G.

description: Good bakery.  Like others have mentioned the focaccia  bread here is to die for.  Whenever I'm in town I pick up a couple of loaves and take them back home for my friends and family to enjoy.  Definitely worth a try if your in the neighborhood.
author: Rob M.

description:
***Eat at your own risk***

Eat this Focaccia bread and you will never be able to eat the grocery store stuff again.  The Pizza one is their classic but the Rosemary is just as great.

***If you plan on buying from the bakery, you should plan on waking up at the crack of dawn- because they sell out FAST!
author: Judy K.

description:
I went on a Tuesday at 10:30am and there was NO LINE.

The cashier said their best seller was pizza-focaccia, so I ordered that.  It was pretty good for just being bread, tomato sauce and onions (fresh and crisp though).  You can just sit across the street at Washington Square park and enjoy the flavors. It's not as tasty if you take it home and wait an hour to eat it- mine got soggy.  (Try unwrapping it if you need to store it)

I also tried a slice of mushroom from a tour group that was there.  A guy in the tour group was so nice to me and offered his huge slice cuz he saw how bitchy the old Italian ladies were to me when I asked to taste or buy a small sample.  I didn't think my question deserved a bitch reply especially after I had already bought their bread.

I really wanted to try the plain and rosemary, but I don't know.  The pizza and mushroom weren't that much more spectacular than ACME's Herb bread or Focaccia bakery's own 60cent focaccia bread.  Not sure if I will be back to face those mean old ladies.
author: Cathy U.

description:
This "bakery" experience I had is the reason why I have started a Yelp account.

I saw this place a few weeks ago and finally decided to try it out. Granted, it's only open until 2pm, I went around noon. The place looks horrible. Empty display cases, a countertop, and two chairs are basically the highlights of the "bakery" There was no greeting, not even a smile, from the two women behind the counter. They told me they only had one slice left. It was noon and they were already sold out! If their business hours are so short but their foccacias are in such high demand, you would think they would make more. 

The jalapeno and cheese foccacia I had was pleasant. Probably the only reason for two stars instead of one. The bread was soft and toppings were just about right. Portion is a bargain for the price, too.

Overall, I doubt I will ever come back because of 1.) the crappy service (or lack thereof) 2.)afraid they'll run out of pizza 10 minutes after opening 3.)uninviting atmosphere, and finally 4.) did I mention crappy service?

For better pizza and service, try Golden Boy's a few blocks away
author: Steven L.

description:
Damn - Best FOCCACIA ever. I understand they simply close for the day when they sell it out. (Must be nice to own this business and not be too concerned with increasing revenue) Go early for best selection, especially on the weekends. 

Don't be fooled by the sparse, less than sterile space; just order, let them wrap it in white paper and tie it up with a string (like in "the old country"?), pay and leave to enjoy the best purchase you'll make this month.
author: KEVIN M.

description: Brusque, older, North Beach Italian-American women make the best focaccia in the known universe in exactly the same way and place that the family has done so since the 1940's.  Also, they are diehard Giants fans here.  This place is perfect, and anyone who gripes about the brusqueness or hours of business is completely missing the point, or has a massive branch in the butt.
author: Nick B.

description:
TB brought me here when we were first hanging out.

The bread is so good and fresh and huge, I had to share it with my friends at work..

When you're at North Beach you gotta try this out.
author: Malou C.

description:
I've been going to Liguria since I was a baby. And my Mom has been going there since the parents of the current owners were running the place.

The place is not flashy or fancy at all...and that's why it's a gem in North Beach. They make this perfect focaccia bread, in a number of flavors ranging from plain to raisin, pizza to garlic, and a few other flavors that includes olive, rosemary and onion. Each order (ranging from $3.25 to $4) comes in a loaf about a foot long and nine inches wide by an inch thick. You can have it whole, or ask them to slice it - but do NOT ask them to slice a big order. Mary'll give you a big scowl, and when it's packed - rightfully so.

The bread is soft, the aroma subtle, and the flavor shockingly good. As it has been mentioned here, they only take cash, the lines can be long on weekend mornings, and they do tend to sell out by noon. But you can also get frozen focaccia on occasion - it never hurts to ask. Not only is this a backup if they run out, but it's also a bit cheaper. Caveat - they may have run out of this too.

Suggestion - raisin focaccia for breakfast, pizza for lunch, plain for sandwiches. 

Enjoy. ;-)
author: Aaron F.

description:
Right across from Mama's, I always wonder about this place when I'm standing in line. So one day I decided to come and give it a try since I was in the neighborhood. 

They sell plain, tomato, or scallion-topped focaccia in BIG flat sheets. I love the tomato one.. I wish I could make some at home just like that. 

Make sure to come early if you want to choose your flavor. I f you come after 11am, there's a chance where you won't get your flavor of choice. because it will be sold out!
author: Juliane N.

description:
The ONLY place to go for focaccia!  I've been blessed to have been introduced to this fabulous family owned & runned bakery from the time I had spent in my mother's womb.  Try to get there early as they tend to run out of their most popular selections.  Nothing beats their tomato (pizza) & garlic sheets!  Take home, throw them in the oven to get them nice & warm and you're set.  The fam usually sneaks a few sliced pieces in the car ride back home  cause it's that GOOD you can't wait.
**They close early so plan a morning trip to make sure what you want is available.  The last time I checked their hours were  Mon-Fri 8am-2pm, Sat 7am-2pm, Sun 7am-12pm.  May have changed since.
author: Stephanie D.

description:
I heard in line yesterday their rent is being raised a thousand more a month?
Come on rich landlords! Liguria Bakery has been here 100 years!
author: liz h.

description: Some of the best focaccia bread you can get in SF! SO good. That's if you can make it there, since they're only open in the mornings until lunchtime. Perfectly textured, perfectly seasoned. They have a few different kinds such as Rosemary Garlic, Onion,  and Jalapeno Cheddar, ranging from $4-$5 for big, flat sheets of focaccia to share. There's always leftover and it tastes just as good the next day after being popped into the oven for a few. My favorite is the Jalapeno Cheddar. Don't expect any smiley or friendly service at all. Just some of the most delicious focaccia you'll bite into.
author: Felicia C.

description:
Every Italian in San Francisco goes to worship at the altar of Liguria Bakery. It's that simple.

Since I was a little kid my grandparents would bring it over. We would devour the 4-8 sheets in no time.  It was always major cause to celebrate and made every visit and holiday better. While we loved the prociutto from Molinari and Florence and my grandmother's homemade ravioli and gravy, it was the focaccia we all craved. 

The same is still true today. At family get togethers, if someone mentions they're bringing focaccia, everything stops for a second in anticipation. 

We serve it to every out-of-town guest with pride. This place ranks up there with San Francisco's most important landmark's.  Viva Liguria!!
author: Mark M.

description:
When I originally ate my first pizza foccacia bread, it was brought into my work place in it's distinctive paper wrap with string ties. I never knew the name of the bakery that made it until 20 years later at another good-bye party for a co-worker brought in that familiar paper with string.  I'm beyond ecstatic that I found my childhood favorite again.

Service is brisk and often lines grow after Sunday brunch. Definitely try the raisin, onion, and the mushroom versions...They are delicious. Pizza/Raisin are now $4.25...Plain/Onion are $4.00
author: Pauline L.

description:
Oh my holy god. 

Let me tell you a little story. 

Once upon a time, I lived in Italy. On some weekends, or for short vacation, I would go out of town. One particular occasion, I ended up in Acqui Terme--a small spa town in Piedmonte, so far south that it was almost in--get this--Liguria, the home of the most common/loved style of foccacia in the USA. 

Walking back to my accommodations one evening from the mineral water areas (over a Roman bridge, past the remains of an acqueduct, yadda yadda) I stopped in at a Gelateria and ordered in Italian. Being that my accent is awful, the man asked me (in English) were I was from. When I said San Francisco, a two hour conversation ensued where he revealed that he lived in SF in the 70's and 80's for about 20 years. 

I started to talk about hanging out in North Beach and how there is this FANTASTIC foccacia place that puts the ones with red sauce face to face and wrapped in butcher's paper and as I said it the man SAID IT WITH ME. 

This Italian, who moved back to Italy 15-20 years ago, proceeded to tell me that LIGURIA BAKERY has the BEST FOCCACIA HE HAS EVER HAD IN HIS LIFE, AND HE'S ITALIAN.

Damn. And it's true, too. It's like oily, soft, delicious crack...and, the story of Liguria Bakery and our mutual love for their breads sparked an international friendship that has lasted two years now!
author: Caroline C.

description:
I love this place! Very historic, very plain...if you didn't know what it was, you'd walk right past it. In fact, I've walked past it many times without even going in. But today, that "ignorance" ended (hey, I just moved here last month okay?). I went to Liguria at the suggestion of my chef friend. "The best focaccia," he said. "Okaaayyy," I replied. Well, after eating their basil (?) and sea-salt bread, I got say that it is got to be the most delicious focaccia I've ever eaten!

Their focaccia has amazing flavor and is very popular so you need to get there early. I imagine they sell out pretty quick. They have many different flavors so my suggestion is to go with a friend and try them all! Anyway, I'm bookmarking this place as it is a must go!
author: K. F.

description:
I famore Italians. Outstanding old-school foccacia. Definitely worth getting up for and standing in line at 6:30am pre-Thanksgiving. And I'm no morning person either. 

We hope to keep this North Beach institution in business forever!
author: Miles G.

description:
Linguria focaccia, Z- best, my favorite is the Pizza, its tomato sauce and green onions, get it sliced in 8 pieces, or get it whole and tear it off. It can be a little over salted sometimes, but its some good grinds!

You want the perfect Sandwhich, buy an Onion or Garlic focaccia, slice it, put pesto on one side, lay some turkey on it, top with a slice of provolone cheese, toast the bread and melt the cheese in the oven, take out, add some mayo to the otherside,top with tomatoes, balsamic vinaigrette dressed spring lettuce mix, a glass of red, an voila!!  You'll love it!

Enjoy!!!
author: Kool K.

description: Alright, every review concerning the service at this joint is accurate. No greeting whatsoever, hell, I wasn't even acknowledged until the older lady came out from the back room. The other lady that was there was chatting on the phone about the SF Giants. Even though she's a fan, I will not excuse her from the terrible customer service. With that being said, I ordered the garlic and rosemary focaccia. For five bucks, I had no idea how the order would turn out. The lady cut the focaccia up into strips and I think that the price is worth the product. It was nothing short of delicious. I swear it was so good, I finished the whole bag before I got home. Lucky for me, I was in the North Beach area in the morning so they weren't closed. If you want to get your fix, better hit them up early because everything goes fast.
author: Lauren L.

description:
Love love love this bakery

Super old school family place we've been going to for more than 25 years
author: Eric O.

description: Focaccia at its best!! If i lived closer around this neighborhood id probably be in line every morning to get one of the freshest breads in town! Love the pizza and garlic and rosemary. Ahhh im so hungry right now I wanna go and knock on the door. Haha
author: Nikka L.

description:
Get here EARLY, they usually sell out before noon.  The prices are good and the Foccacia is GREAT!  My favorite is the tomato, and the onion, oh and plain too, and the raisin.

Most of the restaurants grab this stuff up by the pallet-load and I'm told they ship world-wide, even with gas as high as it is I wouldn't be the least bit surprised.  

Did I mention get here EARLY.
author: Genevra P.

description:
You think you know if you already like Focaccia or not? Well if you have not had it yet from the Liguria Bakery you don't really know what Focaccia can be.

I discovered Liguria Bakery (est 1911) within a years of my moving to San Francisco at the time I was living near Powell and Bush so it was a pretty fast trip from that location. Now living in the avenues and a few years older I wish I could get to the Liguria Bakery more often but dang I really like sleeping in..

BTW reality check: Those of us in the Bay Area are very spoiled when it comes to breads, we have some of the best artisan bakers in this part of the country and have easy access to yummy Sour Doughs, Dutch Crunch / Tiger Breads and in the case of the Liguria Bakery, Focaccia yes this is probably the best or one of the best Focaccia bakeries in the United States.

All I can say is make time during some part of your life and get here at some time after 7:00 in the morning and buy a variety of breads and experience them. You can buy them whole and wrapped in paper and tied with a string or cut into 8 long pieces and tucked in a bag for oh so easy and good eating.

Would say try the green onion which some people have compared the flavor to onion cakes.
Try the Pizza which is just a great thing to snack on or have with lunch.
But you really can not go wrong with the bread here and it is worth just exploring to see which types you like.

Strong suggestion that visiting foodies make an early morning pilgrimage here.
author: Joseph A.

description: Delicious, fresh, warm rosemary garlic focaccia on a rainy day. 'Nuff said.
author: Johanna S.

description:
I went here for the first time today after seeing the dentist. The shop is located across the street from the (usually busy) Mama's restaurant. When you first see the shop, you can tell that it has been around for a long time....and when you try their focaccia bread for the first time, you will understand why. 

The focaccia bread here is fantastic. Everything they sell is made from scratch and very affordable. Simple and delicious. Just remember, they only accept cash. Also, they run out of foccacia bread quickly because it's so popular, so try to get there early in the morning. 

When we got there, she only had three types of focaccia left to choose from. So, we ordered the pizza and the onion focaccia. They were both delicious but the pizza one was my favorite. On the fluffy, warm crust, there is a tangy, rich tomato sauce, with buttery, parmesan cheese and a hint of basil on top. It will blow your mind. I'm definitely coming back here!
author: Kay T.

description:
I gained 5 lbs when I moved around the corner from this place. Coincidence? I think not.

This place is renowned for good old focaccia, served up in plain brown paper with twine. Very old-school Italian. Come right before closing and find a limited selection left; however, I have often scored a discounted slab when the ladies are trying to sell the last (and I mean, very last) of the day's supply. Don't mind burnt corners like me? Congratulations. You don't pay full price (NB: full price is still always under $5 anyhow).
author: Anna S.

description:
OMG. The BEST focaccia I've ever had in my life. Never been to Italy, but DAMN, i can't imagine it gettin better than this. I have been eating the "pizza" focaccia since I was born, and still to this day, every bite seems like a first.

Their rosemary and garlic is good too. I prefer the Pizza though.
author: Lauren C.

description:
Holy smokes! Hands down the best place for focaccia bread in the city. This place is considered one of San Francisco's best establishments. Located in the beautiful Washington Square park as well as across one of the greatest breakfast restaurants in the city, the bread here is amazing. I recommend olive, raisin, and of course pizza. 

Tip: come early because they close when they sell out...could be as early as 12 noon if it is a busy day.
author: John S.

description: true Italian style flat bread, succulent and a really low price, you'll hardly believe it, fresh bread ... excellent, Spartan, actually a real oven the old fashioned way! to frequent as much as possible!
author: Andrea M.

description:
I hate to rain on this Praise parade, but I too have been going to Liguria my entire life and a good deal of its lustre has washed away. I was born in  North Beach many many years ago, and have wasted my teen and college years in many a North Beach Cafe. 

I was in the area of Liguira a couple of months ago and for the 2nd time in the 06, scored some sheets of foccacia. 

first off, their prices have increased considerably while the size of the focaccia has shrank. No joke, I bought a sheet of Olive, walked to my car and began to graze, by the time I hit Broadway and Polk the thing was done, gone and over. And, I hit most of the green lights.

times change, new places open up who try and replicate and often do better than the original. I am one to hold the treasures of yesteryear close to heart, but after two recent visits to Liguria may have to leave this nice old Italian family.
author: Garfield J.

description:
Sunny: I have heard much great things about this little place on filbert and stockton from my boyfriend. This bakery is apparently very popular because they run out of their daily fresh bread quite quickly! He was able to pick up a garlic focaccia and my oh my! Tons of garlic but GOOD! If you are a garlic lover you must give this a try! The pizza focaccia and the jalapeno focaccia are pretty close 2nds. Next I'm going to try the raisin one and can't wait! 

Nolan: It is hard to have a favorite place in a neighborhood like north beach, but this bakery may be it for me.  Their focaccia bread is to die for.  It was almost unbearable to wait a month while they were on vacation, however the fact that they were selling out in record time after that is a testimonial to their quality of the bread.  The pizza is my favorite savory, however the garlic, jalapeno, and onion are all good as well, if you like sweet you should try the raisin.  This may be the best bread I have ever had, I wish yelp had 6 stars.
author: SunnyandNolan E.

description:
The lady at the counter whistles along to U2, is very stoic, and handles your bread and your money herself without washing her hands...

...and still, the rosemary garlic focaccia is pretty damn good. Into the oven it goes, for sterilization (and heat, of course).
author: Maximillian M.

description:
In the focaccia scene, there's nothing worse than crumbly, dry focaccia bread from Safeway. It is worse than, for example, hair down your neck in the haircutting scene. Lucky for us, we have the Liguria Bakery in North Beach. If you buy some of the pizza flavored kind, pre-sliced, and sit in the park katty korner, you might never make it back to work that day. 

The only place I've had better focaccia bread is Italy in the Cinque Terra, which is where it originated. It sorta blew Liguria out of the scene, but considering the horrors that await down overcrowded bread aisles in Safeway, it's all relative.
author: Nathaniel L.

description:
Liguria Bakery makes the best Focacia! I love eating the pizza (no cheese, just the tomato sauce) and the raisin sprinkled with sugar. Both are yummy.  If you dislike oily food, you might want to skip pizza and just eat the raisin.  So, why are they only get 3 stars?

1) Must go there before 11am; otherwise, you will see that little sign on the door that says "Sold out!".  They just don't make that many, and they don't care since they have many orders from restaurants.

2) Like Golden Gate Bakery, those people that work/own the place just don't care about their customers. They have this I-don't-give-a-sh*t-about-you attitude. Another similarity is both shut down couple times a year for a month. Not Many places can do that.
author: Ed W.

description:
Beware, this stuff is addictive.  

The focaccia has the perfect amount of salt, olive oil and (in my case) scallions.  My favorite is the onion.  

I may need a twelve step to stop carb fest 2009.
author: Monica L.

description:
I used to live across the street from Liguria bakery. I have seriously been eating focaccia from here since I began to eat solid foods. My parents are pretty hardcore Chinese and prefer Chinese baked goods, but even they had to succumb to the wonderful delights of this bakery. Despite the fact that my parents insist on eating the focaccia as a side to their jook (congee), long ago I decided to be more traditional and skip the jook part. I remember when this place only had green onion, raisin and plain as the only varieties. I thought their insistence on making their favorite traditional flavors was rather charming. The menu has since grown but it has continued to maintain its charm and character over the decades.

The raisin and green onion are still my favorite. The focaccia is baked to the perfect shade of golden brown and is finished with a touch of olive oil. The green onion adds a slightly crunchy texture to the bread and infuses it with a wonderful savoriness. The raisins are a perfect complement to the mouth-watering focaccia as it adds texture and hints of sweetness to the crunchy, and perfectly chewy texture of the bread.

This place is simply heavenly.

Tip #1: Get here early because Liguria only makes a limited amount each day and closes the store once it sells out.

Tip #2: Please take the time and effort to enjoy this delight fully by eating it while it is warm. I promise you won't regret it
author: Gary L.

description:
I'd donate a kidney for Liguria foccacia.
Get there early. Know what you want when you order, no CREDIT CARDS!!!!!!! Don't ask them to cut it up after they bring it out. Just give them the money and get the eff outta there!!
author: Jessica O.

description:
My friend who was visiting SF insisted that we get up in the gawdforsaken wee hours of a Saturday morning to trudge our scraggly, morning breath laden selves down to Liguria for what he was hyping to be the semi-religious experience of a Liguria focaccia.  We go way back to the Kindergarten days so I agreed to go along with this focaccia quest.  We promptly arrived at our destination to find a line out the door of like minded focaccia obsessed zombies.

OH Lord Have Mercy!  If North Beach is Little Italy then Liguria is it's Vatican.  This corner of Stockton and Filbert should be declared holy ground for the miracle that transpires in those ovens.  I had the pizza flavor and have since been back to try the onion, garlic, and raisin.  All were oven baked ecstasy!   

Bring cash, get there early, and be prepared to become a convert. 

Amen
author: Colin Y.

description:
I am a product of North Beach, by way of my parents, who grew up there and married each other.

I had grandparents in the area when I was a kid, so whenever we would have a big Italian holiday dinner, my grandpa used to bring the focaccia (although we said "fogacia").

I have always savored this as an hors d'ouvre.  Now as an adult, living on the peninsula, I wish there were a way to get this more often.  The grandparents are gone, so it's up to me to make the trek into North Beach, back to the roots, and bring back some good eatin' from this place.

Once you have had their product, you cannot ever accept the crappy imitations you find at grocery store bakeries.  Their versions are laughable, as Liguria has the real thing.

I have experienced a sort of "soup nazi' kind of routine when ordering, but will not deduct any stars.  I think that's just part of the allure, as they have you over a barrel with the best-tasting fogacia in these parts.

Buon appetito!
author: Lola A.

description: I had lived in North Beach for over 20 years, and I really miss this place. I love their pizza bread! They sold out everything at around 2pm. You must try their raisin and pizza flavors.
author: Caroline C.

description:
Bread=amazing
hours=not amazing

Many people complain of poor service/attitude but my wife picked it up, so I didn't have an opportunity to review.
author: N O.

description:
I grew up eating the focaccia at this little corner establishment. I went to elementary school at SSPP (big church on the next block) and would have the benefit of grabbing my focaccia in the morning and then agonize in anticipation for lunch time to eat this yummy goodness.  

They simply are the best tasting focaccia bread!! Once you try it, you can't go back to any other place who sells focaccia.  Try all the flavors.. they may seem awkward (raisin) but it really is just phenomenal. You can never go wrong with pizza.  This place is worth getting up really early in the morning.  So set your alarm and head over there, they run out of focaccia before noon on some days!
author: Theresa A.

description: A leeeetle pricey, but some of the best foccacia you can sink your teeth into. I love the olive and want to try the jalapeno cheese next. My SO is Italian and loves the pizza focaccia, says it's just like the focaccia back east.
author: Bella L.

description: Saw this quiet little place while waiting in line at Mama's so I Yelp'ed it. Ended up getting a pizza foccacia... It really is THAT good. -WOW-
author: Simon S.

description: I didn't even get to eat this fresh.  I had it microwaved after being frozen at a friend's house. Even then it was delicious.  Can't wait to go back and get more.
author: beverly l.

description:
Been going here my entire life. This was the only Italian place (other than Victoria Pastry) my old-world grandma ever bothered to accept she liked and would go buy the pizza focaccia from as a big treat...though she liked it just as much and just pretended it was for everyone else.  She liked to toast her slice, but it was just as good untoasted.  Simple, fresh focaccia.

Even decades ago we might have a small line to pick up the focaccia wrapped in white paper and white string.  Then walk home and enjoy the always delectable goods.  They seem to have more flavors now, but they sound gross (of course I'm sure they are all delicious).
author: Ye W.

description: Top-notch focaccia that supplies most of the city's restaurants' focaccia needs. Reasonable prices for this delectable bread that is made fresh in ovens that look like they are 100 years old if you get a chance to peer in the back room.  Plain, Onion, Olive, Pizza and maybe another I forget are your options around $3 for a sheet and they will cut it up for snacking as well.  5-star rating not given due to a little bit of coldness by the people working there and the fact that they handle money and food without washing hands.  Get there before noon or they likely will be sold out before their official closing time of 3pm.
author: Marc S.

description: Luv this place! Have made special trips from the east bay just for the foccacia so I can take it back to work.
