Get there early with cash in hand  they have one of those old things called a cash register) for the best selection of mushroom, rosemary, garlic, pizza, onion,plain (one more I can't remember)....heavenly bread! That's pretty much all they sell, and when its gone its closed! Its easy to miss, nothing much to it on the outside. And when you walk in its basically a counter, and they walk in the back to get the bread. Very old school, probably has been there forever in North Beach. But worth the trip and oh so delish.
author: Susan D.

description: The Best Foccacia I've EVER EVER HAD. Just thinking about it makes me get in my car and drive 2 hours for that piece of bread!
author: Ejm L.

description: The reviews don't lie! Liguria's focaccia is absolutely amazing...outstanding!  Just moved to North Beach a couple months ago and this place came highly recommended, and rightfully so! I decided to check it out today. I had been previously warned about the lack of customer service, but I have to say the older woman was very pleasant to me this morning! Even if I caught her on a good day, I really wouldn't let the service stop you from enjoying this delicious focaccia!
author: Nicole B.

description:
OK, let me just start by saying the bread is DELICIOUS!

HOWEVER, it is the most unsanitary bakery I have ever been to. HEALTH INSPECTORS, WHERE ARE YOU! I could not believe the way they run this business, it is disgusting. First of all, I walk in there and it is this cute tiny little hole in the wall type bakery shop...fine. Then, as I am waiting for the woman in front of me to order I begin observing the environment and am not liking what I see. 1. There is a $20.00 bill sitting on the paper they would eventually wrap my bread in 2. They are touching money 3. Answering the phone 4. Ringing up my purchase and THEN......they have the nerve to go get my bread from their bakery racks with their BARE HANDS without washing them at all. At least use gloves people. I was so close to making a comment, but decided I just won't ever return to this place until they change their ways. That is too bad because I really did enjoy my rosemary foccacia bread, but I will just have to find another bakery to buy any foccacia bread.
author: Helen M.

description:
Be ready for tasty large pieces of foccacia bread. HUGE. And it can be heavy. Do not go for a long walk up Coit Tower after visiting Liguria Bakery, you'll add about 5 lbs of added weight to your pack. However, if you choose to, you'll have plenty of carbo loading before, after and during the hike.

P.S. the bread makes a delicious crust for home made (but not really home made) pizza.
author: Judy L.

description: I have been eating this focaccia since I was a kid, since they serve this at Alana's in Burlingame. I ventured into Liguria for the first time today and the entire experience matched up to every yelp review I read. I waited in line and listened to two angry Italian ladies bitch and complain and move like molasses. One angry lady answered the phone and fought with someone about a union job and what a great Italian lady she was?!?!?! When it was finally my turn to order I got a little nervous and felt like I was starring in the soup Nazi episode of Seinfeld. I ordered two onions and put my hand out with the cash. The other angry Italian grabbed my bread, wrapped it in paper and tied it up. I ran home and ate the first piece in 5 minutes....AMAZING!!
author: Kathleen E.

description: I used to trade the Sunday Chronicle for a raisin focaccia when I was a paperboy on my way home from my route.  Now that I'm ancient, I eat mostly the onion and the tomato focaccia. Take your tourist friends and family there for a real treat to old San Francisco.
author: Kingmond Y.

description: The ultimate stop in North Beach for their Excellent Foccacia!! My first taste of these foccacia were in the mid 1960's and living not to far from here on Green/Mason St.  My mom brought these back then. Fast forward to the 1990's thur 2010 and I still indulge on these classic foccacia today. Still own by the same family I believe. Best eaten on the same day!!! ( if they last that long).
author: Wolfy W.

description: only place to get your foccacia on.  mushroom and pizza flavor por favor!
author: Dorothy L.

description:
Love Liguria's Focaccia! If I ever moved out of the Bay Area, this is one of the places I'd miss the most. The pizza focaccia is to DIE for! 
If you can make it home without eating it all in the car, it makes heavenly meatball sandwiches... just like the ones they make at Mario's (but that's another story)... Mmmm!
author: nancy b.

description:
I've been eating the pizza focaccia here since I was a tiny little kid. It's very easy to eat, no make that inhale, more than you really should. It's just so good and addictive. And then later when you're so full and a  bit bloated, you just wonder what the hell happened to your self-control.

I always order ahead for same day pick up just to be sure that they have what I want because they sell out super fast. I once made the mistake of going here to buy some plain focaccia for a stuffing recipe for Thanksgiving. It was a 45 minute wait! Never again. 

I was just here today and discovered that they now have mushroom too. When did that happen? Didn't try it but next time.
author: cyndi L.

description:
After reading so many great reviews of Liguria, we decided to try it out as a pre-Coit Tower snack on a sunny afternoon.  It's bothered me that people keep saying "get there early" without providing specifics, so here is what I gathered from my experience: they close at 2pm, and if you get there close to that time the selection is limited but not totally gone.  We got the pizza kind, which was actually the one I wanted to try most.  One order is perfect for two people, and they'll slice it for you so you can just take it across the street and eat in the park.  It's pretty good but not mind-blowing, however eating lunch for less than $4 in this city is always a treat.

The experience was comical - after hearing so much about this place we were kind of wide-eyed upon arrival.  The women behind the counter seemed like they wanted to be amused by our stupid questions but years of old school establishment apathy had deadened their facial muscles.  Not unpleasant, just all business.
author: Anna S.

description:
This place has been here for as long as I can remember.  This place was even here before my father immigrated here!  This definitely will give you that carb fix to last you through the day.  It's so lite, fluffy, and tasty that you will not be able to stop eating.  With so many flavors to choose from - Olive, garlic, tomato, plain, etc, it will make you feel like a kid in a savory candy store.  It's also still packaged the old fashion way- wrapped in paper, and tied with a string.  Everything about this place is so nostalgic, and the ambiance is so simple with white counter space, white shelves, and a cardboard sign that lists the flavors of the day.      

I suggest you get here bright and early because when they sell out (as they usually do), they close for the day.   I've seen it sell out as early as 11am which is why I always pick up some before I head across the street to Mama's for breakfast.
author: Nancy G.

description:
I grew up on this stuff.  I love it and yes, I crave it.  They make the absolute best focaccia.  Pizza is my all time favorite.  Raisin is next in line.   I think back in the day it was only $0.75.  Now, it is $4.00.  Yes, I've been eating focaccia from here for a long long time.

Expect lines.  Expect to be disappointed if you come late and they are out.  So come early and have patience.  Trust me, you will end up falling in love with it just like I have.....a very long time ago.
author: Stella C.

description:
My family has been eating Liguria's foccaccia (tho we pronounce it "fuh-GAHTzuh" like my great-grandma Noni did in her thick Northern Italian accent) for all of the nearly forty years I've been alive and probably a few more. The smell of that little barren shopfront makes me feel all warm and fuzzy inside. 

They used to make only pizza, onion, raisin, and plain. We would always get pizza, toast a sheet at a time then cut into squares an serve with antipasti.

One year we were out of sourbread for toast in the morning, so my grandpa served poached eggs sprinkled with a dash of white pepper over the toasted pizza, and a new traditional was born. You *must* try it.

The secret for Liguria's is to either get there early and hope they aren't sold out, or call in your order a day ahead and still get there early because they'll sell it out from under you if they are running low and you are late.
author: Nicole M.

description: Best Focaccia in the world! I grew up three blocks away on telegraph hill and have been coming here since I was 3 (1986). Never gets old. Simply the best!
author: Jeff H.

description:
same as another post, wandered in looking for change.....and saw they specialized in foccacia....which I'm not a particular fan off....but there 
was a line out the door.......?!  
watching what other ppl ordered and decided to go with the Pizza flavor......OMG........the best foccacia I've ever tasted!!! soft, fluffy, buttery, warm, with tangy tomato sauce and scallions......so delicious!!
author: Monster E.

description:
This place has been a staple in my family for a long time. My grandfather would go early early in the morning to get focaccia back back in the day. My family is from Genoa, so this place is like home. Yes the people who work there can be sort of mean, but who wouldn't be. They wake up at the crack of dawn everyday and it is all family base, so no outside help ( I don't think they trust others to make their amazing focaccia.) 
Some hints for those who haven't been there
Go Early, they close once they sell out.
Try all of them, they are the best. My favorites are the pizza and onion.
Basically once you have focaccia here you will not have it anywhere else.
author: T J.

description: All I can say about this place is " Unbelievable"!!!!. I have been going to this great bakey my whole life, and it has never let me down. It olny sells foccacia, and it sells out fast! Make sure you get there early in the morning to make sure that you can get in line, or pre order it over the phone. I reccomend the pizza and raisin. It is right off Washington square, so you can get some foccaccia and chow down in the park. Ask them to cut it for you so you can eat on the go.
author: Amy H.

description:
Thank you Yelp! I have distinct childhood memories of my pops bringing back the pizza and/or raisin bread every weekend all wrapped in the white paper tied up with string. I've finally been reacquainted with this place and it's still as good as when I was 7 years old. For some reason, I thought it was Chinese bread b/c my dad would always bring it back after visiting Chinatown...

Definitely has nostalgic SF memories for me. This stuff is damn good. Chinese or not.
author: Dave C.

description: The pizza focaccia is absolutely the best.  My mouth is watering just thinking about it.  It tastes the same now as it was 30 years ago and hopefully it never changes.  An SF institution, in my opinion.
author: Stephanie B.

description: The focaccia garlic is great. I wanna order some next time I have some spaghetti! Great food for cheap!
author: Jeremiah B.

description: This is the best focaccia I've ever had. I especially love the onion one. It can get busy in the morning, but it's well worth the wait.
author: Joy H.

description:
I heard about this place from my uncle, and I have to say that it is as good as everyone raves. My personal favorite is the garlic focaccia, which I usually end up finishing in 24 hours. This bread stays pretty fresh for a couple days if you keep it an airtight container, so it also serves as a great, quick breakfast.  What a delicious way to wake up.

This is also a great place to run to if you're waiting in the brunch line for Mama's across the street.
author: Lorenzo M.

description:
Get here early.  Or call ahead.  
Once they're out of foccacia they're out and the doors will be closed. 
Plain, Mushroom, olive, green onion, pizza, garlic, rasin.  
It doesn't matter. All are good.  All will be enjoyed.
author: M E.

description:
OMG- SOOOO good!

You really can't get better than this... but if you don't go early you're pretty much SOL.
author: Stephanie R.

description:
Go early or go home. 

Sheets of the most perfect, crusty, soft focaccia ever. The pizza: lightly sauced with a mouth watering tomato topped with a generous scattering of green onions. Raisin-perfect for both sweet and savory accompaniment. (neopolitan pizza with raisins, spinach & fontina is TO DIE FOR) 

Stacked in a neat package, wrapped in white butcher paper & tied with a string! Perfect. I've been eating Liguria focaccia for my 28+ years on this earth and have never found anything wrong with this slab of joy.
author: Alexis W.

description: The best foccacia bar none cooked in a coal fired oven.  Go early as they are old school and make a set amount daily and close when they are sold out so their closing time changes from noon to 3 many days.
author: Zudo P.

description: I'm not the biggest fan of soft breads, especially not pizza. I always thought the bread was too soggy, but this focaccia bread was pretty damn good. Coming from me warrants at least 4 stars, given my first statement. It was interesting how unfriendly the staff was, but I guess if you're good at what you do, service doesn't matter....or does it? Either way, good bread.
author: Camille T.

description: All I can say is that its good, no its not good it great ... Every flavor just explodes with goodness. Cant beat a nice big slab of foccacia for $4 ... Great for munchies :)
author: Anthony S.

description: Duh, everyone knows this foccacia is bomb. Kinda like everyone knows Mama's across the street is bomb. I'm writting this more for my benefit than to try to let the rest of the world know how wonderful their foccacia is, because they already know. Definitely deserves to be on one of the top 100 things to eat before you die, and I'm glad i did. The hubby picked some up yesterday and made a wonderful breakfast this morning with some chicken and egg white hash on top of a very tasty garlic foccacia. Yum, tasted like more! If you need some bread and it needs to be foccacia, dont waste time on grant st or the grocery store, just come to Liguria, but get therw early they sell out pretty much every day.
author: Audrey V.

description: OMGGGGG I think I found what I thought my heart left behind in Philly & NYC....PIZZA FOCCACIA or as my Mafia friends would say... tomato pie! You must get here early to get some of these special pieces of amazingness! But.... you can find them at many Italian markets in SF-  (i.e. Lucca in the Marina and i have even seen them at the Marina supermarket!) SUPER AMAZING and reminds me of my Mafia friends at all the Italian BYO's in Philly that I seemed to patron quite often with many bottles of wine in tow! (These go great with wine... aka let me have a few extra glasses since these little pieces of amazingness go quite well and coat the stomach!)
author: Kimberly M.

description: Love this place. The mother and daughter that run it close the store at 2 pm or whenever they run out of product, don't have to take no dirt from nobody, and it's the best focaccia in the city. My favorites are garlic, raisin and pizza. If they're out of the fresh stuff take home a frozen one and heat it up in the toaster oven.
author: Morgan L.

description:
Yep I'm joining the bandwagon. 
See below.
I  agree. 
Great great soft delicious foccacia, and i don't usually like foccacia.
and...
I love the quick no nonsense icy service and the white paper and string packaging. I'm a big sucka for pretty packaging.
author: MissSkip Z.

description:
BEST Focaccia bread in the city.
I've been eating their delicious bread for over 15 years now and I still can't get enough of it!  Go eat some for yourself, then bring your friends and amaze them with mouth-watering goodness and come out looking like a hero for knowing of the place.

And as nearly everyone says, GO EARLY.   It feels like such a crushing defeat to be craving some Liguria goods only to find they are sold out of what you want or are closed for the day because they sold out of everything.

Now, most of the time I can barely manage to get out the door without wanting to rip the bag open and chow down...however, if you want hold off and just deal with the excessive salivation you're sure to have, I recommend bringing it with you (and be sure to ask to have sliced up) either up to Coit Tower, or the more cozy Jack Early Park, both of which are within walking distance.  Then you can sit back, delight your taste buds and feast, all the while taking in beautiful views.

Mmmmm I could really go for some right now...
author: Kevin A.

description:
This place is amazing.  Get there before noon, get your focaccia, go home, indulge.

And while you're there, laugh at the people waiting to get into Mama's.
author: Keane N.

description: Amazing focaccia!  Wish I had a bakery like this in Los Angeles.
author: Michael R.

description: A trip to North Beach is never complete without a stop to Liguria Bakery. Best FOCCACIA ever.  If Italians tell me so, it must be true. Of course, also true from personal focaccia experience. I love the pizza and the raisin focaccias.  So fresh - straight outta the oven fresh. Must come early (at least before 11 a.m.) otherwise you'll be out of choices.
author: Marzan W.

description: Aptly named bakery. Liguria is famous for many things, foccacia being one of them.  This place would make the Liguri proud.
author: Roger H.

description: What an interesting place. GO early to get focaccia - which is amazing there when fresh, but they sell out of plain quickly. In fact, they close when they have sold out of the day's product... but stay open as long as something is left to sell. It's across from an amazing breakfast place... so stop by and get a snack while you wait in line across the street for a table...
author: Thighmaster M.

description: Yum delicious green onion and pizza foccacia! Prices have gone up over the past years, but the taste and service are still the same! I love coming here and getting my pizza foccacia cut so I can walk out and eat it :). The foccacias last a long time frozen and they taste delicious cold too!
author: Fiona N.

description: Ridiculously good foccacia...baked fresh in 100 year old ovens...wrapped in white paper... tied off with with butcher's string...and it's available unless they run out.  Simple, nostalgic, and one of the city's best food experiences.  If you're hanging out in North Beach ask them to slice it up so you can enjoy as you stroll. One of my favorite things period.
author: Frankie B.

description: They have great focaccia but holy crap are they rude. I understand that dealing with tourists can be annoying but every time I come here I get treated like a leper.
author: Dan M.

description: Yuuummm!  We stayed one block away from here for 3 days and we couldn't stop getting the focaccia every morning just to snack on. Great and freshly made every morning. The place has been there over 100 years and owned by the same family.  Definitely mom & pop shop.  We spoke Italian with the elderly lady who works there.  That gave us a little Italian taste.  You can't say you have been to San Francisco if you haven't tried this place.  One thing I should mention is that no gloves are used when serving the food.
author: Alyse R.

description:
what a find! thank you once again big eats! 

for $8.50 i walked in and out within 5 mins leaving with a tasty treasure tied up in a white little package and string bow :) i ordered 1 pizza and 1 black olive flavor and it fed 3 of us breakfast, and 2 of us the leftovers for lunch! 

this is a small bakery that appeared to be family owned with one thing in mind, no drinks, no cookies.. just great foccaccia! i can not wait to come back
author: Barbara C.

description: Ah, Mamamia, the foccacia is bellissimo! Get there before they sell out, before noon usually. The foccaccia lady, I have renamed the Foccacia Nazi, don't say hi or ask how she's doing today, don't smie and certainly, don't piss her off or you won't get your focaccia!
author: Mary M.

description: Nice mom and pop shop with some fantastic focaccia bread.  You must arrive early and be willing to take what you can get, but they do focaccia right here.   It's not really something I would necessarily recommend to go out of your way for, but if you are in the area and it's before 11:30 or so, head down there!
author: Smog R.

description:
This is one of thos places that us natives won't tell you about because not only is it good, but it is a great value.  I could live on their focaccia for days....in fact I one lived on their focaccia and water for weeks.

Shhhh...don't tell people...especially Dodger fans...these guys love the Giants ....Dodgers don't deserve such goodness
author: Al Y.

description:
if you haven't been here yet, you have been missing out on everything good in north beach.  i'm serious.  i realize no one is a focaccia connosieur in general.  i mean the stuff's usually pretty bad because its hardly ever available fresh out of the oven.  and who really wants to nosh on a stale piece of oily dry flavorless bread??

but liguria is a completely different deal altogether.   always fresh (but that also means limited hours).  and delicious flavors.  must try flavors are pizza and garlic - the garlic one is surprisingly sweet, not nasty pungent, well, ok, a little pungent, but surprisingly sweet.  this place supplies a lot of restaurants so everything is made fresh on location.  if you get the older woman who sits at the no frills counter in the tiny retail space out front, don't be offended that she doesn't waste her time or energy on niceties.  she is wonderful.  and seems like an institution all her own...

do stop by here on your way to napa or some other destination where you need to head out early AND want to arrive on a full stomach.  

and trust me.   get more than you think you want or need.   you'll be surprised at how fast it goes, and how much can go.  man.  the stuff is good. and it's cheap, for what you get.  so feel free to indulge.  i hope this place never goes out of business.
author: Nikki F.

description: Anyone who gives this place anything less than 5 stars is a pathetic incompetent moron who doesn't know what the hell they're talking about.
author: Doctor L.

description: This is the best foccacia I've ever had.  My dad used to bring it home when I was a kid and it's just as good as ever.  Whenever I go, my family asks for some as well so I end up buying large sheets, cutting it into squares and freezing it.  Yum!
author: Andrea P.

description: Truthfully these ladies scare the hell out of me, but I cannot stop eating their raisin focaccia bread.
author: C P.

description: My Italian friend brought me here. If she thinks this place is worthy then its got to be. Its awfully difficult to tell what this place is from the outside, even from the inside you can't figure out what it is. That did not stop the focaccia from being delicious. I'll definitely come here when I have some random craving for focaccia. Though it is quite a trip.
author: Peeta B.

description: This old-school bakery does focaccia so well, I really don't know what else they do. Family-owned and operated, they close when they run out of their focaccia. My sister introduced me to this gem a couple year ago, and now whenever I'm in North Beach in the am, I have to get my fix.
author: Ronny S.

description: Seinfield had soup Nazis in New York and we have foccacia Nazis in SF!  My buddy first brought me here years back and prepared me before going in.  He said, "Only cash, Don't ask too many questions, and No complicated orders!"  One story was a guy tried to order ten and have all of them cut up for him.  They told him to get out !  Yikes!  To get the best selection, get here early with cash and smile.  All of the flavors are good, especially the pizza and raisin.  They close up shop when they run out.  It is right across from Mama's so you could pick one up while you wait in line for a table.
author: Jason A.

description: This place is amazing. The ladies that run it are the best! Get there early, the foccaccia runs out. Have them cut it up for you so you can eat it right away, or take it home to make sandwiches or whatever. A gem!!!
author: karla m.

description:
This place is absolutely awesome!  This place sells out by late morning so we "planned" our order in advance. We ate at Mama's across the street and placed our order for focaccia while waiting in line for breakfast. I ordered the pizza, plain and rosemary. When I returned about an hour later, my bundles of fresh focaccia were expertly packed in the bakery's tradional white paper, tied up with bakers string and on their bakers shelf ready for me to pick up! This place is very "old school" italian. No signage on the store and really nothing to see in the store since the focaccia is in the back since it sells as fast as it is made! 
This is one of those places you must experience! I tried the rosemary for a change and it is now my favorite!
author: Mary H.

description: If you enjoy places that are untouched by time, not to mention good focaccia, Liguria is a must. You can find my full report at : http://bit.ly/9V0S8S
author: Mister Meatball M.

description: If there were a food that could give you an orgasm, this would be it....the pizza focaccia is really some of the best stuff I have ever eaten.  Just a reminder you need to get here early before they run out.
author: Denny R.

description: I never thought I'd be going somewhere to just buy focaccia and eat just focaccia but I have to say that this was a pleasant surprise.  The place sits opposites Mamma's (look for the long line) and if you weren't looking, you would more than surely never noticed it was there.  The place has history,  the first time I walked in, I started chatting with a guy who has been going there for 20 years as we waited.  He pulled me over to show me the old brick stoves at the back where they've been doing the same thing for years.  Albeit the price, nothing else seems to have changed much.   It tends to loose it's flavor the longer it sits around, so eat it straight away.  My first time, I couldn't stop eating the one "square" of green onion focaccia bread I got, almost ate the whole thing myself!  Go early,  they close when they run out, which seems to be around 12.
author: Alan P.

description: Noni approved!   My in-laws have been going here for 20+ years.  We love the pizza, onion and raisin flavors.  As everyone says, you have to get here early because they run out quickly!  We usually buy 3 whole sheets and warm it in the oven if it gets stale.
author: Chris K.

description:
I had a dream about this place last night, woke up... I realized it has yet to be reviewed by me. And I know without my seal of approval some of you might not know what to do with yourselves.

Liguria: Is awesome... but not without fault.
The ladies that work there are MEAN MEAN MEAN. They take their sweet ass time and only take cash. I do not lie when I say my very own aunt was soup nazi'd from Liguria because she got there 20 minutes late to pick up an order. They told her never to come back. It sullied the family name. We could no longer make preorders when that was still allowed. My Italian grandfather may have considered disowning her. (ok maybe not THAT far, but I bet it crossed his mind!) But my family has been coming here for literally generations. And thats a long time!

Fast forward to present time. My stepmother and I drive to SF at 4 AM on either Christmas or Christmas Eve every year to wait in line in front of this place. (Sometimes, it doesn't need to be a holiday, but we wait till 6 to go on normal days.) We are willing to sock priests in the face to get a good spot in line, because when they run out...they run out...they will slam the doors shut in your face with a smile. And no Italian Christmas is complete without this stuff.

THIS STUFF IS MAGICAL!!!!!! It is perfect. Exactly what you need in Focaccia. The right mix of flavor, oiliness, saltness, and plain old wonderfulness. I've been told by many an Italian, in my family and others....that Liguria beats anything found in SF, in CA and in Italy. 

My favorite: the very underrated; Black olive.

Seriously, I love food, but very few things are worth waking up at 4 AM for. I'd put maybe sex and Liguria in that category. In fact, I'm going RIGHT NOW! All this talk of focaccia makes me hungry!
author: Emily B.

description:
there is no other place to get foccacia in the bay area. my nonna has shopped here her whole life, as well as my great nonna. come before noon, or you won't get any ... even earlier if you want a better selection.

oh, and the pizza foccacia has been my lifetime favorite. its a must.
author: Alexia P.

description: I've been going to this place since I was a little kid. They serve the best focaccia bread in SF or Bay Area. I like the onion ,my wife likes the pizza and everyone else likes the rosemary and garlic. ==warning== parking is difficult and its take out only, a must do if you come to the North Beach area.
author: Howard J.

description: Fantastic breads!! Pizza Foccacia bread is awesome.The bakery has been around for over 100 years,  and it really is the best bakey in North Beach! If you want a little taste of what italy is like-then you should stop by this spot. Always a long line, and they close whenever they run out of breads-tell all sign they rock. The people that work there have a bit of an attitude, but once you taste the bread--all is forgiven.
author: Danielle C.

description: I was introduced to this place by a friend and have since been making it a can't miss destination before traveling home.  Prior to my friend's recommendation, the request from the family was always sourdough bread...not anymore, it's all about the raisin focaccia from Liguria!  Like the Yelp consensus tells you, you need to get in early before they sell out or place the order in advance.  So the next time you're stuck in the Mama's line and need something to hold you over, walk right across street and treat yourself to some focaccia heaven!
author: Jeff A.

description: I don't eat focaccia unless it is from this place! The store bought, dry & stale focaccia has nothing on this one. You have to come here super early to make sure you get the focaccia you want but believe me they are all good. It makes me drool just writing about it. I buy at least 3 slabs at a time becasue I usually eat half of one by the time I get home. My favorites are pizza & Garlic Rosemary.
author: Maritess N.

description: They don 't exactly gush warmth ("no foccacia for you!" )but the foccacia is wonderful.  I thought they had closed.  They decorated their store front with tons of Halloween crap.  Go early.
author: Bleep S.

description: A couple years since my first visit, this place hasn't changed and is still a gem. I got to share the experience with my wife this time, she loved the mushroom focaccia bread. Thanks!
author: Jesse W.

description: Finally got in there early enough to snag a pizza one- DAMN delish! Holding out on the last star until I try more, but I have to say- it was fabulous fresh...but later in the day, when it's not warm...TOAST IT! That was serious love. I was actually so in love with this giant focaccia that I shared some at first, and then licked the rest so no one would take any...mine mine mine! Can't wait to get more after a nice bfast at Mama's across the street- perfecto!
author: Diane S.

description: They only make focaccia bread. They sell out when they close, around noon. Try the garlic. It is powerful. No place to eat - take it to go.
author: Vena V.

description: By far this place serves the best foccacia bread in town. Get there early since they close up shop when they sell out of their focaccia which means by at least noon. I love their pizza foccacia. It's greasy but the bread is light and fluffy with just the right amount of salty, sweet tomato sauce. It's sooooooooo good.
author: b p.

description:
I won't repeat the raves about the focaccia - I think you've got it. However, my 5 stars include the authentic service. I have seen the counter ladies melt over a little boy they know from the neighborhood and gush over a neighbor's new baby. I live in the neighborhood and have been there often enough that the "Tude-o-meter" has dropped from downright rude to merely curt. Don't expect them to fawn over you - isn't getting a taste of their wonderful product enough? I love them just the way they are. 
On a serving suggestion note - we cut a 4x4 portion horizontally and use the slices as a bun for burgers - it's thick enough to still stand up to the juices. Garlic and rosemary or mushroom add a great taste to the grilled hamburger. Any of the flavors would make tasty bread for a sandwich. It's great alone, but why limit yourself?
author: Linda R.

description: Open the door and step back in time to a modest bakery.  The old fashioned register is gone (or moved elsewhere).   Prices have changed since I went in the 80's (pizza use to be 85 cents), but the freshness and simplicity of their focaccia can't be beat.  Still family run and worth a visit when you're in NB.  Go early; they sell out fast, especially on weekends.   I think you can order ahead of time; every time I visit, I see some pre-done for customers.  Bon appetit!
author: Jen L.

description: They only make a limited amount of fogaccia bread daily, 7 days a week.  Most of the time, if I don't get there by noon, they're sold out already... especially on weekends.  Their onion bread is to die for!!!  I still remember when a slice was 50 cents.
author: Kmaintl L.

description: WOW, where do I start.  Let me just tell you that I grew up on their foccacia.  I attended Sts. Peter and Paul for 9 years (grab some foccacia and eat it while admiring the churches beauty!) and this was so convenient for my family.  Field trips and late starts in the morning always led us to this place.  Such a simple business with simple prices :]  The foccacia is consistently good and each flavor is delicious.  All-time favorite is pizza, followed by raisin and then onion.  Make sure you go EARLY because as soon as they are sold out, they close up shop.  Uber smart in making us want it even more.  Even if the line is long, wait it out because I promise it will be quick as they move with lightening speed here!  Don't forget to bring cash!!
author: Nicole G.

description: Perfect thing to snack on while waiting in line at Mamas! Those breads are so yummy. I've seen people buy a whole bunch of slabs to take home, maybe they make sandwiches out of them. Maybe I will try that another time. I only buy one cut up and it never lasts to reach home :D it's gone in 5 minutes. I wish they were closer to where I lived, it's way to far to walk from the SOMA often :(
author: Kaushal P.

description: Love their focaccia bread -- tried others but there is no comparison. It is made here, therefore fresher than fresh. I used to go here all the time when I lived in SF --- remembering those high school days, getting sliced focaccia bread for 75 cents + 5 cents extra for the slicing and having a feast. Now the pizza focaccia is $4.25 (tells you how long ago the high school days were....) but it's still worth it. I came here today after a dental appt. because it was early, the focaccia bread wasn't sold out yet, and I had no kids with me! Like the olden days....and the people are still gruff as ever!
author: Lulubelle L.

description: I'm from the Midwest so I was a focaccia virgin until recently.  For a while, I didn't even know what focaccia was.  I thought it was some type of  fancy Italian shoe.  I then got hooked and started making panini sandwich's at least once a week.  My lady friend heard from her peeps at work that this was the best place for focaccia in the city so I headed out early to check it out.  It definitely lived up to my high expectations!  I haven't even made a sandwich yet because I eat the bread so quickly!  I don't know how they make it, but I'm sure their secret ingredient is crack.
author: Sloppy J.

description: Been coming here since I was a kid and I still crave their focaccia often.  4 stars because it was a lot better before when the older gentleman used to make it.  Since his passing I believe his daughter and wife, (correct me if I'm wrong) took over.  The bread is still great, but just not like before.
author: Eric T.

description: Delicious foccacia.  Get there early to get what you want.  Service was friendly and efficient.  The pizza and the garlic ones were delicious.
author: Aaron T.

description: This place is awesome!!!  They have the best focaccia ever!!  Highly recommend getting there early to get the flavor you want.
author: Shana W.

description: I decided to peak in to Liguria Bakery when I was waiting in line for Mama's. Quiet inside, I just watched what others ordered and tried to follow suit. The lady was definitely not the chatty type. The garlic rosemary foccacia bread is wonderful and you can have her cut it for you, if you dare. Come early because she sells out quickly. I heard her reserve some for you if you call ahead.
author: Rachelle T.

description: Forget about it.Forget any other focaccia that is.This is the best on the planet.Mike and Mary and the rest are all real class and their product reflects that.Be sure to stop at the St.Peters and Pauls and light a candle while your are there   ciao don
author: Don T.

description: The raisin is my favorite breakfast on the run...and the pizza is amazing- but here's a tip I stole from Plumpjack Cafe. Use the pizza (sauce side down) as a bun while making burgers at home. Its seriously amazing.
author: Noelle Q.

description: Yum! Heat it til it crisps a little and you'll be in heaven. This bakery's foccacia is worth the trip from San Jose.
author: Mary M.

description:
its just down the street from me, and i pass it every morning on my way to work.  definitely your neighborhood bakery.  it just so happens that it's awesome.  my favorites are definitely the pizza and the garlic or onion.  who am i fooling?  everything has been good.  definitely the best focaccia you can get anywhere!

though minus one star b/c they cut up your bread, then grab your bills or coins with bare hands . . . then cut up the next persons bread . . . though apparently this no-hand-washing policy has persisted for some like 50 plus years, its still kinda gross when you stop to think about it, of course that doesn't stop me from getting stuff here.
author: Jason J.

description: Those of you looking for the North Beach of old, all you have to do is walk into Liguria Bakery.  It is a bakery that only does one thing and they do it very, very well!  Focaccia!  They do have it five ways, Pizza, Plain, Garlic, Onion or Raisen.  Perfect for lunch or a very cool(and cheap) appetizer for a party.  They come in Quarter sheets or whole sheets(enough for 5-7 people).  MONGIA
author: Steven S.

description:
Classic Focaccia, just like Grandma used to make.

Beware, parking is not plentiful nearby.  They don't take anything except cash (why?  because they don't need to), and when they're out, they close.

The building is very plain, there's not much in the way of decor on thie inside.  You'd swear they just opened for business.

However, the bakery has been in existence nearly 100 years.  They're the "gold standard" for real Italian focaccia.
author: Mike H.

description: How many times have you eaten something and found yourself saying "oh my God" in mid bite? This was one of those times. Unreal flavor and freshness. Practically sold out by 11:30 on a Saturday morning and I can see why. This is the best foccacia you're ever going to taste. It's surrounded by trendy touristy spots in North Beach. No flash here. The signage looks like it hasn't changed in decades. It's no wonder the locals don't want anyone to know about this. More focaccia for them. I ate it for lunch. Saving some for dinner!
author: Mark K.

description: Love the foccacia here so much...especially the mushroom and pizza. It reminds me of childhood full of pizza bread.  I only get to come here when I am nearby and early in the morning. Come here any time after 11 or 12, no luck for you.  They are either closed or sold out of their more popular flavors.  Come early to wait in line for a couple minutes and you won't be disappointed. This place is probably the best foccacia place you can find in SF.
author: Stephanie L.

description: "Yummy Focaccias! Raisin is great.They run out of bread very early. Need to be there before noon. Focaccias are a tad oily though..."
author: Jocelyn L.

description: Our resident Italian in our office is the one who introduced us to this non-atkins friendly food. Every couple of weeks or so, he brings in Huge stacks of focaccia for us, and I stuff myself with enough carbs to last an entire month ;)   It is SO good. And now they have a couple new flavors, mushroom focaccia, olive focaccia, and rosemary. I didn't care much for the olive one. It's just canned sliced black olives tossed on top of the plain focaccia. But the mushroom.... YUM!!! it's sauteed mushrooms on top of plain lightly salted focaccia. My favorite is still the pizza one. Something about tomato sauce that I love. But as the other reviewers have said, make sure you get there early cause as soon as they run out, they will close. The don't have set hours, and in the summer time they close the shop for 3 weeks, as their vacation time.
author: Marina K.

description: Only giving it 1-star since I was so disappointed that they close at 2pm - was excited to taste some great foccacia after I read all the yelp reviews and but came 1/2 hr too late!
author: Jim C.

description: Wonderful.  Reminds me of focaccia in Cinque Terre (in the real Liguria).  Be aware, by 10 AM she may be out of your favorite flavor, and somewhat soon after that she can run out of everything.
author: Mike D.

description: Love the mushroom and pizza flavor bread.  Outstanding, no B.S. shop.  Love the ladies that work there, so nice and friendly.  The price is outstanding too.
author: Goose C.

description: More than 5 stars!!!  Been going here for over 30 years!!! Best thing about this place and the focaccia...is that it hasn't changed one bit during those 30 years!!! My family loves this one of a kind treat! Eating the pizza bread really...I mean, really brings back memories! NYC may have the best pizza...but I'm more than happy to have Liguria Bakery!
author: Terry O.

description: I love their focaccia, and the way its wrapped in paper and twine, in a shop that has nothing at all in it, ....and closes when they sell out. ( i just read that here and pilfered it. ha ha) i love the rosemary, and i have yet to try the pizza, the mushroom, and the olive. i finally went in last month, after having passed it often, and i consider it one of my favorite finds of 2006.
author: sarah C.

description: A buddy of mine recommended this place to me.  I am sceptic when it comes to recommendations for food.  So I had to empircally verify if it is in fact delicious. Hands down, the best foccacia I've ever had.
author: Ren C.

description: I will go out of my way for Liguria focaccia.  I wish I could get my sorry ass over to North beach earlier before they sell out.
author: Larry B.

description: I know there's a ton of 5 * reviews but I just have to add my own.  I've been eating Liguria's focaccia bread since I was a little girl.   My dad would work in SF on the weekends and he would often come home with that white paper package wrapped with string.  Their tomato and onion are my favs and it tastes the exact same way it did 40 years ago -- yummy!   We can't have a family get together without this for an appetizer and we always buy an extra slice or two for the next day.  But try to eat it fresh on the day you buy it -- it can't get any better than this.
author: Robbie R.

description: Being a resident of Southern California for all of my life, I've never heard of "Pizza bread," that is until my girlfriend introduced me to it.  When I first had it, the consistency of the bread jumped right at me.  I was expecting it to be warm, but being cold actually was pretty good. really good.  I can tell why this place can have such a loyal following.  I haven't tried all of the different toppings, but garlic is pretty good too.  I've heard that they close when they sell out, fortunately, i've never had the problem of them selling out before arriving, THANK GOD for that, because i would be so bummed if that were to happen.  Every time I visit the city, this is one of the places that I MUST go to before returning back to southern california. 5/5 stars, definitely as good as it gets. YUM
author: Bryan T.

description:
A solid four and a half stars for Liguria; 5 stars may be pushing it...

The pizza bread is fantastic; tried the garlic but surprisingly I did not like it as much (still good, though).

As stated by other yelpers, the old Italian woman that is usually there can be a little intimidating but this just goes to show that if a product is that good, customers will beat a path to the door.
author: John C.

description: Breakfast of champions!  I ordered the pizza, and was given enough to feed not only myself, but all of the old grannies practicing tai chi across the street as well!  They only do one thing here, but they do it very well.  This is strictly take-out.  What prevents me from giving this place my first ever five-star rating is the mean service that I saw some of the people waiting in front of me receive from the women working there.  They were very nice to me, however.  But then who needs service and ambience?
author: Nathan W.

description: For truly authentic, indescribably wonderful Italian-style focaccia, there is none better in SF.  From the soft, tender moistness of the middle to the perfect crispness of the crust, with the perfect dash of olive oil and light salt, it's amazing.  And hugely filling.  Have them cut it up for a wonderful snack food in nice stick-sized pieces.
author: Don H.

description: When I was a kid and went to my godparents' apartment for dinner, I knew I was in for a treat when I saw that white paper tied with string sitting on the counter as I walked into the kitchen. I thought it came right from Italy special delivered. Later as I grew up and started wandering around the neighborhood, I discovered it came from an abandoned-looking storefront just down the street from Butch's bar. One of North Beach's treasures!
author: Chris E.

description: OK folks I've got another place for you its called Liguria Bakery , a place where they make the  best focaccia in the " World " this is another place my family has been going to for the last 98 years and i still go at least twice a week.They have 10 different types from plain to onion to raisin , tomato even jalapeno. But keep in mind they usually sell out by noon and the wait can be long so place your order in advance. This place is so good i wont i mean i will not eat any one else's "Focaccia". Once you've had them you will be spoiled and any one else's that you try will never compare. My two favorites are the Tomato and Onion. so the next time you haven a party or some kinda holiday dinner at your house or you just want the best Ficaccia you've ever had just think Liguria Bakery i promise you wont be disappointed............ And no sorry people they don't use cheese on any of there breads or it would be pizza bread not Fociccia
author: Jeff P.

description: I just went here yesterday. It's a small bakery on the corner and there were 2 ladies working in there...not very friendly by the way. After reading all the reviews, I wanted to get here early to make sure there was anything left. I got here around 11AM and they'd already ran out of more than half of their menu! I got the pizza focaccia, which was $4.25. They also have them cut up into pieces, but I got the whole one instead. Most of them are $4.25, and I think there were a couple that was $5. They also have frozen ones for $3. It was delicious! Next time I wanna try the Garlic and Rosemary. Parking was crazy though...
author: Christine C.

description: Buy four pizza focaccia wrapped up in paper and twine.  Eat one in the park while letting the sun warm your face.  It's baked there in the early morning and the place closes when they sell out.  Sells to many of the restaurants in the neighborhood.  Mario's sandwiches wouldn't nearly be the same without them.
author: Kev M.

description: Old school!!  They do only one thing but they do it great.  Order any of the foccacia and you can't go wrong.  The plain or garlic rosemary make for great sandwiches.  Get there early because when they run out they close up.
author: goldberg d.

description:
Yummy Foccacia. Get in early.. (before noon on weekends) to get the best selection. We always try to get a chunk of this foccacia. We love the plain, pizza as well as the rosemary.. 

The people running this place always feel like the family (which we don't have) in Italy :)
author: Tarak P.

description: Holy crap the focaccia here is good.  Beware, most of the bread is sold by  noon and you'll be left with frozen focaccia if you're lucky.
author: Helen B.

description: Best bread ever!  I've been going here since I can remember, over 20 years.  We used to hang out in the front just to get a whif of the aroma.  This place brings back memories.
author: Samson M.

description: Nothing new to report here. I brought my aunt here recently and she absolutely loved it. She was evening thinking about how she could take it back with her to Los Angeles. I'm more of a purist, I prefer plain or rosemary.
author: Mark B.

description: Liguria...Orgasmically good.  I really think that should be their motto...
author: Knathan R.

description: The raisin focaccoa bread is so unique and tasty.  You'll be going back for more, even though customer service is not a concept there.
author: Lily S.

description: The black olive bread is incredible. The garlic one is fantastic. Get there by 10a on Saturdays if you want the full selection b/c they run out fast.
author: suzie k.

description: I walked in and it smelled so good, the lady working there wasn't mean to me, nor even paid attention that I was there, but I just walked in to check out the focaccia choices since I heard great things about the place and my friend was in line at Mama's. While tempted to purchase something, I was able to resist and went back to the line. I traded with my friend (who was visiting from Pittsburgh) and she headed over, she took a little while and I assumed that she had been taken by the enticing aromas. As soon as I had that thought, she came walking across the street some tasty rosemary focaccia in hand. We couldn't help but start munching on it. It was funny that we were eating focaccia while waiting for our brunch, but it was just too good.
author: Katherine R.

description: Small little shop that serves one thing....foccacia.  And it's damn good.  I just had the pizza foccacia while I was in and made the grave mistake of not warming it up.  Still, it was cheap, large, and absolutely delicious.  If you're in the area, you simply must stop by.
author: Zach S.

description: Easily one of the treasurers of San Fran.  If you eat focaccia in a restaurant in this city that you die for, chances are it came from this joint.  Walk across the street to Mario's for a bad ass sandwhich on this tasty dough.  Get there early peeps as this place closes shop as soon as they ditch inventory and that is early!
author: Porfirio R.

description:
OMFG!!!! it's THAT good. my old roommate introduced me to this place. she's in the restaurant biz and told me a lot of places come here to get focaccia for their restaurants. 

not only is this place so dirt cheap but oh-so-fresh. but beware - come here early to get first dibs. i'm actually drooling as i write this... 

it's kitty corner to washington square park and across from mama's. love love love this place. this is a must go if you're in san francisco - or if you live there.
author: Miss O.

description: Focaccia is just cooked dough....until you eat it here. I don't like bread, I don't like italian starch...but I love coming in here, getting a plain, wrapped up in my paper and tied up with string. These are a few of my favorite things.
author: B S.

description: The foccacia here is the best in the west but as most reviews state the service is not that great. You may want to call in ahead of time and have them hold some for you to pick up as they tend to run out early. Try the raisin. Its absolutely fabulous but you must love raisins. You will not find anything better anywhere else this side the Mississippi!! Seriously! I have been enjoying their Foccacia since I was a kid in the early 70's!!!
author: Theresa M.

description: One of SFs best kept secrets.  Ive been going there for 20 yrs and its hasn't changed a bit. ( well the price has gone up a little).  YUM.
author: laura b.

description: after stumbling accross Liguria on yelp, I decided to try it out.  It's exactly how people describe it.  AMAZING focaccia!  I only bought 2 pizza and one garlic, but i like the pizza a bit better.  Perfect for football parties!  I'm planning to get the rosemary garlic for the next Chargers game!!
author: Andrew G.

description:
i'm so excited!!!....
and i  just can't hide it!!!!...
i'm about to lose control and i think i like it!!

that's  how i feel when i'm on my way to Liguria. get there early, people! they run out quick and close early! sometime's i'll drive ALL the way from Pacifica to North Beach to get some scrumptious foccacia only to find the "closed" sign up. my heart shatters right then and there. it's no fun being deprived of raisin foccacia.
author: Regina C.

description: This is the best focaccia that you will taste in Northern America! The only place that rivals it is in Italy itself, that must be why this place has been around for nearly 100yrs. If you're in San Francisco, it's a must!!
author: alice r.

description:
I finally had a chance to try their bread after several years of hearing about it (I finally woke up early enough on a Saturday).   

I ordered the mushroom focaccia,  the bread was soft and slightly flaky.  It tasted pretty good but then anything with that much butter and olive oil on top would taste good!  It actually had way too much butter so it was slightly on the salty side.

The reason why I did not give this place a higher rating is that there is nothing special about their focaccia.  I've tasted similar if not slightly better foccia at other places.   Safeway's fresh baked focaccia would be comparable (only when you buy it when it comes out of the oven).
author: Roast D.

description: I was not a fan of focaccia bread, until I had a sandwhich at mario's Bohemian cafe.  They use Liguria Bakery focaccia bread, they make amazing sandwiches.  They let me know about the Liguria Bakery, omg it is soooo good.  I am going to need to start jogging every day but it is so worth it.
author: Nolan E.

description: Yum!  Focaccia.. that's it.  Raisin, onion, garlic, pizza.. all the flavors are highly recommended.  The official closing time is 2pm, but in reality they close when they run out of da' shiznit.  The unassuming nature makes this a true neighborhood  find.
author: Justin S.

description: I was there earlier this month, I can't get over it!  I'm not an early riser but made sure than my first morning in SF, I woke up and was out the door before 9am with my printed map and the map on my phone showing me which direction to be going in.  The ladies didn't seem as bad to me as the others make them sound.  But even if they were, the bread is so worth it!  I was told to freeze whatever I don't eat within a day.  I just defrosted it and microwaved it.  All I can say is go.
author: Karen T.

description: They only sell focaccia bread, but they do it so well they don't need to sell anything else.  This family run joint makes just enough to make it through lunch, plan on getting there before noon to get a full selection.  Amazing bread that does freeze well, so stock up when you buy.  Customer service is a bit surly, but as long as you wait in line and don't complain you will be treated fairly.  A San Francisco Institution.
author: Mickey D.

description: OMG! You would never know this place was even there unless someone told about this place or you walked in to see.  This place has the best focaccia bread you can imagine.  The onion, pizza and if you love garlic, is the best.  They also have other toppings.  It's so soft and FRESH.  You better call in your order or go in early to get what you want because they DO sell out.
author: Susan W.

description:
In a world of chain food and pretentious restaurants, it is nice to enjoy a place that does one thing and does it better than anyone else.  If you want focaccia, there isn't any place better and that includes Italy.

I've been eating Liguria's bread for over 50 years, and though I Ieft the area years ago, no trip to San Francisco would be without an early visit to Liguria.  

If you want to walk into a place and be greeted by Chad or Buffy,  standing there holding menus, giggling and showing you to your art deco table - forget it. The store front hasn't changed, the counters haven't changed and the simple delight of walking into a classic old bakery and starting to salivate at the smell of fresh focaccia is still one of the small pleasures. 

The focaccia is fresh and hot, hand cut if you want it, wrapped in butcher paper and tied up with string (remember string?).  The string is then cut using the finger (not a pair of scissors).  If you want a backrub while you're waiting - go somewhere else.  The bakers/employees have been up since 5 a.m. (or earlier) and are working magic.  BTW - that would be the same family since 1911.  

As they near their 100 yr anniversary, I'm just happy that I've gotten to eat the last 50 years of it.  Grabbing some Liguria focaccia, a fresh crab claws and some wine and sitting down at the wharf - it doesn't get better.
author: Dexter H.

description: Iconic and best of all, delizioso!  Yes, 6 days a week, they make just enough to close by around noontime. If you're feelings are easily hurt by non-smiling curt service, don't go there. You'll leave wondering what you did to piss them off.  If you crave the best foccacia (pizza bread) there is outside of Italy, this is a must.  You'll leave knowing that you'll be back to this North Beach treat, very soon! (Like the past 38 years I've gone there, cash only)
author: Norm T.

description: the pizza foccacia (tomato and green onion) is the best!  the olive one is OK, i found it to be a bit salty for my taste.
author: Wendy S.

description: This is my favorite food place in the world.Raisin for breakfast with a cup of coffee watching happy,smiling,and singing people do tai chi in the park.
author: Jack M.

description: I've been to this place since I was in the 6th grade many, many years ago.  The pizza "cut" used to cost me $1.75 and it now costs $4.25.  Anyhow, the foccacia that I have found a liking to now is the garlic - it's so good - I'm snacking on it right now.  The place looks exactly the same as so long ago except that the menu has expanded to include "fancier" items such as jalapeno + cheese or rosemary garlic.  I think you still need to go earlier in the day before they sell out and close early for the day which occurs regularly.
author: C K.

description: Their focaccia is delicious.  I've eaten a whole slab for lunch... more than once.  Is that bad?  It's so worth it, though.  Fresher is better but I pop frozen ones in the oven at 375 for about 5 minutes and they come out warm and chewy and glisteny.  It's the closest to the best I've had, which was when I got randomly stranded in Genova, hot out of the oven with the edges golden crisp, porous and filled with olive oil, and olive oil dripping down my wrist.  Sigh, sometimes I wonder if it is better to have tasted to never taste again or to have never tasted at all.  Anyhow, paired with deli meats and cheese from Lucca, you have yourself a wonderful meal.  They also take orders at Lucca's for Liguria focaccia if you live closer to the Mission and would rather not trek to North Beach.
author: HW R.

description: Had some awesome focaccia bread someone else bought from there.  Can never make it myself during their limited hours and/or "closed when sold out" hours, though.
author: e g.

description: The best foccacia in the city and beyond. So old school, bare bones. You wouldn't even know it's there. Looks like it hasn't changed since 1946. But, that's all they do-focaccia-and they do it oh, so well.  My favorites are the Raisin (great pastry or donut alternative for meetings) and the pizza.
author: Lucie F.

description: No doubt about it but this is the only place to get the best foccaccia...and you have to get there early on sundays so they dont run out...if your there early buy enough and have some eggs over easy and a glass of choclate milk and you'll be in heaven...i know i am:-P
author: Ron S.

description: ambrosial, appetizing, delectable, delicious, flavorful, luscious, palatable, savory, scrumptious, tasty, yummy focaccia ... especially the pizza one ... too bad they're a little outside my "within walking distance" radius
author: spiff e.

description: I used to live in this neighborhood and yes, this place is the total bomb.  Anachronistic in a yummy way.
author: Joseph S.

description: OMG, Liguria Bakery!  I've been coming here for way over 20 years and it's still the greatest! The rasin focicca is the the best breakfast treat ever and all the other fociccas are just plain yummy! This place is a real find and who knows how much longer Liguira Bakery will be with us. Go now! Go early! The taste will enchant you.  The memories will haunt you and you'll be glad!
author: Yvette P.

description: yes, this is how you do it.  you make one thing perfect, in this case, the best focaccia, and that's it, you don't mess around, neither do those ladies, so stop trying to mess with them.
author: Shona M.

description: This classic Italian family dishes out the best focaccia I have ever known.  When you go in old friends are sitting down chatting.  I love the Garlic focaccia!
author: Antony E.

description:
My Grandfather used to come here in the 1920's - and each generation
in our family as continued ever since. My favorites are the tomato, the raisin and the onion. The garlic is good too, but strong. It is the best foccaccia bread you can find anywhere - and tasts best within the first couple of hours after baking.
The only reason I didn't give this reiew 5 stars is because the
people who work here are unfriendly.  The daughter acts like
she hates being there - the older lady with the dark  hair has a sour puss,
look.(That's her in the photo shown below.)  You don't get much conversation - just place your order - they give you the price and and a half ass thank you - and you leave.   It is really too bad because Mr. Asti and another elderly man who used to work there were always pleasant and smiling and interacted well with customers. The next generation, forget-about-it!  Just give me the money and leave!  What a miserable existence to act so unappreciative that your family has built up this wonderful and profitable living for you and you act like you have a grudge.  They could be having fun while they ring up the $$. Actually, I
should say that the son is okay. The place is original - nothing has been changed and no remodeling and I suppose that is a good thing.....of course, you wouldn't expect a Genovese Italian to spend their money on fixing the place up. Ha! (Hey, I am 100% Italian and half Genovese, so I can get away with that remark). Anyway--------the foccaccia is 5++ stars!
author: Girly Foodie F.

description: Absolutely amazing.  Thank you yelp community for pointing out this gem.  The bread is not to be missed, and could be the BEST single food available in the Bay area.  My only complaints are the fact that they're usually all sold out by noon or 1pm on weekdays.  There's also a cranky "bread-nazi" women running the place, but since the food really deserves  10 stars, They still get 5 stars, even with their short-comings..  Mmmmm Mmmmm
author: John M.

description: family run foccacia bakery...  i've lived in nB for over 13 years and i've seen it goes from 2.25 for pizza to 4.00.  hey... blame it on inflation or the damn energy crisis, but the bread is delicious.  if ur lucky... u can catch a batch coming out from the oven.    personally... i like the onion, mushroom or olives.  you can't go wrong with any of your choices, but beware....  the later u go...  the chances are they are going to run out of the foccacia that u want.  :P
author: jay c.

description:
okay when I first heard about this place I was a non believer...I mean how do you get by in SF just selling Focaacia especially when it seemed like you were never ever open....totally thought it was a front...until I tried their foccacia and it's some of the best I've ever had ..I saw the light ....so get there early otherwise there won't be any left...=( if you do get there late...don't even bother choosing from the menu just ask them what they have left cause it'll just save you a lot of time...=) The mushroom is excellent and it's a great snack for while you wait for Mama's...

beware...it is a little on the oily side ..but that's what makes it good right?
author: Joy Y.

description: I was lucky enough to try some at a co-workers house and I could not stop eating the stuff! I can't wait to get more! If you have not tried this foccocia before, you are totally missing out, let your tastebuds live a little and make a trip down to get some. Best carb indulgence. Raisin, green onion, garlic or pizza- all are a little slice of heaven.
author: Rhea A.

description:
get here early b/c they close when they run out!

favorites are mushroom, green onion, olive, plain

if you want to make a sandwich w/ them, they're pretty thin, so you have to use each one for the top and the bottom.  

you can ask them for a slab or to cut it up into smaller pieces to eat while you're waiting to get into mama's!
author: rien d.

description: Highest quality focaccia bread.  Go early.  Yum!
author: Grace R.

description: The foccacia here is very tasty, sometimes a little too oily, but very good. I give them three stars because they don't seem to care about sanitation. They handle cash and then go handle their product with bare hands. It's been mentioned in an earlier review. Nostalgia for old-school style aside, just because you are popular and have been functioning as such for years does not mean you cannot upgrade your mentality of sanitary standards. I am certain they've heard this before. How hard is it to slip on plastic gloves before handling the bread? Really... how hard?
author: Maria Y.

description: I discovered this unassuming bakery when I was working on the Peskin Campaign. If you thought you never liked Foccacio bread you might be mistaken once you've tried Liguria Foccacio - available in raisin, onion, plain and pizza. If you live in North Beach/Telegraph Hill you probably already know that they are usually sold out by noon if not earlier so for the rest of us set your alarm clocks for bright and early and put on your coat because the trip will be well worth it.
author: Sequoia N.

description: +This is the absolute best place for foccaccia in SF. I have been going there since the 70's and no place beats it. You have never tasted anything like it. It makes all other foccacias taste like cardboard!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!
author: taylor s.

description: helllla goooodddddddd!!!! and cheap......
author: m p.
